en.question: What should you do when merging?

options.A: Merge at a much lower speed than the flow of traffic.
options.B: Use your mirrors to make sure the gap in traffic is large enough for you to enter safely.
options.C: Merge without signaling.

en.description: Check your mirrors and merge smoothly without slowing down traffic. Always signal.

en.question: Documents related to hazardous materials transportation must be stored_

options.A: Attached to the sun visor
options.B: In a box on the trailer.
options.C: In the pouch of the driver door.

en.description: Keep the papers for hazardous materials in the driver door pouch. This way, they are easy to reach if needed.

en.question: Which of these statements about driving through a tunnel is correct?

options.A: There may be strong winds when exiting.
options.B: Turn off all lights inside the truck.
options.C: Keep windows open for fresh air.

en.description: When you drive out of a tunnel, you might feel a strong push of wind.

en.question: Among these vehicles, which is more likely to experience off-tracking during turns?

options.A: Tractor with 45-feet trailer.
options.B: 28-feet box truck
options.C: 45-feet straight truck

en.description: When a big truck turns, the back end can swing out. This is called off-tracking. A tractor with a 45-feet trailer is more likely to do this because it's longer and the way it's put together makes the back end swing out more when it turns.

en.question: Under what circumstances should you sound your horn?

options.A: To let others know you are running late.
options.B: To say hello to a friend on the sidewalk.
options.C: If it helps to avoid a crash.

en.description: Use your horn only if it can help stop an accident from happening.

en.question: Identify the incorrect statement regarding alcohol consumption.

options.A: A drinker can control how fast his or her body absorbs alcohol.
options.B: Alcohol goes directly from the stomach to the blood stream.
options.C: BAC is determined by how fast you drink; how much you drink and how much you eat.

en.description: A drinker can't control how fast his or her body absorbs alcohol.

en.question: If your vehicle is missing _ or more leaves from any leaf spring, it won't be allowed to be used.
en.description: If a quarter or more of the leaves in any leaf spring are missing, your truck can't be used until it's fixed.

en.question: Select the correct statement regarding the transportation of hazardous materials.

options.A: Hazardous materials can be disposed of in regular trash bins if the containers are sealed.
options.B: Any truck carrying any amount of hazardous materials must have placards.
options.C: All hazardous materials present health and safety danger.

en.description: Hazardous materials are always dangerous to health and safety, no matter what kind they are. They can hurt people and the environment, so it's important to handle them carefully.

en.question: To figure out how much alcohol is in someone's blood (BAC), you need to know:

options.A: Their height.
options.B: Their weight.
options.C: The time of day they drink alcohol.

en.description: An individual's body weight plays a central role in determining how alcohol disperses throughout the body. Essentially, a lighter person will have a higher concentration of alcohol in their bloodstream after consuming the same amount as someone heavier.

en.question: What is the right way to hold a steering wheel?

options.A: With both hands, on opposite sides of the wheel.
options.B: With one hand on the top of the wheel and the other on your lap.
options.C: With your knees, while using your hands to adjust the radio.

en.description: The correct way to hold a steering wheel is with both hands placed on opposite sides of the wheel. This gives you the most control over the vehicle, making it safer to drive.

en.question: What statement about the use of drugs is correct?

options.A: Taking drugs is safe if driving short distances.
options.B: Use of drugs can lead to an accident and/or arrest.
options.C: Drugs have no effect on driving skills.

en.description: Using drugs can make driving unsafe and might get you into an accident or even get you arrested.

en.question: Specify the conditions under which a driver without a hazardous materials endorsement is allowed to drive a vehicle carrying hazardous substances.

options.A: The hazardous materials are contained in a tool box.
options.B: The vehicle does not require placards.
options.C: The hazardous materials are in a sealed, unbreakable container.

en.description: If the hazardous materials being transported do not require placarding under federal and state regulations, a driver without a HazMat endorsement may operate the vehicle.

en.question: What would be your total stopping distance at 55 mph on dry pavement?

options.A: The width of a standard car lane
options.B: Three times the height of a basketball hoop.
options.C: The length of a football field.

en.description: If you're driving at 55 mph on a dry road and need to stop, you'll need as much space as a football field to do so safely.

en.question: What should you do if you see a hazard on the road ahead?

options.A: Use your four-way flashers or brake lights to warn others.
options.B: Drive closely to the vehicle ahead to use it as a shield.
options.C: Turn on your high beam headlights to signal danger.

en.description: When you see something dangerous on the road ahead, the best thing to do is turn on your emergency lights or tap your brakes to alert other drivers. Never get too close to the car in front as a shield, and don't just turn on your bright lights. This way, everyone can stay safe.

en.question: What is the safest method to merge onto the road?

options.A: Use your horn to alert others before merging.
options.B: Wait for a large enough gap in the traffic to enter the road.
options.C: Drive in reverse before merging.

en.description: Merging onto a road safely means finding a big enough space in traffic so you can join in without causing problems. This way, cars have room to adjust and you can blend in smoothly.

en.question: What statement about loading cargo is correct?

options.A: Cargo does not need to be secured if it's under 100 pounds.
options.B: Cargo must be inspected every 100 miles.
options.C: A state law dictates legal weight limit.

en.description: The weight limit is determined by the state in which you are operating.

en.question: What is the appropriate action if the drive wheels begin to spin when you start moving from a stationary position?

options.A: Turn off the engine.
options.B: Increase the engine's speed.
options.C: Take your foot off the accelerator.

en.description: If your wheels are tugging when you start driving, simply take your foot off the accelerator pedal.

en.question: What should you do when a heavy load slows you down while ascending an incline?

options.A: Increase your speed significantly.
options.B: Turn on your hazard lights and stop.
options.C: Shift to lower gear.

en.description: If your truck is carrying a heavy load and it's making you slow down while going uphill, you should switch to a lower gear. This helps your truck gain more power to move up the hill easier.

en.question: How should you arrange reflective triangles when parking on the roadside of a straight, level, four-lane divided highway?

options.A: One within 10 feet of the front of the vehicle, one about 50 feet to the rear, and one about 250 feet to the rear.
options.B: One within 5 feet of the rear of the vehicle, one about 50 feet to the rear, and one about 150 feet to the front.
options.C: One within 10 feet of the rear of the vehicle, one about 100 feet to the rear, and one about 200 feet to the rear.

en.description: When parking on a straight, level, four-lane divided highway, place one within 10 feet of the rear of the vehicle, one about 100 feet to the rear, and one about 200 feet behind your vehicle for safety.

en.question: Which of the following statements regarding the pre-trip inspection of your wheels and rims is true?

options.A: Wheels do not need to be inspected if they appear clean.
options.B: Rust around wheel nuts may mean that they are loose.
options.C: Cracks in the wheel rims are safe as long as the wheel turns.

en.description: Rust around the wheel nuts can be a sign that they are not tight enough. Always check this before a trip.

en.question: Identify the correct practice regarding engine overheating.

options.A: You should never remove the radiator cap on a pressurized system until the system is cooled.
options.B: You can continue driving as long as the temperature gauge is in the red zone.
options.C: Driving with a low coolant level won't cause overheating.

en.description: If your engine is too hot, don't take off the radiator cap if the engine hasn't cooled down. Driving when the temp gauge is in the red or with not enough coolant can make things worse.

en.question: Select the statement that is false regarding the procedure for reversing a heavy vehicle.

options.A: Because you can't see clearly through your mirrors, you should reverse slowly to make the process more safe.
options.B: Because you cannot see, you should back slowly until you slightly bump into the dock.
options.C: Rely on your side mirrors, rearview camera, and engage a helper when reversing if possible.

en.description: When maneuvering a heavy vehicle, every movement must be precise and controlled. Relying on a slight bump as a guide introduces risks of misjudging distance, causing damage to both the vehicle and the dock.

en.question: When driving a large vehicle that moves slower than other traffic, which guideline should you AVOID following?

options.A: Focus on maintaining a steady speed.
options.B: Signal other drivers when it is safe to pass you.
options.C: Stay in the right lane whenever possible.

en.description: You should avoid signaling other drivers when it is safe to pass because it is their responsibility to judge the road conditions and determine when passing is safe. Instead of signaling, focus on maintaining a steady speed, staying in the right lane when possible, and allowing other drivers to make their own safe decisions about passing.

en.question: What is true regarding taking emergency or evasive maneuvers?

options.A: In order to turn quickly you must have a firm grip on the steering wheel.
options.B: Always use the brakes hard to maintain control.
options.C: Speeding up is safer than stopping in emergencies.

en.description: When you need to turn quickly in an emergency, make sure you're holding the steering wheel tightly to control the vehicle properly.

en.question: When driving at the usual speed on a highway, you should try to look ahead of your car for about __ miles.
en.description: When driving fast on a big road, you should try to look ahead for about 1/4 mile. This helps you see what's coming and keep safe.

en.question: Which brake system should be checked when the vehicle is stationary?

options.A: Service brake.
options.B: Parking brake.
options.C: Hydraulic brakes.

en.description: When your vehicle is not moving, check if the steering wheel is firm and doesn't move too much. Also, test the hydraulic brakes to ensure they are working properly.

en.question: Identify the accurate statement regarding the operation and effect of brakes.

options.A: Brakes require less force to stop a vehicle as it speeds up.
options.B: Brakes work best when they are wet or icy.
options.C: The heavier a vehicle or the faster it is moving, the more heat the brakes must absorb to stop it.

en.description: When a vehicle is heavier or moving fast, its brakes need to soak up more heat to make it stop.

en.question: What is accurate about the impact of hot weather on tires during driving?

options.A: You should inspect your tires every two hours or every 100 miles when driving in very hot weather.
options.B: Driving slowly will prevent tires from heating up in hot weather.
options.C: Using winter tires will improve traction in hot weather.

en.description: When it's really hot, check your tires every 2 hours or 100 miles to make sure they're okay. Driving slow or using winter tires won't help in the heat.

en.question: After turning on the engine:

options.A: The battery charge indicator will fully charge in 3-5 minutes.
options.B: The air pressure gauge will immediately show full pressure.
options.C: The coolant temperature gauge should begin a gradual rise to normal.

en.description: After you start your truck's engine, watch the coolant temperature gauge. It should slowly start to go up until it reaches the normal range. This shows your engine is warming up properly.

en.question: Which action should you AVOID when aiding injured individuals at the site of an accident?

options.A: Keep injured persons cool.
options.B: If a qualified person is helping them, stay out of the way unless asked to assist.
options.C: Move severely injured person if there is a danger due to fire or passing traffic.

en.description: It is important to keep injured individuals warm to prevent shock. Cooling them down could worsen their condition, especially if they are in shock or suffering from blood loss.

en.question: Identify the correct statement from the following.

options.A: Most vehicles use less fuel at night than during the day.
options.B: Most roads are less crowded at night, reducing the risk of accidents.
options.C: Many heavy vehicle accidents occur between midnight and 6 a.m.

en.description: Most big vehicle crashes happen between midnight and 6 a.m. This is because it's harder to see, and drivers might be tired. So, driving big vehicles at night can be more dangerous, not just because of less traffic or using less fuel.

en.question: How far ahead should a driver be looking while operating the vehicle?

options.A: 10-13 seconds
options.B: 3-5 seconds
options.C: 12-15 seconds

en.description: When driving, it's best to look 12-15 seconds ahead on the road. This means if you're going faster, you'll look further ahead. For example, in the city, this could be about one block ahead. Looking far ahead helps you see problems early, so you have more time to react and keep safe.

en.question: What is a safety measure to follow when setting up reflective triangles?

options.A: Hold the triangles between yourself and oncoming traffic.
options.B: Wear dark clothing to make sure you don't distract drivers.
options.C: Place them all in a straight line regardless of road shape.

en.description: When setting up safety triangles, keep them between you and the cars coming your way. This helps cars see you and the triangles better, keeping you safe.

en.question: What statement regarding the behavior of other drivers on the road is true?

options.A: Drivers in small cars understand the blind spots of large trucks and always stay clear.
options.B: Short term or daily rental truck drivers are often not used to the limited vision, which makes these drivers a hazard.
options.C: All drivers are equally aware of the blind spots of large vehicles.

en.description: Many people driving rented trucks for just a day or a short time aren't used to the poor visibility these big vehicles have. This can make them risky on the road.

en.question: What statement is accurate concerning drug consumption and driving?

options.A: Prescription drugs are allowed if a doctor says they will not affect the driving ability.
options.B: Medications bought over-the-counter are always safe for driving.
options.C: Taking medication as long as it is not during working hours is allowed.

en.description: If a doctor says your prescription medicine won't affect your driving, it's okay to use it. But, just because you can buy medicine without a prescription doesn't mean it's safe to drive after taking it. Taking medicine is okay if it doesn't affect your driving, no matter the time.

en.question: Under which circumstance is it advisable to gently tap your brakes to activate the brake lights?

options.A: You are about to exit the road and need to slow down.
options.B: You need to quickly change lanes.
options.C: You're driving in heavy fog.

en.description: When you're about to leave the road and need to slow down, gently press your brakes to make your brake lights blink. This will alert drivers behind you that you're slowing down.

en.question: How should you respond if your vehicle begins to hydroplane?

options.A: Release accelerator.
options.B: Turn the steering wheel quickly.
options.C: Turn on your headlights.

en.description: When your vehicle slides on water, ease off the gas pedal slowly. Don't turn the steering wheel fast or turn on your lights. This will help you regain control.

en.question: Identify the accurate statement concerning overhead clearance.

options.A: Always add an extra foot to the clearance measurement for safety.
options.B: The weight of a vehicle changes height.
options.C: Overhead clearance is not affected by weather conditions.

en.description: The weight of your vehicle can make it taller or shorter, changing how much room you need to clear things above. Always add a bit more space above your vehicle to be safe.

en.question: At what blood alcohol concentration (BAC) level will you be subject to a 24-hour out-of-service order?

options.A: Any detectable amount.

en.description: If you have any alcohol in your body that can be measured, you won't be allowed to drive for a day.

en.question: What is accurate regarding a skid caused by the rear drive wheels locking?

options.A: On a vehicle with a trailer, the trailer can push the towing vehicle sideways.
options.B: Applying more brake pressure will stop the skid.
options.C: Turning the steering wheel sharply increases control.

en.description: When the back wheels of a vehicle with a trailer skid, the trailer can push the vehicle to the side, making it slide sideways.

en.question: Identify the true statement related to accelerating a vehicle.

options.A: Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.
options.B: Gradual acceleration increases fuel consumption.
options.C: Acceleration increases fuel efficiency at all times.

en.description: Roughly speeding up your vehicle can break parts of it.

en.question: Backing of the commercial vehicle is

options.A: Safe as long as you go fast.
options.B: If you don't use rear-view mirrors, it's not difficult.
options.C: Always dangerous.

en.description: Backing up a big truck is always dangerous. You should avoid doing it as much as you can. If you must back up, make sure to check everything carefully and go slow.

en.question: Why is it dangerous if the exhaust system is damaged?

options.A: Increases fuel consumption significantly.
options.B: Poisonous fumes can enter the cab or sleeping compartment.
options.C: Can cause the tires to deflate.

en.description: If your truck's exhaust system is damaged, harmful gases can get inside where you sit or sleep, which is very dangerous for your health.

en.question: What is accurate regarding the procedure for notifying authorities after an accident?

options.A: You must only report accidents that occur on highways.
options.B: If you have a cellular phone or CB radio you should notify the authorities before exiting the vehicle.
options.C: You can wait until the end of the day to report the accident.

en.description: If you're in an accident, use your phone or CB radio right away to tell the cops before you get out of your vehicle. Don't wait till later or think it's only needed for highway crashes. Quick action is important.

en.question: You must come to a complete stop at a railroad crossing when:

options.A: The nature of the cargo makes a stop mandatory under the State or Federal regulations.
options.B: The crossing is on a single-lane road with limited visibility.
options.C: There is no flagman, warning signals or gate at the crossing.

en.description: You must stop at a railroad crossing if your truck is carrying something that rules say you must stop for, or if the crossing is on a narrow road where you can't see well.

en.question: How should you handle slippery road conditions?

options.A: Make turns as gently as possible.
options.B: Increase your speed to pass other vehicles quickly.
options.C: Drive with your hazard lights on at all times.

en.description: When roads are slippery, it's safest to turn very slowly and gently. This helps prevent the truck from sliding or losing control. Quick turns can be dangerous because the truck might not grip the road well.

en.question: What are the possible outcomes of applying wet brakes after driving through heavy rain?

options.A: Overheating of engine
options.B: Increased fuel consumption
options.C: Trailer jack-knife

en.description: If your truck's brakes get wet from a lot of rain, they might not work right. When you try to stop, the truck could slide out of control, like when the back part swings out. It's like trying to skate on ice; very slippery and hard to steer.

en.question: What potential issues could arise from having too little weight on the drive axle of a vehicle?

options.A: Poor traction
options.B: Increased fuel efficiency
options.C: More likely to tip over during turns

en.description: If a vehicle doesn't have enough weight on the drive axle, it won't grip the road well, leading to poor traction. This means the tires might slip more, especially in bad weather, making it harder to control the vehicle.

en.question: Which of the following statements about the pre-trip inspection of your brakes and suspension system is true?

options.A: Air pressure in the brake lines doesn't need to be consistent.
options.B: Brake pads are fine as long as they are not completely worn down.
options.C: Brake shoes should not have oil, grease, or brake fluid on them.

en.description: When you check your truck before a trip, make sure the brake parts aren't oily or greasy. This keeps your brakes working right.

en.question: You are driving a heavy vehicle and approaching an off-ramp that curves downhill. What is the safest way to exit the highway?

options.A: Slow down to a safe speed before the curve.
options.B: Increase your speed to match highway traffic.
options.C: Maintain your speed until you reach the bottom of the off-ramp.

en.description: When exiting a highway with a heavy vehicle using a downhill off-ramp that curves, slow down to a safe speed before you start the curve. This helps you control the vehicle better and stay safe.

en.question: What should drivers know about the effect of poor weather on road conditions?

options.A: When the temperature drops, the bridges freeze before the road.
options.B: The sun can dry wet roads faster at night than during the day.
options.C: The wind has no effect on how quickly roads dry.

en.description: When it's cold, bridges get icy before roads do. The sun helps dry wet roads faster during the day, not at night. Wind doesn't change how fast roads dry.

en.question: While driving at 50 mph on a straight, level highway with no vehicles ahead, your tire suddenly blows out. What is the initial action you should take?

options.A: Stay off the brake until the vehicle has slowed down.
options.B: Turn the steering wheel sharply to the left.
options.C: Turn on your hazard lights and stop immediately.

en.description: If your tire blows out while driving at 50 mph, first thing: don't hit the brakes right away. Let the car slow down on its own first.

en.question: What is the term used to describe how commercial vehicles tend to swing wide on turns?

options.A: Curve dragging
options.B: Turning stretch
options.C: Off-tracking

en.description: When a big truck turns, the back wheels don't follow the same path as the front wheels, causing the truck to swing wide. This is called off-tracking.

en.question: Which of the following is accurate concerning vehicle operation at low temperatures?

options.A: Tire pressure does not need to be checked in cold weather.
options.B: Windshield washer antifreeze should be used.
options.C: Brakes work better on icy roads.

en.description: When it's cold, using antifreeze in your windshield washer helps keep the liquid from freezing so you can clean your windshield.

en.question: What principle should be understood about speed management and its impact on stopping distances?

options.A: Speed does not affect stopping distance.
options.B: If you double your speed, stopping distance will be increased by 4 times.
options.C: Stopping distance decreases as your speed increases.

en.description: When you drive faster, it takes much longer to stop. If you go twice as fast, it takes four times the distance to stop your vehicle.

en.question: Which statement is accurate regarding the challenges of driving in strong wind conditions?

options.A: Keep your windows open to reduce wind resistance.
options.B: Turn off your headlights to improve visibility.
options.C: Winds are especially a problem when coming out of tunnels.

en.description: When driving out of tunnels, be careful because the wind can suddenly hit your vehicle hard. This makes controlling your vehicle more challenging.

en.question: Which item is typically not checked within the engine compartment during pre-trip inspections?

options.A: Engine oil level.
options.B: Worn electrical wiring insulation.
options.C: Valve clearance.

en.description: Before a trip, you don't check the color of the brake fluid in the engine area. You also don't look at the tire pressure gauge or measure the gap between valves there. These checks are not part of the engine compartment inspection.

en.question: Which tool would be INEFFECTIVE in removing ice from a windshield?

options.A: Windshield scraper.
options.B: Windshield defroster.
options.C: Dust brush.

en.description: Using a dust brush won't help clear ice from a windshield. It's too soft to scrape off ice effectively. You need something stronger like an ice scraper for this job.

en.question: What should you do when encountering glare ice, making the roadway exceptionally slippery?

options.A: Stop driving as soon as you can safely do so.
options.B: Turn on your high beams to melt the ice.
options.C: Drive in the middle of the road to avoid icy patches.

en.description: When the road is very slippery because of ice, the best thing to do is to stop driving as soon as it's safe. This helps avoid accidents because the ice makes it hard to control your vehicle.

en.question: You are behind the wheel of a vehicle that can comfortably reach 55 mph on an open stretch of road. Currently, you are navigating through heavy traffic where the flow is steady at 35 mph, even though the posted speed limit is 55 mph. What speed should you maintain to ensure safety?

options.A: 50 mph
options.B: 60 mph
options.C: 35 mph

en.description: Drive at the same speed as the other cars, 35 mph, to avoid crashes. Going faster can cause accidents since traffic is moving slower.

en.question: What should be understood about the operation of the heating system in a vehicle?

options.A: When driving in winter weather, you should check that the heater is working properly before starting your trip.
options.B: Turning on the heater can reduce engine performance.
options.C: Heaters are only needed for vehicles driving in snow.

en.description: Before you go on a trip in cold weather, make sure your car's heater works well. This helps you stay warm and keeps the windshield clear.

en.question: When should you check if your parking brakes work?

options.A: During a sharp turn
options.B: When you're on a steep hill.
options.C: While the vehicle is parked.

en.description: You should check your parking brakes when your vehicle is parked, not moving. This makes sure they work right and can hold your vehicle safely when you're not driving it.

en.question: Which precaution should you take before driving in mountains?

options.A: Know escape ramp locations on your way.
options.B: Decrease your vehicle's weight by removing unnecessary items.
options.C: Fill your fuel tank only halfway to reduce weight.

en.description: Before driving in mountains, learn where escape ramps are in case you need them.

en.question: What does implied consent mean?

options.A: You agree to let officers search your home for alcohol.
options.B: You are giving your consent to be tested for alcohol in your blood.
options.C: You automatically agree to follow all traffic signals while driving.

en.description: Implied consent means you've agreed to let police test you for alcohol in your blood if they think you've been drinking and driving.

en.question: Brake fade:

options.A: Is a sign that the brake fluid needs to be changed immediately.
options.B: Is completely normal and requires no action.
options.C: Can be caused by the brakes getting very hot.

en.description: Brake fade happens when your brakes get too hot from use, making them not work as well. This can happen if you use them a lot in a short time, like when going down a long, steep hill. It's important to know this so you can avoid it and keep your brakes working right.

en.question: You should NOT ___ if your headlights are not working properly.

options.A: Adjust.
options.B: Clean your headlights.
options.C: Leave on your high beams.

en.description: If your car's headlights aren't working right, don't keep your high beams on. This can blind other drivers and is unsafe.

en.question: What happens when the amount of alcohol in the blood goes up?

options.A: The drinker's ability to perform tasks improves.
options.B: Judgment and self-control are affected.
options.C: The effects of alcohol decrease.

en.description: As the amount of alcohol in the blood goes up, it becomes harder for a person to think clearly and control what they do. Also, they react slower to things happening around them.

en.question: When checking hydraulic brakes, you should pump the brake pedal three times and then apply firm pressure for five seconds. A brake pedal that works right should:

options.A: Feel spongy
options.B: Not move.
options.C: Become harder to press

en.description: When you check hydraulic brakes by pressing the brake pedal three times and then holding it down firmly for five seconds, the brake pedal should not move at all. If the pedal stays in place and doesn't go down, it means the brakes are working correctly.

en.question: What action should you take if you need to leave the road in a traffic emergency?

options.A: Drive in reverse to slow down.
options.B: Turn on your hazard lights and wait for help.
options.C: Avoid braking until your speed has dropped to about 20 mph.

en.description: If you must leave the road in an emergency, avoid using the brakes until you slow down to 20 mph. This helps you control your vehicle and prevent accidents.

en.question: What do retarders do?

options.A: Increase fuel efficiency.
options.B: Help slow the vehicle while driving and reduce brake wear.
options.C: Make the engine run smoother.

en.description: Retarders help slow down the vehicle when you're driving. This means you don't have to use the brakes as much, which makes them last longer.

en.question: To keep yourself awake and focused when driving, you should _

options.A: Take periodic breaks.
options.B: Drink lots of coffee
options.C: Listen to extremely loud music.

en.description: To keep awake while driving for a long time, it's best to take short breaks now and then. This means stopping your drive occasionally to stretch, walk around, or just take a breather. This helps your body and mind stay fresh. Drinking lots of coffee or blasting loud music might seem helpful but isn't as effective or safe as taking breaks.

en.question: If you don't have a CB radio, what should you do if there's an accident?

options.A: Protect the area.
options.B: Leave the scene immediately.
options.C: Take a nap until help arrives.

en.description: If you're in an accident and don't have a CB radio, make sure to keep the area safe. This means doing things like setting up warning signs or cones if you have them, to prevent further accidents. Leaving or sleeping is not the right thing to do.

en.question: Which factor does NOT influence your choice of gear when driving in mountainous areas?

options.A: The length of the grade.
options.B: The weight of the load.
options.C: Tire thread's depth.

en.description: When driving in mountainous areas, the choice of gear is influenced by factors like how steep the road is (the length of the grade) and how heavy your vehicle is (the weight of the load). However, the depth of the tire tread does not affect which gear you should use.

en.question: Which of the following is NOT damaged by rough acceleration?

options.A: Coupling.
options.B: Mechanical damage.
options.C: Tire damage.

en.description: When you accelerate roughly, it can harm parts of your car. It can damage the coupling and cause mechanical damage. However, tire damage is not one of these issues because rough acceleration affects the engine and connecting parts more than the tires.

en.question: What should you remember when crossing or entering traffic with a heavy vehicle?

options.A: Heavy vehicles need larger gaps in traffic than cars.
options.B: It's okay to quickly switch multiple lanes if there's enough space at the moment.
options.C: You should speed up when merging to make other vehicles keep their distance.

en.description: When you're driving a big truck or bus and want to join or cross the road, remember big vehicles need more room than cars. So, look for a bigger open space in traffic to move in safely.

en.question: What should you do if you are being tailgated?

options.A: Speed up to put distance between you and the tailgater.
options.B: Increase your following distance.
options.C: Turn on your hazard lights to warn the tailgater.

en.description: If someone is driving too close behind you, don't speed up. Instead, make more space between you and the car in front. This way, if you need to stop suddenly, you have more time to do so safely, and it could also encourage the person behind you to back off.

en.question: What does countersteering involve?

options.A: Pushing the pedal harder to brake quickly
options.B: Applying more gas to increase speed.
options.C: Turning the wheel back in the other direction after steering to avoid a traffic emergency.

en.description: Countersteering is when you quickly turn the steering wheel in the opposite direction after steering to dodge something on the road, helping you to straighten the vehicle and avoid losing control.

en.question: What is the recommended practice during a long, steep downgrade?

options.A: Use the braking effect of the engine.
options.B: Shift to a higher gear to increase speed.
options.C: Turn off your engine to save fuel.

en.description: When you're going down a big hill, it's smart to use your engine to help slow you down. This means you let the engine's natural power control your speed without using the brakes too much.

en.question: What helps keep a car engine from getting too hot when driving in warm weather?

options.A: Keeping the air conditioning on high.
options.B: Driving at a higher speed to increase airflow.
options.C: Enough engine oil level.

en.description: Enough engine oil is key because it lubricates the engine parts, reducing friction and helping the engine stay cool.

en.question: Medicine used to treat the common cold:

options.A: Often makes you sleepy and should not be used while driving.
options.B: Can improve driving focus if taken in small amounts.
options.C: Increases alertness and reaction times when taken before driving.

en.description: Cold medicine can make you feel sleepy, so it's not safe to take when you're going to drive.

en.question: Your tire tread should _ when driving in cold weather.

options.A: Be double the depth required in normal weather.
options.B: Provide enough traction to push the rig over wet pavement and through snow.
options.C: Be rotated every 50 miles to ensure even wear.

en.description: When driving in cold weather, make sure your tires have good grip for moving over wet roads and through snow. This helps keep you safe and moving.

en.question: What practice is advised for safely driving at night?

options.A: Drive close to the vehicle ahead to use their lights for better visibility.
options.B: Keep your speed slow enough that you can stop within the range of your headlights.
options.C: Adjust your mirrors frequently to catch the headlights from cars behind you.

en.description: When driving at night, go slow so you can stop within the distance your headlights shine. This way, you won't run into something because you'll see it in time.

en.question: What should you do if you are unsure of the correct extinguishing agent for a hazardous material fire?

options.A: Throw sand
options.B: Pour soda
options.C: Wait for fire fighters.

en.description: If you're not sure how to put out a fire caused by dangerous materials, it's best to wait for the firefighters to arrive. They are trained to handle such situations safely.

en.question: What is correct regarding the use of turn signals?

options.A: When turning, you should signal early.
options.B: Turn signals are optional during daylight hours.
options.C: You do not need to use your turn signal when changing lanes in traffic on a four-lane highway.

en.description: When you plan to turn, it's important to use your turn signals early. This lets other drivers know what you're going to do ahead of time, so everyone stays safe on the road.

en.question: What does controlled braking involve?

options.A: Squeezing the brakes firmly without locking the wheels.
options.B: Tapping the brakes lightly and frequently.
options.C: Dragging your foot along the ground to slow the vehicle.

en.description: Controlled braking involves applying the brakes as hard as you can without locking the wheels. If the wheels lock up, release the brakes and reapply them immediately.

en.question: What should you do to avoid brake fade?

options.A: Pump the brakes repeatedly when going downhill
options.B: Shift to a lower gear only after your speed has already increased.
options.C: Select the gear, which will keep your vehicle to a safe speed on a deep downgrade.

en.description: To avoid your brakes from getting too tired and not working well, especially when going downhill, choose a lower gear before you start going down. This helps control your speed without using the brakes too much.

en.question: Among these, which vehicle type would require the greatest distance to come to a complete stop?

options.A: Bobtail truck.
options.B: Empty truck.
options.C: Loaded truck.

en.description: A truck carrying a heavy load has a lot more mass, which means it builds up greater momentum when moving. This extra momentum requires more time and distance for the brakes to slow down the vehicle to a complete stop safely.

en.question: What is the minimum tread depth required for front steering wheel tires?

options.A: Less than 1/32 inch
options.B: At least 5/32 inch
options.C: Not less than 4/32 inch.

en.description: The rubber part on the front tires of big trucks needs to be thick enough so the truck can be driven safely. The thickness should be at least 4/32 of an inch.

en.question: What are the consequences for a driver stopped at a roadside rest area with a BAC of 0.02?

options.A: You will have to attend a mandatory driving course.
options.B: You will be placed out of service for 24 hours.
options.C: You will be fined $500.

en.description: If a truck driver is stopped and tests show a tiny bit of alcohol in their system (0.02 BAC), they can't drive for a day.

en.question: The center of gravity of a load:

options.A: Can make a vehicle more likely to tip over on curves if it is high.
options.B: Does not affect the handling of the vehicle.
options.C: Can be ignored when driving at low speeds.

en.description: The spot where all the weight of a load feels like it's centered can cause a truck to tip over more easily on curves if it's placed high up. Even at slow speeds, you can't ignore where this spot is.

en.question: What is accurate regarding the adjustment of mirrors on a vehicle?

options.A: You should only adjust the side mirrors, not the rearview mirror.
options.B: You should adjust your mirrors before starting the trip.
options.C: You can use mirrors to see clearly in heavy fog.

en.description: Before you start driving, make sure to adjust your mirrors. This helps you see around your vehicle better.

en.question: How soon should you set out your emergency triangles after parking on the shoulder due to a road emergency?

options.A: Within 30 minutes.
options.B: Within 5 minutes.
options.C: Within 10 minutes.

en.description: If you have to stop your truck on the side of the road because of an emergency, you should put out your warning triangles within 10 minutes. This helps other drivers see your truck and avoid hitting it.

en.question: Cracks in brake drums (or discs) must not be wider than___of the friction surface's width.
en.description: Cracks in the brake drums or discs should not be bigger than half the width of the friction surface. If they are, it’s not safe to drive.

en.question: Which statement is INCORRECT regarding the inspection of brakes and suspension systems during a pre-trip check?

options.A: Air pressure in tires does not affect braking.
options.B: Brake shoes should have brake fluid on them.
options.C: Suspension systems do not require inspection.

en.description: Brake fluid on brake shoes is incorrect and unsafe, as it can interfere with braking. Brake components must be clean and dry.

en.question: What is an important aspect to check using your vehicle's mirror?

options.A: If there are any cracks in your windshield
options.B: If your tires are properly inflated.
options.C: Where the rear of your vehicle is while you make turns.

en.description: When you are making turns, it’s important to use your mirrors to check where the back of your vehicle is. This helps avoid collisions.

en.question: Controlled braking:

options.A: Helps increase fuel efficiency.
options.B: Is used to keep a vehicle in a straight line when braking.
options.C: Allows you to drive faster in wet conditions.

en.description: Controlled braking helps keep the vehicle moving straight and safely during braking, especially in emergencies.

en.question: What is the advised method for starting a heavy vehicle with a manual transmission on an incline from a stopped position?

options.A: Accelerate quickly to prevent rolling back.
options.B: Engage a higher gear than normal before starting up the incline.
options.C: Use the parking brake to hold the vehicle until the clutch engages.

en.description: When restarting on a hill, use the parking brake to prevent rolling back. Release it as the clutch engages to move forward smoothly.

en.question: What indication might suggest a tire failure has occurred?

options.A: The wheels are painted.
options.B: Vibration.
options.C: Radio interference.

en.description: Vibration while driving can be a sign of tire failure. It may mean a problem with the tire’s structure or inflation.

en.question: What is correct regarding the use of radiator shutters and the winter front during cold weather driving?

options.A: Radiator fans should be turned off to save energy.
options.B: Ice should be removed from the radiator shutter.
options.C: Using antifreeze is unnecessary with a winter front.

en.description: In cold weather, remove ice from the radiator shutter to allow proper airflow and engine temperature regulation.

en.question: When descending a long, steep grade in a truck with a manual transmission, which gear should you select?

options.A: A lower gear than you would use to climb the hill.
options.B: Neutral gear
options.C: The gear you use on flat terrain.

en.description: On a steep descent, use a lower gear than you would for climbing. This helps control speed using engine braking instead of relying solely on brakes.

en.question: What is crucial to remember about performing emergency braking?

options.A: Slowing down gradually will always stop the vehicle faster.
options.B: If the wheels are skidding, you cannot control your vehicle.
options.C: Pushing the accelerator will help regain control faster.

en.description: When you have to brake in an emergency, remember that if your wheels are skidding, you can't steer the truck. So, keeping the wheels rolling without skidding is key to controlling your vehicle.

en.question: Which of these statements regarding the technique of downshifting is correct?

options.A: Downshift only when the vehicle is moving at its top speed.
options.B: When you downshift for a curve, you should do so before you enter the curve.
options.C: Downshift without using the clutch at all times.

en.description: When you need to slow down for a curve, shift to a lower gear before you actually start turning. This helps you control the vehicle better.

en.question: Which of these statements regarding the process of backing up a heavy vehicle is true?

options.A: You should avoid backing whenever you can.
options.B: Use your mirrors to guide you while backing up, ignoring the outside surroundings.
options.C: Backing up can be done quickly to save time.

en.description: When driving a big truck, try not to back up if you can help it. It's safer that way.

en.question: How many red reflective triangles must you have with you?
en.description: You need to have 3 red reflective triangles in your truck. They are used to warn other drivers when you have to stop on the side of the road.

en.question: Why should you turn on your turn signals before making a turn?

options.A: It helps other drivers know that you have completed your turn.
options.B: It keeps your turn signals from turning off too early.
options.C: You need both hands on the wheel to turn safely.

en.description: Turn signals should be activated in advance to free up your hands and allow you to keep both hands on the wheel for a safe turn.

en.question: How should you manage your speed when using a curved highway ramp for exiting or entering a highway?

options.A: Slow down to at least 50% of the posted speed limit.
options.B: Maintain a speed 5-10 mph under the posted speed limit.
options.C: Brake sharply to reduce speed by 20 mph below the limit.

en.description: When using a curved ramp to get on or off a highway, keep your speed 5-10 mph lower than the posted limit. This helps you stay safe while merging.

en.question: When you _, you should ensure that your emergency four-way flashers are turned on.

options.A: Drive in heavy rain.
options.B: Stop at a green light.
options.C: Park on the side of the road.

en.description: When you park on the side of the road, turn on your emergency four-way flashers to alert other drivers to your position.

en.question: What correct action should be taken in the event of a vehicle fire?

options.A: A burning tire should be cooled with water.
options.B: Use sand to put out an engine fire.
options.C: Throw flour on the fire to put it out.

en.description: If your tire catches fire, pour water on it to cool it down and help put the fire out.

en.question: Which set of lights is impossible to inspect simultaneously?

options.A: Turn signals, brake lights, and four-way flashers.
options.B: Turn signals, tail lights, and clearance lights.
options.C: Brake lights, headlight high beams, and parking lights.

en.description: Turn signals, brake lights, and four-way flashers can't be inspected at the same time because they share components and interfere with each other.

en.question: What is not essential for drivers to know when seeking a hazardous materials endorsement?

options.A: Basic chemistry.
options.B: Which products can be loaded together.
options.C: When to use the placards.

en.description: Basic chemistry is not essential. Drivers need to follow safety regulations and procedures, not analyze chemical compositions.

en.question: What changes occur to the tar on road surfaces during hot weather?

options.A: It bleeds making the road surface slippery.
options.B: It hardens, increasing tire grip.
options.C: It evaporates, leaving gaps in the road.

en.description: When it gets really hot, the tar on roads gets soft and sticky. This makes the road slippery, kind of like when there's water on it, so it's harder for cars to stay steady and safe.

en.question: What is not necessary for starting a bus on a level surface with good traction?

options.A: Slow acceleration.
options.B: A tire check.
options.C: Parking brakes.

en.description: You don't need to use the parking brakes to start a bus on a flat surface where the wheels won't slip.

en.question: A hazard:

options.A: Can be safely ignored.
options.B: Is any road condition or other road user that is possible danger.
options.C: Is always a vehicle malfunction.

en.description: A hazard is anything on the road or anyone using the road that could be dangerous.

en.question: If a straight vehicle without a trailer experiences a front-wheel skid, it will _

options.A: Stop immediately.
options.B: Turn in the opposite direction of the steering wheel.
options.C: Go straight ahead even if the steering wheel is turned.

en.description: When a straight vehicle's front wheels lose grip and slide, it won't stop right away or turn the other way. Instead, it will keep moving straight, no matter which way the steering wheel is turned.

en.question: What potential issues could arise from loading cargo primarily at the rear of a trailer?

options.A: Increased fuel consumption
options.B: Poor traction on drive wheels.
options.C: Improved braking performance

en.description: When loading stuff onto a truck, make sure everything is evenly spread out in the cargo area. This helps keep the truck steady and safe on the road.

en.question: What should be kept in mind when you must drive off the road to avoid a hazard or emergency?

options.A: It is less dangerous to drive onto the shoulders than to cause a collision.
options.B: You should only leave the road at high speeds to avoid accidents.
options.C: You can easily control your vehicle on any shoulder surface.

en.description: When you need to avoid danger and have to leave the road, remember it's safer to go onto the side of the road than to crash. Do not think you can control your car easily on every roadside surface.

en.question: Which of the following is not recognized as a type of retarder?

options.A: Hydraulic
options.B: Robotic
options.C: Electric

en.description: Robotic is not a type of retarder. Retarders help slow down vehicles. Types include magnetic, which uses magnets, and pneumatic, which uses air pressure. Robotic isn't related to this system.

en.question: Retarders:

options.A: Reduce the overall speed of your vehicle automatically.
options.B: Increase fuel efficiency significantly.
options.C: Can cause the drive wheels to skid when they have poor traction.

en.description: Retarders help slow down your vehicle without using the brakes. They're great for saving brake wear but use them carefully in bad weather or on slippery roads, as they can make the wheels slide if there's not enough grip.

en.question: What components make up the total stopping distance for trucks and buses?

options.A: Alert distance, processing distance, and stopping distance
options.B: Focus distance, decision distance, and halting distance
options.C: Perception distance, reaction distance, and braking distance.

en.description: The total stopping distance for your truck or bus comes from 3 parts: 1. Perception distance - how far you go while noticing a need to stop. 2. Reaction distance - distance covered as you move to hit the brakes. 3. Braking distance - how far you go until you actually stop.

en.question: What is the initial step you should take if your brakes stop working while descending a slope?

options.A: Flash your lights to signal for help.
options.B: Turn off your engine immediately.
options.C: Look outside your vehicle for another means of slowing you.

en.description: If your truck's brakes stop working while going downhill, quickly look around for another way to slow down your vehicle, like an escape ramp or a less steep road. Don't turn off the engine or just flash your lights; find a safe way to slow down.

en.question: You should position your vehicle for parking so that _

options.A: Park diagonally across multiple spots.
options.B: Park with your back to the main road.
options.C: You can pull forward when you leave.

en.description: When parking, find a spot where you can drive straight out when you leave. This means you won't have to back up, making it safer and easier for you.

en.question: What is the advisable speed for a commercial vehicle when taking freeway exits to ensure safety?

options.A: Below the posted speed limit.
options.B: As fast as the vehicle ahead.
options.C: Twice the posted speed limit.

en.description: When entering freeway exits with a big truck, it's safest to go slower than the speed sign says. This helps avoid accidents since big trucks need more time to slow down and stop.

en.question: To prevent cargo from shifting, you should use at least one tie-down for every _ feet of cargo.
en.description: To keep stuff from moving around while you're driving, you should use a strap or securement for every 10 feet of stuff you're carrying. This helps make sure everything stays in place and safe.

en.question: What guideline must be followed when transporting hazardous materials?

options.A: Containers must be painted green for easy identification.
options.B: Containers should be marked with four-inch diamond-shaped hazard labels.
options.C: Containers can be transported without any labels if they are inside a box.

en.description: When moving dangerous stuff, you must use containers with special diamond-shaped labels that show they're hazardous. This is very important for safety.

en.question: When is it necessary to be secured by a seat belt in a vehicle in motion?

options.A: Only if the vehicle has airbags.
options.B: All the time.
options.C: Only during bad weather.

en.description: You should always wear a seat belt when you're in a moving vehicle, no matter what. It doesn't matter if the vehicle has airbags or what the weather is like.

en.question: According to the driver's manual, which action is NOT advised when passing another vehicle?

options.A: Assume that another driver does not see you.
options.B: At night, turn on your high beams before you start to pass and leave them on until you have completely passed the vehicle.
options.C: Lightly tap your horn.

en.description: You should not turn on your high beams when passing another vehicle at night because it can blind the other driver. Use low beams to avoid causing temporary blindness.

en.question: In what way does a vehicle's load impact its required stopping distance?

options.A: The size of the tires, not the weight, dictates stopping distance.
options.B: The color of the vehicle determines how quickly it can stop.
options.C: Empty trucks take longer to stop than if loaded, but this is not the normal case for buses.

en.description: The heaviness of a truck affects how quickly it can stop. Generally, a loaded truck stops quicker than an empty one because the weight helps with tire grip. This rule doesn't always apply to buses.

en.question: Which of the following is a correct practice about vehicle tires?

options.A: Tires should be inflated to the maximum pressure listed on the sidewall to pass inspection.
options.B: Tread wear indicators are only needed on the front tires.
options.C: Tires of mismatched sizes should not be used together in the same vehicle.

en.description: When checking tires before a trip, don't use tires of different sizes together. It's not safe or allowed.

en.question: What term describes the total weight of the truck, trailer, and cargo together?

options.A: Total vehicle load
options.B: Combined vehicle mass
options.C: Gross combination weight

en.description: The correct term is 'Gross combination weight.' This means the total weight of the truck, the trailer it's pulling, and everything inside both.

en.question: Which indicator is not typically associated with tire failure?

options.A: Vehicle's fishtail.
options.B: Steering wheel twisting.
options.C: Cold steering.

en.description: Cold steering is not usually a sign that something is wrong with your tires.

en.question: What should you NOT check during your walk-around inspection?

options.A: Hydraulic brake cylinders leaks.
options.B: Condition of hoses.
options.C: Brake adjustment.

en.description: During your walk-around inspection, you should not check the brake adjustment. This is because checking the brake adjustment is a more complex task that usually requires specific tools and expertise. It is not something that can be easily or accurately assessed during a basic visual inspection.

en.question: The effectiveness of an engine brake is maximized when the engine is at _ RPM and the vehicle is in a _ gear.

options.A: Below, higher
options.B: Above, lower
options.C: Near, lower

en.description: The engine brake works best when the engine is running at a speed (RPM) that is close to its optimal level and the vehicle is in a lower gear. This combination makes the engine brake more effective, helping the vehicle slow down more efficiently.

en.question: While driving at a slow speed, it's advised to look ahead of your vehicle by approximately ____

options.A: 5 blocks
options.B: 1 block
options.C: 3 blocks

en.description: When you're driving slowly, it's best to look ahead about 1 block. This helps you see what's coming up and react safely.

en.question: Hydroplaning:

options.A: Is completely avoidable by turning the steering wheel rapidly.
options.B: Happens only at low speeds.
options.C: Is more likely if tire pressure is low.

en.description: When your tires glide on water because they can't touch the road, it's more likely if your tires don't have enough air. This doesn't just happen when you're driving slow, and trying to steer quickly won't stop it. Make sure your tires are properly filled to help prevent this.

en.question: If you must drive through deep puddles or flowing water, what action can help keep your brakes functional?

options.A: Increasing your speed before entering the water.
options.B: Gently putting on the brakes while driving through the water.
options.C: Using the air dryer frequently before entering the water.

en.description: When you must drive through deep water, lightly press your brakes while moving through it. This helps keep them working right.

en.question: If you must drive through deep puddles or flowing water, what action can help keep your brakes functional?

options.A: Increasing your speed before entering the water.
options.B: Gently putting on the brakes while driving through the water.
options.C: Using the air dryer frequently before entering the water.

en.description: When you must drive through deep water, lightly press your brakes while moving through it. This helps keep them working right.

en.question: In preparation for winter conditions, which vehicle system requires extra attention during inspection?

options.A: Steering.
options.B: Exhaust.
options.C: Transmission

en.description: Before winter, it's important to check the exhaust system of your vehicle. Cold weather can make small issues in the exhaust system worse, so it's good to make sure everything is working properly to avoid problems when it's really cold outside.

en.question: How should the brake pedal be applied when descending a steep grade?

options.A: Steady, heavy pressure until the bottom.
options.B: Release the brake when you are 5 MPH below your safe speed, then let your speed come back up to your safe speed and repeat again.
options.C: Apply brakes only once halfway down the

en.description: When going downhill, don't press the brake hard all the way. Instead, slow down 5 MPH below your safe speed, then let go of the brake until you reach that speed again. Repeat this to safely control your speed.

en.question: While driving on a level road in a vehicle with hydraulic brakes, you press the brake pedal and it sinks to the floor. Which of the following statements is true?

options.A: Turning off the engine will increase brake pressure.
options.B: Pumping the brake pedal may bring the pressure up so you can stop the vehicle.
options.C: Adding more brake fluid will immediately fix the problem.

en.description: Pumping the brake pedal might help build up enough pressure to stop the vehicle. This can be a temporary fix to slow down or stop when the brake pedal feels too soft.

en.question: After steering onto the shoulder to avoid an accident, how should you return to the road?

options.A: Accelerate quickly to merge with traffic.
options.B: Wait for a tow truck to help return to the road.
options.C: Using mirrors and turn signals, turn sharply to get back to the road

en.description: To safely return to the road after steering onto the shoulder, it's important to use your mirrors and turn signals to check for traffic and communicate your intentions. Turning sharply helps you regain control and align with the road quickly, minimizing the time spent in a potentially dangerous position.

en.question: Which of these statements about the handling of a steering wheel is true?

options.A: Keep your hands at the bottom of the wheel for better control.
options.B: If you do not hold a wheel with both hands it could pull away from you.
options.C: Hold the wheel with one hand at the top for more precision.

en.description: Holding the steering wheel with both hands prevents it from slipping away. This gives you better control of the vehicle.

en.question: Most skids:

options.A: Are due to heavy loads.
options.B: Are caused by going too fast or trying to stop too quickly.
options.C: Only occur during rainstorms.

en.description: Most skids happen because of excessive speed or sudden braking, not necessarily due to heavy loads or weather.

en.question: What is emergency braking?

options.A: Slowing down for a routine stop
options.B: Responding to a hazard by slowing the vehicle.
options.C: Coasting to a stop without using brakes

en.description: Emergency braking is when a driver responds quickly to a sudden hazard by applying the brakes to avoid danger.

en.question: On a road covered with snow, by how much should you reduce your driving speed?
en.description: You should reduce your speed by half on snowy roads to maintain traction and control.

en.question: What should you assume about the actions of a vehicle, pedestrian, or bicycle when you are passing them?

options.A: They will increase their speed.
options.B: They may be moving to your traffic lane.
options.C: They are aware of traffic signals.

en.description: Always assume others might enter your lane when you are passing them to avoid collisions.

en.question: How should you manage your speed when exiting a highway via an off-ramp that curves downhill with a heavy vehicle?

options.A: Slow down to 15 mph below the posted speed limit.
options.B: Slow down to a safe speed before the turn.
options.C: Apply the brakes firmly while in the curve.

en.description: Slow down before the turn when exiting on a curving downhill ramp, especially with a heavy vehicle.

en.question: During the pre-trip inspection, where should you keep the ignition key?

options.A: Hanging from the rearview mirror.
options.B: Attached to the exterior door handle.
options.C: In your pocket.

en.description: Keep the ignition key in your pocket during inspection to avoid it being lost or the vehicle being started accidentally.

en.question: How far should you stay behind another vehicle when driving on a highway?

options.A: 3 seconds for every 35 feet of vehicle length
options.B: 2 seconds for every 25 feet of vehicle length
options.C: 1 second for each 10 feet of vehicle length

en.description: Use the rule of 1 second for every 10 feet of vehicle length to keep a safe following distance.

en.question: When is the right time to learn how to use a fire extinguisher?

options.A: Only when the fire happens.
options.B: Only when you are transporting flammable materials.
options.C: Before the fire happens.

en.description: You should know how to use a fire extinguisher in advance so you’re ready in case of an emergency.

en.question: There's a vehicle in front of you with a sign on it. The sign has a red triangle and an orange middle. What does this sign tell you?

options.A: The vehicle is an emergency response unit.
options.B: It is a delivery service vehicle.
options.C: It may be a slow-moving vehicle.

en.description: A red triangle with an orange center is used to mark slow-moving vehicles like tractors or construction equipment.

en.question: At what Blood Alcohol Concentration (BAC) level is a commercial driver considered legally intoxicated while operating a commercial vehicle?
en.description: For truck and bus drivers, if their blood has more than 0.04% alcohol, they are considered too drunk to drive safely.

en.question: What does Gross Vehicle Weight (GVW) stand for?

options.A: Weight of the vehicle's engine only.
options.B: Total weight of a single vehicle plus its load.
options.C: Weight of the vehicle's tires only.

en.description: Gross Vehicle Weight (GVW) is the total weight of the vehicle itself plus everything it's carrying, including passengers, cargo, and any other items on board.

en.question: What emergency tools do you always need to have in your car?

options.A: Warning devices for parking vehicle.
options.B: Tire repair kit.
options.C: Spare fuel canisters

en.description: Your truck must have gear for emergencies: tools to signal when parked, a fire extinguisher to put out fires, and no spare fuel cans - they're not needed. Always be ready for any trouble on the road.

en.question: Which of these statements about the risk factors for a vehicle fire is correct?

options.A: Steel parts of the vehicle are more likely to catch fire than other parts.
options.B: Brake fluid is non-flammable.
options.C: Poor cargo ventilation may cause cargo to catch on fire.

en.description: If the area where goods are stored in a vehicle doesn't have enough air moving through it, there's a higher risk that these goods might start a fire.

en.question: What is true regarding the technique of double clutching and shifting?

options.A: Double clutching should only be used with a heavy load.
options.B: Double clutching should not be used when the road is slippery.
options.C: You can use the tachometer to tell you when to shift.

en.description: Double clutching means pressing the clutch twice when changing gears. It's best to use the tachometer, which shows your engine speed, to know the right time to shift gears. This helps make sure your truck runs smoothly.

en.question: You should not use stab braking on vehicles with:

options.A: Manual transmission systems
options.B: Air conditioning systems
options.C: Anti-lock brakes.

en.description: Stab braking shouldn't be used on vehicles with anti-lock brakes. This is because antilock brakes are designed to keep the wheels from locking up during braking, making it safer and easier to control the vehicle. Stab braking can mess with how these systems work.

en.question: What should you do if you are unsure whether your vehicle can go under an object because of its height?

options.A: Check the weather forecast for wind conditions that might affect clearance.
options.B: Drive closer to the center of the road to avoid the object.
options.C: Find another route that will not require driving under the object.

en.description: If you're not sure your truck can fit under something like a bridge, don't guess. Instead, choose a different way to go where you won't have to worry about fitting under that object. This keeps you and your truck safe.

en.question: How many miles into your journey must you conduct an inspection of your truck?
en.description: The correct answer is 50. This means that after you have traveled 50 miles from the start of your trip, you need to stop and check your truck to make sure everything is working properly.

en.question: What is the reason given in the driver's manual for advising against frequent use of your horn?

options.A: Using the horn can drain your vehicle's battery.
options.B: It can startle other drivers.
options.C: To avoid waking up nearby residents

en.description: You shouldn't honk your horn a lot because it can scare other drivers. This can make driving unsafe for everyone.

en.question: When driving a commercial vehicle, you need to pay extra attention to keep it in the middle of your lane because commercial vehicles:

options.A: Need more fuel than smaller vehicles
options.B: Have smaller mirrors, making it hard to see.
options.C: Are often wider than other vehicles.

en.description: Driving big trucks means you need to be extra careful keeping it in the middle of your lane because they're wider than most other vehicles. This extra width makes it tough to stay lined up right without paying close attention.

en.question: When should you stop driving?

options.A: Whenever you become sleepy.
options.B: When you've finished your coffee.
options.C: After 5 hours.

en.description: Stop driving when you feel sleepy. Driving tired can be very dangerous because you might fall asleep and cause an accident. It's important to listen to your body and rest when you need to, so everyone stays safe on the road.

en.question: Why is it important to check your truck or bus before driving?

options.A: To save fuel.
options.B: Safety.
options.C: To improve driving skills.

en.description: Checking your truck or bus is important to make sure it is safe to drive, which can help prevent accidents.

en.question: Communication means:

options.A: To communicate your intention to other motorists.
options.B: To listen to music loudly while driving
options.C: Using hand signals to play a game

en.description: Talking or signaling to let other drivers know what you plan to do on the road.

en.question: Which of the following is a type of jackknifing?

options.A: Both trailer and tractor.
options.B: Tractor.
options.C: Trailer.

en.description: Jackknifing happens when the trailer part of a big truck swings out and forms a sharp angle with the front part, kind of like a folding pocket knife. This can happen if the driver turns too sharply while going too fast.

en.question: Which item should NOT be checked during a pre-trip inspection?

options.A: Amount of fuel in a vehicle.
options.B: Cargo securement.
options.C: Whether all lights are working.

en.description: The amount of fuel isn't checked during a pre-trip inspection because the focus is on the vehicle's safety and functionality, not fuel levels.

en.question: What is the best course of action for drivers when confronted with dense fog?

options.A: Increase your speed to get out of the fog faster.
options.B: Turn on your loud music to alert other drivers.
options.C: Park the truck until the fog disappears.

en.description: When it's very foggy, it's safest to stop driving and park your truck. Wait until the fog clears up before you start driving again. This way, you avoid the risk of accidents because it's hard to see in fog.

en.question: When inspecting the vehicle, checking of - will NOT stop a fire from happening.

options.A: Cargo ventilation.
options.B: Electrical system isolation.
options.C: Battery fluid level.

en.description: Checking the battery fluid level will not prevent a fire, as fires are more likely caused by issues like fuel leaks or electrical problems, which aren't directly related to the battery fluid level.

en.question: What should you NOT do if a car suddenly cuts in front of you, creating a hazard?

options.A: Slow down to prevent a crash.
options.B: Honk your horn and stay close behind the car.
options.C: Signal and change lanes to avoid hazard.

en.description: Don't flash your high beams over and over, honk your horn while staying close to the car, or speed up to pass the car quickly. These actions can make the situation more dangerous.

en.question: If your vehicle starts burning while you're driving, what should you do?

options.A: Use water immediately to douse the flames.
options.B: Park in an open area.
options.C: Drive towards the nearest body of water.

en.description: If your vehicle starts burning while driving, find a wide-open space to park it safely. Parking in an open area helps avoid spreading the fire to buildings or trees and makes it easier for emergency services to reach you.

en.question: What is the best reaction when, on a road with only two lanes, you see another car coming towards you in your lane?

options.A: Flash your headlights rapidly.
options.B: Steer to the right.
options.C: Hard braking.

en.description: If another car comes into your lane, don't panic. Don't try to speed up or flash your lights. Instead, safely move to the right side of your lane or onto the shoulder if you can. This helps avoid a crash by giving the other driver space to get back into their lane.

en.question: Drivers of trucks and truck-trailers must verify that their load is securely fastened how many miles into their trip?
en.description: Truck drivers must make sure their load is safely tied down within the first 50 miles of their journey. This is important to prevent accidents or losing goods on the road.

en.question: Why is it necessary to change gears the right way?

options.A: To make the ride smoother for passengers.
options.B: To keep control of the vehicle.
options.C: To save fuel.

en.description: Shifting gears right helps you control the vehicle better.

en.question: You're driving a large vehicle known for making wide turns. You're on Pine Street and plan to turn left onto Cedar Street. Both Pine and Cedar Streets have two lanes and allow two-way traffic. Considering the need for extra turning space due to the size of your vehicle, what's the best approach for this left turn?

options.A: Use the right lane of Pine Street for the turn.
options.B: Wait until you reach the end of Cedar Street to start turning.
options.C: Begin turning your vehicle when you are halfway through the intersection.

en.description: When turning left in a big vehicle on two-way streets, start turning when halfway through the intersection. This helps make the wide turn safely without needing extra space from the right lane or waiting too long.

en.question: You're driving in an area with limited streetlights, and your headlights aren't giving you enough visibility. What strategy could improve your situation?

options.A: Apply a layer of reflective tape on the exterior of your vehicle.
options.B: Use your high beams when legal and keep your interior lights off.
options.C: Install brighter bulbs in your headlights.

en.description: When driving in the dark, switching to high beams can make it easier to see by shining a brighter, focused light ahead. Keeping the interior lights off prevents glare on your windshield, which helps you see hazards sooner.

en.question: Why does a vehicle go faster when moving downhill?

options.A: The air becomes thinner.
options.B: Lack of traction.
options.C: Gravity.

en.description: When you drive downhill, gravity pulls the vehicle faster, making it speed up.

en.question: The bridge formula:

options.A: Allows for unlimited axle weight regardless of distance between axles.
options.B: Calculates the maximum vehicle height based on axle distance.
options.C: Permits less maximum axle weight for axles that are closer together.

en.description: The bridge formula decides how much weight can be on each axle of a big vehicle. If the axles are closer together, the vehicle can't carry as much weight on them. This rule helps protect bridges and roads from heavy vehicles.

en.question: What's the proper way to handle a skid caused by accelerating too quickly with the drive wheels?

options.A: Turn the steering wheel rapidly left and right.
options.B: Stop accelerating.
options.C: Gently tap the brakes.

en.description: When your driving wheels start to skid because you're speeding up too much, the best thing to do is to stop pressing on the gas pedal. This helps your wheels catch grip again and stops the skid.

en.question: You should be aware that containerized loads __

options.A: Must be placed on flatbed trailers only.
options.B: Generally are used when freight is carried part way by rail or ship.
options.C: Do not need to be secured since they are in containers.

en.description: Loads in big boxes (containers) are usually used when goods are moved by trains or ships along with trucks.

en.question: Managing the space (to the) _ your vehicle is crucial.

options.A: To the side of
options.B: Front of
options.C: Back of

en.description: The space in front of your vehicle is the most crucial to keep an eye on because you need enough room to safely stop or react to things happening on the road. This helps prevent accidents and keeps you and others safe.

en.question: What is the correct definition of emergency braking?

options.A: Slowing down for a yellow traffic light.
options.B: Responding to a hazard by slowing the vehicle.
options.C: Using the turn signal while braking lightly.

en.description: Emergency braking is when you quickly slow down your vehicle because there's a danger or unexpected problem ahead. It's a fast response to stop or slow down to avoid a crash or hazard.

en.question: Which type of vehicle will find it most challenging to stay in its lane during strong wind conditions?

options.A: A double with an empty trailer.
options.B: A tractor pulling a loaded flatbed trailer.
options.C: A triple axle vehicle with cargo.

en.description: A big truck pulling an empty trailer is most likely to have a hard time staying in its lane when it's very windy. This is because the wind can push against the large, empty space of the trailer, making it harder to control.

en.question: Convex (curved) mirrors:

options.A: They show a wider area than flat mirrors show.
options.B: They reduce the field of view, making objects appear closer than they actually are.
options.C: They only show what's directly behind you.

en.description: Convex mirrors, like those on buses or trucks, let you see more around you than flat ones. But, things in these mirrors might look blurrier and not as clear. They don't just show what's directly behind but give a wider view.

en.question: What should you remember about using mirrors while driving?

options.A: Mirrors automatically adjust to reduce glare at night.
options.B: There are blind spots that your mirror cannot show.
options.C: Mirrors can display the exact speed of the vehicle behind you.

en.description: Mirrors don't show everything. There are hidden spots that your mirrors can't see, so always be careful and check those areas to stay safe on the road.

en.question: What practices should you follow while driving at night?

options.A: Adjust your speed to keep your stopping distance within your sight distance.
options.B: Turn off your headlights to reduce glare.
options.C: Use high beams in all situations to see further.

en.description: When driving at night, slow down so you can stop within the area you can see. Don't turn off your headlights; they help you see. Don't always use high beams; they can blind others.

en.question: What is the best course of action when you need to steer quickly to avoid a crash?

options.A: Close your eyes and steer in the direction you think is safest.
options.B: Turn off the engine while steering.
