options.C: Don't turn any more than needed to clear what is in your way.

en.description: When trying to avoid a crash, only turn the steering wheel as much as you need to get around the obstacle. Don't turn more than that.

en.question: Is it necessary to regularly check the adjustment of your brakes?

options.A: No, because the other brakes will make up for the air brakes when they are out of adjustment.
options.B: Yes, because the brakes can get out of adjustment when they are used a lot.
options.C: Only if the vehicle fails to stop properly.

en.description: Yes, it's important to check your brakes regularly because using them a lot can make them not work as well. This helps make sure they keep working right.

en.question: When you drive in an area where construction work is happening, you should:

options.A: Watch for sharp pavement drop off.
options.B: Increase your radio volume to stay alert.
options.C: Ignore traffic signs and signals.

en.description: When driving in a work zone, look out for sudden edges or drops in the road. Don't turn up your radio; it won't help keep you alert. Always pay attention to and follow the traffic signs and signals.

en.question: What should you do before making a turn that requires entering the opposite lane?

options.A: Watch for oncoming traffic.
options.B: Back to allow the oncoming traffic to pass.
options.C: Signal to oncoming traffic and proceed slowly.

en.description: When you have to get into the other lane to turn, make sure to look out for cars coming your way.

en.question: Which component does not add extra gears to certain trucks?

options.A: Auxiliary transmission
options.B: Automatic transmission.
options.C: Multi-speed rear axles.

en.description: Automatic transmission shifts gears on its own but doesn't add extra ones.

en.question: What should you do when you begin to drive up a hill from a stopped position?

options.A: Release the parking brakes as you apply engine power.
options.B: Press the accelerator hard while the brakes are still engaged.
options.C: Shift into a higher gear before starting up the hill.

en.description: When starting up a hill from a stop, first let go of the parking brake while gently pressing on the gas. This helps your truck move smoothly without rolling backward.

en.question: What is correct about the air pressure in tires?

options.A: Tire pressure doesn't matter as long as the tire looks full.
options.B: Tires should always be overinflated.
options.C: Air pressure in tires increases with the temperature.

en.description: Air pressure in tires increases with temperature because air expands when heated. This is why it's important to check tire pressure regularly, especially during seasonal temperature changes, to ensure safety and optimal tire performance.

en.question: High beams should be:

options.A: Dimmed at the time when you get within 100 feet of another vehicle.
options.B: Used when it is safe and legal to do so.
options.C: Activated in heavy traffic.

en.description: Use high beams when it's safe and allowed by law. Don't use them in heavy traffic.

en.question: After avoiding a collision by moving onto the right shoulder and continuing to drive at 40 mph, how should you safely return to the main part of the road?

options.A: If the shoulder is clear, stay on the right until your vehicle comes to a stop then move back into the pavement when it is safe.
options.B: Accelerate to match the speed of traffic before merging back onto the road.
options.C: Continue at 40 mph and merge directly into traffic.

en.description: If the shoulder of the road is clear, you should first move to the right side and remain there until your vehicle comes to a complete stop. Once it is safe to do so, carefully move your vehicle back onto the pavement and resume driving.

en.question: When dealing with a coolant container that is part of a pressurized system, which of the following is true?

options.A: The system self-regulates and requires no coolant top-ups.
options.B: You can check the coolant level of a hot engine.
options.C: The coolant container's markings shift with temperature, making a hot engine's reading unreliable.

en.description: Some vehicles have sight glasses, see-through coolant overflow containers, or coolant recovery containers. These permit you to check the coolant level while the engine is hot. Never remove the radiator cap or any part of the pressurized system until the system has cooled.

en.question: Which of these facts about using brakes is correct?

options.A: The faster or heavier the vehicle is, the more heat the brakes have to absorb to stop it.
options.B: Brakes work best when they are cold and dry.
options.C: Brake fade is not caused by heat.

en.description: When a vehicle is big or moves fast, its brakes need to soak up more heat to make it stop.

en.question: Which statement about handling different types of cargo is true?

options.A: Unstable load such as hanging meat or livestock can require extra caution on curves.
options.B: Dry goods do not need to be secured as they are not at risk of movement.
options.C: Fragile items can be stacked high as long as they are wrapped in plastic.

en.description: When carrying items that can move around easily, like hanging meat or animals, you need to be extra careful when turning. Dry items still need to be properly held down, and items that can break shouldn't be piled up high, even if they're wrapped in plastic.

en.question: What is the best response when drivers follow too closely behind your large vehicle during poor weather conditions?

options.A: Increase your following distance.
options.B: Switch lanes to let the tailgater pass.
options.C: Turn on your hazard lights to encourage them to keep distance.

en.description: If someone is driving too close to you in bad weather, it's smart to create more space between you and the car in front. This way, you have more time to react if something goes wrong.

en.question: What factors make tourists potential road hazards?

options.A: They may move slowly, unexpectedly change lanes or stop.
options.B: They often use maps while driving.
options.C: They might take photos while driving.

en.description: Tourists can be risky on the road because they might drive slowly, change lanes or stop without warning as they might be unsure of where they're going.

en.question: What actions are required if you find yourself parked on the roadside at night?

options.A: Turn on your four-way-emergency flashers to warn others.
options.B: Activate your vehicle's spotlight.
options.C: Keep your headlights on full beam.

en.description: The best choice is option 1. This is because using your emergency flashers makes your car more visible to other drivers, helping to prevent accidents.

en.question: What is likely to happen if you are convicted for the first time of DUI while driving a commercial vehicle?

options.A: Mandatory defensive driving course completion
options.B: At least one-year suspension of your CDL.
options.C: Community service for 50 hours

en.description: If you get caught driving a commercial vehicle under the influence for the first time, you'll likely lose your commercial driver's license for at least one year.

en.question: How long should the following distance be when you're driving a 40-foot vehicle at 35 mph under clear and dry conditions?

options.A: 4 seconds.
options.B: 6 seconds
options.C: 2 seconds

en.description: When driving a big 40-foot vehicle at 35 mph on a dry, clear day, you should stay at least 4 seconds behind the vehicle in front of you. This gives you enough time and space to stop safely if needed.

en.question: Which of these statements about staying alert while driving is true?

options.A: Drinking energy drinks continuously is better than taking breaks.
options.B: Listening to loud music is more effective than a short nap.
options.C: Sleep is the only thing that can overcome fatigue.

en.description: The only true way to fight off tiredness is by getting some sleep. Drinking lots of energy drinks or blasting loud music might seem helpful, but they don't really solve the problem of feeling sleepy. Taking short naps is a better choice than relying on these methods.

en.question: What should you do if your brakes overheat and fail while you're going down a long, steep hill?

options.A: Turn on your hazard lights and honk continuously.
options.B: Turn off your engine.
options.C: Look for an escape ramp or escape route.

en.description: If your brakes stop working on a steep hill, quickly look for a safe way off the road or an escape ramp to stop safely.

en.question: At night, it's advisable to switch to high beams if there's no oncoming traffic within how many feet?
en.description: When driving at night, use your high beams if no other cars are coming towards you and are farther than 500 feet away. High beams help you see better, but you must switch to low beams when cars are closer to avoid blinding other drivers.

en.question: How should you handle driving on a slippery road?

options.A: Slow down gradually.
options.B: Keep your speed the same as on a dry road.
options.C: Turn on your high beams.

en.description: When the road is slippery, it's safest to slow down slowly. This helps you keep control of your vehicle and avoid accidents. Keeping your speed like it's a dry road or using high beams won't make driving safer on a slippery surface.

en.question: During a pre-trip inspection on the steering and exhaust systems, which problem, if found, must be fixed before you drive?

options.A: Oil on a tie rod.
options.B: Steering wheel play of more than 10 degrees (2 inches on 20 inches steering wheel).
options.C: Rust on the exhaust system.

en.description: Before you drive, make sure the steering wheel doesn't move too much (more than 10 degrees or 2 inches on a big steering wheel).

en.question: What is the right way to let others know you want to switch lanes?

options.A: Signal early and change lane slowly and smoothly.
options.B: Signal only if other vehicles are close.
options.C: Signal at the last moment and swiftly change lanes.

en.description: The right way to switch lanes is to turn on your signal before you start moving, then carefully and slowly move into the new lane. This lets other drivers know what you're doing ahead of time and helps keep everyone safe on the road.

en.question: Where should you place reflective triangles to warn other drivers when stopping on a hill or curve on a two-lane two-way road?

options.A: Within 100 feet behind you.
options.B: Within 500 feet behind you.
options.C: Within 300 feet behind you.

en.description: If your vehicle stops on a hill or curve on a two-lane road, put reflective triangles 500 feet behind your vehicle to warn other drivers.

en.question: Which of these things should you not do when turning left?

options.A: Position your vehicle in the left lane, signal early, and maintain a smooth, controlled left turn
options.B: Start at the inside lane and swing right as you turn
options.C: Approach the intersection in the left-turn lane, use your left indicator, and stay in your lane until the turn is complete.

en.description: When turning left, you should not start in the inside lane and swing to the right. This is dangerous because it can confuse other drivers and cause accidents. You should stay in your lane and make a smooth, safe turn.

en.question: What kind of fires can you safely put out with water?

options.A: Oil fires
options.B: Tire fires.
options.C: Chemical fires

en.description: Tire fires can be safely extinguished with water because water can cool the rubber and suppress the flames without causing dangerous reactions.

en.question: Cargo inspection:

options.A: Must be done by a certified inspector before departure.
options.B: Should be performed after every break you take while driving.
options.C: Is required once at the beginning of the week.

en.description: Before you start driving and after every break, check your cargo to make sure it's safe and secure. No need for a special inspector to do it, and doing it just once a week isn't enough.

en.question: What is correct regarding the placement of emergency markers when a vehicle is stopped?

options.A: Turn on the vehicle's hazard lights only during daylight hours.
options.B: Place a sign on the vehicle stating it's not moving.
options.C: If a hill or curve keeps drivers behind you from seeing the vehicle within 500 feet, the reflective triangle should be moved back to give adequate warning.

en.description: If your vehicle stops where drivers can't see it within 500 feet because of a hill or curve, you need to put the reflective triangle further back to warn them.

en.question: In an emergency, which of the following actions should you avoid?

options.A: Steer sharply to the left or right depending on the obstacle.
options.B: Braking until your speed has dropped to about 20 mph.
options.C: Combining strong braking with precise steering adjustments to maintain control during an emergency.

en.description: In certain emergencies, coming to a complete stop isn't always the safest option. If there isn't enough space to brake in time, you may need to steer around whatever lies ahead.

en.question: What should you do if your hydraulic brakes stop working and you notice the brake pedal is spongy or hits the floor?

options.A: Pump the brake pedal to generate pressure.
options.B: Turn off the engine to stop the vehicle.
options.C: Turn on the hazard lights and keep driving.

en.description: If your hydraulic brakes fail and the pedal feels spongy or goes to the floor, you should quickly pump the brake pedal. This action can help build up enough pressure in the brake system to allow you to stop the vehicle safely.

en.question: Getting stuck on railroad tracks might occur if:

options.A: The tracks have a steep approach.
options.B: Your trailer is too light.
options.C: You drive too fast over the tracks.

en.description: If the road leading to the tracks is very steep, your vehicle might get stuck on the tracks.

en.question: Escape ramps:

options.A: Require special permits to use.
options.B: Can only be found on steep grades longer than 1 mile.
options.C: Should be used by any driver who loses braking power.

en.description: Escape ramps are safety areas on steep roads where drivers can go if their brakes stop working. Any driver with brake problems should use them to stop safely. They don't need special permits and are found on long, steep roads.

en.question: Serious skids are often caused by:

options.A: Driving too fast for conditions.
options.B: Not using headlights in rain
options.C: Ignoring traffic signs

en.description: Most skids happen because you're driving too quickly for the weather or road conditions. If you go too fast when it's rainy, snowy, or the road is slippery, your vehicle is more likely to skid and lose control. Always match your speed to how the road and weather are.

en.question: What should you do if an oncoming vehicle at night does not dim its high beams?

options.A: Turn off your headlights.
options.B: Look to the right lane or edge markings of the road.
options.C: Turn on your interior lights.

en.description: If another car's bright lights are blinding you at night, don't look straight at them. Instead, keep your eyes on the right side of the road or the lane markers to stay safe and avoid being blinded.

en.question: Which consequence is unlikely to occur if you shift into a low gear while driving fast with an automatic transmission?

options.A: Overheating of the engine
options.B: Increased fuel consumption
options.C: A loss of steering control.

en.description: Switching to a low gear at high speed won't make you lose control of steering. It can make the engine too hot and use more fuel, but steering the truck stays the same.

en.question: What is the main reason for deadly accidents on the road?

options.A: Driving too fast.
options.B: Driving with the radio too loud.
options.C: Driving in bad weather

en.description: The main reason for deadly car accidents is driving too fast. Going too quickly makes it harder to stop or react in time to avoid dangers. This can lead to serious crashes, especially on busy roads or in bad weather. Always keep to the speed limit to stay safe.

en.question: Is it within the authority of state inspectors to inspect your truck or bus, and do they have the power to put it out of service?

options.A: Only at designated inspection stations.
options.B: Yes and they can put you out of service if unsafe.
options.C: Only with your permission.

en.description: Yes, state inspectors can check your truck or bus anytime to see if it's safe. If they find something wrong, they can stop you from driving it.

en.question: What is the proper procedure to recover from a skid caused by the drive wheels locking up during braking?

options.A: Accelerate and hold the steering wheel firmly
options.B: Turn off the engine.
options.C: Stop braking, turn quickly, then counter steer.

en.description: If your drive wheels start sliding, first, stop stepping on the brake. Then, quickly turn the steering wheel in one direction and immediately steer it back the other way. This helps you regain control of the vehicle.

en.question: Oversized loads:

options.A: Are allowed on all roads at any time.
options.B: Require special permits.
options.C: Need to be painted bright pink

en.description: When you're carrying really big loads that don't fit normal size limits, you can't just drive them on any road whenever you want. You need to get special permission or permits to do so. This makes sure it's safe for everyone on the road.

en.question: What is the duration of CDL suspension for a first offense of operating a commercial vehicle while under the influence of alcohol or drugs?

options.A: 3 months
options.B: 1 year
options.C: 4 years

en.description: If you're caught driving a big truck or any commercial vehicle after drinking alcohol or taking drugs, you won't be allowed to drive these kinds of vehicles for 1 year. If you do it again, the punishment is even harsher.

en.question: In a scenario where a collision with another vehicle seems unavoidable without taking evasive measures, which principle should be considered?

options.A: Turning off your headlights can help avoid collisions.
options.B: Speeding up is often the best way to avoid a crash.
options.C: You can almost always turn to miss an obstacle more quickly than you can stop.

en.description: If you think you can't avoid hitting another car unless you take some action, you should know that turning your car to avoid the obstacle is usually faster than trying to stop. So, the best thing to do is to turn your car quickly to miss the obstacle.

en.question: Which statement is true regarding the impact of high temperatures on tire condition?

options.A: You should inspect your tires every two hours or every 100 miles when driving in very hot weather.
options.B: Tires are less likely to blow out in hot weather because the heat expands the air inside.
options.C: Tires naturally get cooler and perform better as the outside temperature rises.

en.description: When it's very hot, check your tires every 2 hours or every 100 miles. Hot weather can actually increase the chance of tire problems because the heat makes the air inside expand. This can lead to more tire blowouts.

en.question: Under what circumstances is it necessary to have assistants while backing your vehicle?

options.A: Only during nighttime.
options.B: Whenever you have to back.
options.C: Only if the area is crowded.

en.description: Whenever you need to back up your vehicle, it's smart to have someone help you. This ensures you can see areas you normally can't and avoid accidents. It's especially helpful in tight or crowded spots, but good practice anytime you're reversing.

en.question: To avoid a collision, you turned onto the shoulder. With the shoulder clear, what should you do next?

options.A: Turn on your hazard lights and wait for help.
options.B: Speed up and merge into the traffic immediately.
options.C: Stay on shoulder until your vehicle has come to a stop.

en.description: If you turned onto the shoulder to avoid a collision, it's important to make sure your vehicle is completely stopped and safe before doing anything else. This helps prevent further accidents and gives you a chance to assess the situation calmly.

en.question: Lacking a hazardous materials endorsement on your commercial driver's license, yet being asked to transport hazardous materials in a vehicle that requires placarding. How should you respond?

options.A: Refuse to haul the load.
options.B: Take the load and make sure to drive extra carefully.
options.C: Ask a friend to drive instead

en.description: If you don't have the special permission (hazardous materials endorsement) on your driver's license to carry dangerous goods, you should not agree to transport them. It's against the rules to carry such materials without the right permission, no matter how careful you are or if someone else drives instead.

en.question: Which principle about managing your speed is correct?

options.A: Driving slowly means you can always stop instantly.
options.B: You should choose a speed that lets you stop within the distance that you can see ahead.
options.C: You can safely drive at any speed if you're experienced.

en.description: The right way to pick your speed is to make sure you can stop your vehicle safely within the distance you can clearly see in front of you.

en.question: What type of driving involves being aware and ready for possible dangers ahead?

options.A: Aggressive
options.B: Defensive
options.C: Reactive

en.description: Drivers who watch out for dangers and think ahead to avoid them are practicing defensive driving. This means they are careful and ready to react to keep safe, not aggressive or just reacting when something happens.

en.question: What action is necessary if ice buildup prevents your windshield wipers from functioning properly while driving?

options.A: Slow down and open your windows to see better.
options.B: Stop safely and fix the problem.
options.C: Turn on your high beams to melt the ice.

en.description: If your wipers get icy and can't clean your windshield, the best thing to do is to safely stop and remove the ice. Don't try to drive with bad visibility or use other methods that might not work.

en.question: What's true about checking parts of the suspension system?

options.A: Axles' mounts should be checked at each point where they are secured on the vehicle frame and axles.
options.B: Spring coils can be slightly compressed and still be considered safe.
options.C: U-bolts can be loose as long as they are not completely detached.

en.description: When checking the parts that help your vehicle's wheels move smoothly, make sure the parts that connect the axles to the vehicle are tightly fixed. U-bolts should never be loose, even if they're not fully off.

en.question: You can identify the presence of hazardous materials by looking at the container _.

options.A: Sizes
options.B: Colors
options.C: Labels

en.description: To know if something is a hazardous material, check the labels on its container. Labels give important info like what the material is and how to safely handle it.

en.question: When filling out a vehicle inspection report, you must sign it _.

options.A: Before the vehicle is used again
options.B: When any defects are noted whether they are certified to be repaired or not.
options.C: After the vehicle has been driven for more than 100 miles.

en.description: When you check your vehicle and note any problems, you need to sign the inspection report. This is important whether the issues are fixed yet or not.

en.question: A crucial principle to follow when loading cargo is to ensure that the load is:

options.A: Above the cab height
options.B: Balanced in the cargo area.
options.C: Below the truck's floor level

en.description: When packing stuff onto a truck, make sure the weight is evenly spread out in the back. This helps keep the truck stable and safe to drive.

en.question: You are driving a long vehicle that makes wide turns. You want to turn left onto Oak Street from Elm Street. Elm Street has two left-turn lanes (marked A and B). Oak Street is a four-lane street with two lanes in each direction. You should:

options.A: Drive straight through the intersection and make a U-turn further down Oak Street.
options.B: Use left turn lane 'B'
options.C: Turn right onto Oak Street and then make a U-turn.

en.description: Choose left turn lane 'B' for a wide turn. This lane gives your long vehicle more space to turn without hitting anything or moving into other lanes.

en.question: A vehicle's destructive force in a crash is approximately how many times greater if you double its speed?
en.description: When you double the speed of your vehicle, the force in a crash becomes 4 times stronger. This makes crashes more dangerous.

en.question: If you're behind the wheel of a 40-foot vehicle cruising at 55 mph on a dry road with good visibility, how much space should you ensure is open in front of you?

options.A: 5 seconds
options.B: 7 seconds
options.C: 8 seconds

en.description: If you're driving a 40-foot vehicle at 55 mph on a dry road with good visibility, you should keep a 5-second distance between your vehicle and the one in front to give yourself enough time to react and stop if needed.

en.question: What does Gross Vehicle Weight Rating (GVWR) mean?

options.A: The total weight a vehicle can carry including passengers and cargo.
options.B: The manufacturer-specified maximum combined weight of the vehicle and any attached trailer when fully loaded.
options.C: The weight of the vehicle when it's not carrying any cargo or passengers.

en.description: GVWR is the max weight set by the maker for a vehicle when it's full of passengers and cargo.

en.question: Which statement regarding the regulation of driving hours for commercial drivers is true?

options.A: You can drive for as long as you feel alert without taking breaks.
options.B: You should balance your hour of service with enough sleep to keep you alert.
options.C: You can ignore the hours of service rules if you drink coffee.

en.description: You need to mix your driving hours with enough rest to stay awake and alert. This means you can't just drive non-stop because you feel okay or drink coffee to ignore the rules about how long you can drive.

en.question: Aggressive driving is:

options.A: Driving a vehicle with the intent to do harm to others.
options.B: Driving a vehicle slower than the speed limit on purpose.
options.C: Driving a vehicle with loud music to distract other drivers.

en.description: Aggressive driving means you drive in a way that could hurt others on purpose. This isn't about going slow or playing loud music, but about dangerous actions that could cause harm.

en.question: In the event of a rear tire failure, dual rear tire:

options.A: Enables faster acceleration
options.B: May prevent vibration or thumping.
options.C: Reduces engine power automatically

en.description: When one of the back tires goes flat, having two tires next to each other helps keep the ride smooth and stops the truck from shaking too much.

en.question: While driving a vehicle equipped with ABS brakes, a yellow light on the dashboard begins flashing. What could this indicate?

options.A: Your vehicle ABS may not be functioning properly.
options.B: Your tire pressure is too high.
options.C: Your headlights are not working.

en.description: If the yellow light on your dashboard blinks while driving and your car has ABS brakes, it likely means the ABS system isn't working right. ABS helps you steer during hard braking, so if it's not working, braking might be less safe.

en.question: What behaviors could indicate that a driver is being aggressive on the road?

options.A: Using turn signals for every turn and lane change.
options.B: Changing lines frequently and abruptly without notice.
options.C: Following too closely behind another vehicle.

en.description: An aggressive driver often switches lanes quickly without warning.

en.question: How can a driver effectively deal with fatigue?

options.A: Drinking lots of coffee
options.B: It can only be paid off by sleeping.
options.C: Ignoring it and continuing to work.

en.description: Being very tired can only be fixed properly by getting some sleep. Drinking lots of coffee or just trying to push through it doesn't really solve the problem.

en.question: What should a driver do when they see a circular sign that's black and yellow?

options.A: Slow down, look and listen, and be prepared to stop if a train is approaching.
options.B: Sharp turn to the right.
options.C: No passing zone ahead.

en.description: A round, black on yellow sign warns you. It means slow down, look around, and be ready to stop for a train.

en.question: What is NOT correct about using brakes in an emergency?

options.A: You should always apply the brakes as hard as possible, regardless of the road conditions.
options.B: It is not important how you brake in an emergency situation.
options.C: Braking should be done only with the front wheels to maintain control.

en.description: In an emergency situation, how you brake is very important. You need to apply the brakes in a way that helps you control the vehicle and stop safely.

en.question: How can you spot a driver who isn't paying attention?

options.A: The vehicle is drifting across lines and moving at variable speeds.
options.B: The driver is using turn signals correctly for every lane change.
options.C: The vehicle is maintaining a consistent speed in the correct lane.

en.description: A distracted driver can often be spotted if their car keeps zigzagging between lanes or changing speed for no clear reason. This happens because they're not paying full attention to driving.

en.question: What is the safest way to use communication devices inside a vehicle?

options.A: Read text messages only at stop lights.
options.B: Adjust the volume while driving.
options.C: Pull off the road in a safe, legal place to use the equipment.

en.description: The best way to use things like phones in your truck is to first pull over safely off the road. Then, you can use your device without risking an accident.

en.question: Trucks and buses have to follow special rules and limits. Which of these statements is true?

options.A: Buses are exempt from highway speed limits.
options.B: Trucks must stop at all green traffic lights.
options.C: Laws and restrictions can vary from place to place.

en.description: Different places have their own rules for trucks and buses. What's allowed in one area might not be in another.

en.question: If the yellow ABS warning light turns on in a truck, truck, or bus while you're driving, what does it mean?

options.A: Your vehicle's ABS may not be functioning.
options.B: Your vehicle's oil level is too high.
options.C: Your headlights are not working properly.

en.description: If the yellow ABS light turns on while you're driving a big vehicle like a truck or bus, it means the antilock brake system might not be working right.

en.question: You looked in your mirror and saw a car coming from behind. When you checked again, the car was gone. You want to switch lanes. What should you do?

options.A: Wait to change lanes until you are sure that car isn't in your blind spot.
options.B: Your headlights are not working properly.
options.C: Turn on your radio to distract yourself from the worry.

en.description: Before changing lanes, make sure the car that disappeared from your mirror isn't in your blind spot where you can't see it. Always double-check before moving over to avoid any accidents.

en.question: You can tell if the vehicle you're driving has ABS brakes by:

options.A: A manual in the glove compartment detailing the ABS system.
options.B: A sticker on the windshield indicating ABS is present.
options.C: When you turn on the ignition, yellow ABS malfunction lamps light up on the instrument panel.

en.description: When you start the car, if it has ABS brakes, a yellow warning light that says ABS will turn on for a bit on the dashboard.

en.question: How fast you go should be determined by:

options.A: The color of your truck.
options.B: The type of music you're listening to.
options.C: Your visibility.

en.description: When deciding how fast to drive, think about how well you can see. If it's hard to see far ahead because of weather or nighttime, slow down.

en.question: How much brake pressure you need to stop the vehicle depends on:

options.A: The temperature outside and the weight of the driver.
options.B: The vehicle's speed and how quickly you want to stop.
options.C: The color of the vehicle

en.description: The force needed to stop your truck changes based on how fast you're going, and how quickly you need to stop.

en.question: The antilock braking system uses special sensors and computers to detect:

options.A: Potential wheel lock up.
options.B: Tire pressure levels
options.C: Engine temperature readings

en.description: Antilock braking systems use special technology to notice when a wheel is about to stop turning and skid, helping to keep the vehicle under control during sudden stops.

en.question: Tire chains:

options.A: Should always be carried when driving in winter weather.
options.B: Should be checked for damage only once a year.
options.C: Can be left loose for better traction

en.description: When driving in winter, always have tire chains with you. They need to be checked for damage more than once a year. Don't leave them loose; they must be fitted properly for safety.

en.question: What is true about tires?

options.A: You should inspect your tires every two hours or every 100 miles when driving in very hot weather.
options.B: Tires with different tread depths are safer for long trips.
options.C: Tires should be replaced with new ones every 5000 miles to ensure safety.

en.description: When driving in hot weather, check your tires every two hours or every 100 miles to make sure they're safe.

en.question: What should you do if a turn requires entering the lane of oncoming traffic?

options.A: Watch for oncoming traffic.
options.B: Signal the oncoming traffic to stop.
options.C: Drive faster to finish the turn quickly

en.description: When turning and you have to stop in the lane for cars coming towards you, make sure to keep an eye out for these cars. Don’t tell them to stop or speed up to finish your turn quickly.

en.question: What actions are advised when you're nearing a bridge while driving on a road with two lanes?

options.A: Turn off your headlights.
options.B: Check the weight limit of the bridge.
options.C: Increase your speed to cross quickly.

en.description: Before you go over a bridge on a small road, always look for how much weight it can handle to make sure your vehicle isn't too heavy for it.

en.question: What are the risks associated with driving over railroad crossings on dirt roads?

options.A: You might accidentally follow the wrong path and get lost.
options.B: You could get hung up halfway across the tracks.
options.C: Dirt on the tracks could reduce tire traction, causing sliding.

en.description: Crossing railroad tracks on dirt roads can be risky because your vehicle might get stuck on the tracks due to misalignment or uneven terrain.

en.question: What is the recommended procedure if your vehicle gets stuck at an elevated railroad-highway intersection?

options.A: Wait for help inside the vehicle.
options.B: Get out the vehicle and away from the tracks.
options.C: Call a friend for advice.

en.description: If your vehicle is stuck on train tracks, don’t stay inside. Get out quickly and move far away from the tracks to stay safe.

en.question: An antilock braking system is:

options.A: A method to increase fuel efficiency.
options.B: An addition to your normal brakes.
options.C: A system to enhance vehicle speed.

en.description: An antilock braking system helps your normal brakes work better by stopping wheels from locking and skidding.

en.question: Placards must be:

options.A: Displayed inside the vehicle's cabin
options.B: Visible only during daytime hours.
options.C: Placed on all four sides of a vehicle.

en.description: Placards, which are warning signs, must be placed on all four sides of a vehicle carrying hazardous materials for visibility from all directions.

en.question: To keep your cargo from sliding, you should use blocking___

options.A: In the front, back, and/or sides of the cargo.
options.B: Attached to the roof of the cargo space.
options.C: Under the cargo.

en.description: Cargo blocking is used on the front, back, or sides of cargo to prevent it from moving during transport.

en.question: If you need to use your cell phone while driving, you should:

options.A: Hold the phone with your shoulder while driving.
options.B: Pull off the road onto a safe and legal position.
options.C: Use voice commands only, without handling the phone.

en.description: If you need to use a phone while driving, pull over in a safe and legal spot to avoid distractions and stay safe.

en.question: What's the best practice for adjusting your speed on roads where trucks are required to move slower than cars?

options.A: Only use the left lane for passing.
options.B: Adjust your speed to speed of other trucks and buses.
options.C: Keep your vehicle at the maximum speed limit allowed for trucks, regardless of traffic flow.

en.description: Drive at the same speed as other trucks and buses to maintain smooth and safe traffic flow.

en.question: What is an INCORRECT way to use your vehicle's lights?

options.A: Turning on interior lights while driving at night to read a map.
options.B: Using your high beams when driving in fog.
options.C: Flashing your brake light to get someone off your tail.

en.description: Flashing your brake lights to intimidate or signal another driver is unsafe and may provoke road rage or confusion.

en.question: What should you do when nearing a traffic signal that's been green for a while?

options.A: Turn off your engine and wait.
options.B: Wait until the light turns yellow, then slow down.
options.C: Start slowing down so you will be ready to stop.

en.description: If a green light has been on for a while, slow down in case it changes so you’re prepared to stop safely.

en.question: One reason tanks that carry dry bulk need extra attention is:

options.A: The load can shift.
options.B: They require special cleaning chemicals.
options.C: They increase fuel consumption significantly.

en.description: When driving a truck with a dry bulk tank, you need to be extra careful because the stuff inside can move around a lot. This can make driving tricky, especially when turning or stopping.

en.question: When driving up or down hills, what's the best way to pick a safe speed?

options.A: Based on your vehicle and its cargo, select a safe speed that is within the posted speed.
options.B: Use the speed of the vehicle coming towards you as a guide.
options.C: Adjust your speed to match the radio's music tempo.

en.description: When driving downhill or uphill, pick a speed that's safe for your truck and what you're carrying, and make sure it's not more than the speed limit.

en.question: What additional equipment, besides a tire wrench, might you have in your vehicle for safety or maintenance purposes?

options.A: Spare tire
options.B: First aid kit
options.C: Battery charger.

en.description: When driving a big vehicle like a truck or bus, it's smart to have some extra items with you. A battery charger means you can boost your vehicle's battery if it dies, avoiding getting stuck.

en.question: What is ABS used for?

options.A: Give you more control over the vehicle when braking.
options.B: Reduce the vehicle's stopping distance significantly.
options.C: Lower the effectiveness of your vehicle's brake lights

en.description: ABS brakes help you steer better when you hit the brakes hard. They don't make the car stop faster but keep the brakes from locking so you can control the car better.

en.question: What should you do before deciding to drive if you've consumed alcohol?

options.A: Go for a run.
options.B: Eat a big meal
options.C: Wait for it to wear off.

en.description: If you've had alcohol, don't drive right away. Instead, wait until the effects of the alcohol have completely gone away. This is the safest choice to ensure you're fully sober and can drive without any risk.

en.question: What is the appropriate response when dealing with an aggressive driver on the road?

options.A: Speed up to match the aggressive driver's speed.
options.B: Make every attempt to get out of their way.
options.C: Ignore the driver and keep driving at your speed.

en.description: If another driver is being aggressive, like tailgating or yelling, try your best to safely move aside and let them pass. Don't try to speed up or compete with them. Stay calm and keep driving safely.

en.question: Doubling your speed will increase your stopping distance __ times.

options.A: Eight
options.B: Five
options.C: Four

en.description: When you go twice as fast, it takes about four times more road to come to a stop.

en.question: What should you do if you're operating a commercial vehicle taller than 13 feet?

options.A: Use a GPS to find routes without low clearances.
options.B: Drive only during daylight to avoid low clearances.
options.C: Stop and make sure that a clearance is high enough.

en.description: When driving a commercial vehicle with a height over 13 feet, it's crucial to ensure the vehicle can safely pass under any overhead clearance. Drivers should stop and verify that the height of the clearance, such as a bridge or overpass, is sufficient to avoid any accidents or damage to the vehicle. Always be cautious, as clearance heights can vary depending on conditions like road construction or resurfacing, which may reduce the available height. Failing to check clearances could result in serious accidents or vehicle damage.

en.question: Which of these options is INCORRECT?

options.A: Drinking coffee will not help lower your BAC faster.
options.B: A drinker can control how fast his or her body absorbs and gets rid of alcohol.
options.C: Eating food can help slow the absorption of alcohol into your bloodstream.

en.description: The statement that 'a drinker can control how fast his or her body absorbs and eliminates alcohol' is incorrect. The body's process of absorbing and eliminating alcohol is largely automatic and cannot be controlled by the individual.

en.question: How should you signal your presence to other drivers when visibility is poor due to heavy rain or snow?

options.A: Opening all windows
options.B: Flashing your high-beam headlights
options.C: Turning on the low-beam headlights.

en.description: When it's really hard to see because of heavy rain or snow, it's best to turn on your low-beam headlights. This helps other drivers see you without blinding them, like high-beam lights can do.

en.question: Perception distance is how far your vehicle goes from the moment:

options.A: The eyes see a hazard to the time your foot pushes to the brake pedal.
options.B: The radio is turned off to the time the hazard lights are activated.
options.C: The headlights are turned on to the time the vehicle slows down.

en.description: Perception distance is how far your vehicle goes while you notice a danger and then start to press the brake pedal to slow down.

en.question: While driving, your gaze should be directed:

options.A: Only in the rearview mirror.
options.B: Only to the left side of the road.
options.C: Back and forth, near and far.

en.description: When driving, it's important to keep an eye on everything around you, not just nearby but also what's further ahead. This means you should constantly move your gaze from side to side and look far down the road, not just at what's immediately in front of you. This helps you spot any potential dangers early and react in time.

en.question: For this question, imagine you are operating a long vehicle that makes wide turns. You plan to turn left from Ocean Street onto Atlantic Street. This intersection presents you with a choice between two left-turn lanes: the inside lane (first from the left) and the outside (second from the left). Given the characteristics of your vehicle and the roadway configuration, you should:

options.A: Start from the third lane and make a wide left turn.
options.B: Use outside turn lane (second from the left).
options.C: Wait in the middle of both lanes before turning.

en.description: Choose the outside turn lane (second from the left) to make your turn. This gives your long vehicle enough space to complete the turn without crossing into other lanes.

en.question: A good sign that the road may be starting to ice over is when _.

options.A: The air feels warmer.
options.B: Your outside mirrors have ice on them.
options.C: Your antenna starts to vibrate.

en.description: When it's getting icy on the road, a clear sign is seeing ice build up on your outside mirrors. If you spot ice there, it's a good hint that the road is also starting to get icy. So, keep an eye on your mirrors for ice to stay safe.

en.question: When navigating mountainous terrain cautiously, what factor is crucial to consider for ensuring safety?

options.A: Weight of the vehicle.
options.B: Length of the vehicle's brakes usage time
options.C: Height of the vehicle

en.description: When navigating mountainous terrain with caution, it's crucial to consider the weight of your vehicle. The vehicle's weight can significantly impact braking, control, and maneuverability, especially on steep inclines and declines.

en.question: What's important to keep in mind regarding alcohol consumption?

options.A: Eating a big meal will speed up the process of eliminating alcohol from your system.
options.B: Drinking coffee will help sober you up more quickly.
options.C: Alcohol first affect judgment and self-C control, which are necessary for safe driving.

en.description: Alcohol messes with your decision-making and self-control first, which you really need to drive safely.

en.question: Over-weight or over-sized loads:

options.A: Need to pay a fine before moving.
options.B: Require a special transit permit.
options.C: Are only allowed on weekends.

en.description: If your truck's load is too heavy or too big, you must get a special permission slip to move it.

en.question: What's the right action to fix a skid caused by accelerating too quickly with the rear wheels?

options.A: Turn the steering wheel quickly to the left.
options.B: Stop accelerating.
options.C: Turn off the engine.

en.description: To fix a skid where the back wheels of your vehicle slide because you sped up too fast, stop pressing the gas pedal. This helps your vehicle regain control and stop skidding.

en.question: Make sure to set up your vehicle's outside mirrors so that:

options.A: You can only see the road behind you.
options.B: Some part of the vehicle is showing.
options.C: You can see the sky clearly.

en.description: Adjust your vehicle's mirrors so you can see a bit of your vehicle. This helps you know how your vehicle fits in traffic and spots in your mirror's view.

en.question: When you're operating a large vehicle and it starts to rain, making the roads slick, what action is advisable?

options.A: Decrease your speed even further for adverse weather.
options.B: Increase your speed to pass the slippery section quickly.
options.C: Apply sudden brakes to stop.

en.description: When it rains and the road gets slippery, slow down even more than usual. This helps you stay safe because your vehicle can slide easily on wet roads. Speeding up or stopping suddenly can cause accidents.

en.question: While driving through continuous rainfall, what sign suggests that hydroplaning can occur?

options.A: The vehicle's speed is under 30 mph.
options.B: The vehicle in front of you creates water splashes.
options.C: The rain stops suddenly.

en.description: When driving in rain and you see the vehicle ahead making water splashes, it means the road is very wet and your car could start sliding on the water surface, like it's surfing. This is a sign that hydroplaning might happen.

en.question: The total working load limit of a cargo securement system must be a minimum of _ the cargo weight.

options.A: Four times
options.B: Three times
options.C: One-half times

en.description: When tying down cargo, the total strength of all the things used to hold the cargo must be at least half the weight of the cargo itself. This means if your cargo weighs 1000 pounds, the gear you use to secure it must be able to handle at least 500 pounds.

en.question: What are hazardous materials placards and what is their purpose?

options.A: They are signs on the outside of the vehicle that indicate the hazard class of cargo
options.B: They are electronic screens inside the vehicle showing the cargo's destination.
options.C: They are labels on packages that list the ingredients of the hazardous materials.

en.description: Hazardous materials placards are signs put on the outside of trucks. They show what kind of dangerous goods are inside by using special symbols or classes. This helps people know what's being carried and how to be safe around it.

en.question: Which of the following statements about overtaking a motorcycle is TRUE?

options.A: Flash your headlights repeatedly.
options.B: Stay in their lane and not move over.
options.C: Motorcyclists might be dragged off course by the vehicle's air suction

en.description: When you pass a motorcycle, be careful because the wind from your vehicle might pull the motorcycle towards you or push it away. This can make it hard for the motorcyclist to stay in their lane.

en.question: Which of the following actions will help prevent skidding?

options.A: Drive as close as possible to the vehicle in front of you.
options.B: Accelerate quickly when starting.
options.C: Adapt driving speed according to road or weather conditions.

en.description: To keep your vehicle from sliding, make sure to drive slower or faster based on the road or the weather. If it's raining or snowy, go slower. This helps you stay in control.

en.question: What does a hazard mean?

options.A: A regular occurrence that requires no special attention.
options.B: A potential danger that may be caused by someone or something
options.C: A situation that can be easily ignored.

en.description: A hazard is something that could be dangerous, caused by a person or thing.

en.question: The word "load" means -__.

options.A: The total weight a vehicle can safely transport.
options.B: The maximum load that can be carried by a B tire at a certain pressure without causing damage.
options.C: The average pressure recommended for a tire.

en.description: The term "load" means the heaviest weight a tire can carry safely at a certain air pressure without getting damaged.

en.question: How soon should the oil pressure gauge show the normal level after you start the engine?

options.A: After 5 hours.
options.B: In a few seconds
options.C: Within 30 minutes.

en.description: After you start the truck's engine, the oil pressure should become normal quickly, in just a few seconds. This is important because it means the oil is flowing properly to keep the engine running smoothly.

en.question: Locking jaws should close around the__ of the kingpin for a secure connection.

options.A: Tip
options.B: Groove
options.C: Shank

en.description: The locking jaws of a trailer should close around the "shank" part of the kingpin. This is the correct way to connect a trailer to a truck safely.

en.question: Why do we use blocking and bracing?

options.A: To adjust the mirrors for better visibility.
options.B: Common method to keep cargo secure
options.C: To reduce fuel consumption.

en.description: Blocking and bracing is a way to make sure your cargo doesn't move around while you're driving. It helps keep everything in place so it's safe and secure.

en.question: Which of the following should you not worry about when driving on a hot day?

options.A: Drive at a slower speed to prevent overheating.
options.B: Slippery roadways caused by melting tar.
options.C: Bugs squashed on the windshield will get dried up quickly.
options.D: Overheating could be caused by loose belts in the engine compartment.

en.description: Bugs on the windshield will dry quickly on a hot day, so this is not something to worry about while driving.

en.question: What is an example of communicating safely?

options.A: Honking your horn when it's legal and you need to pass another vehicle.
options.B: Flashing your lights at night, whenever you need to pass
options.C: Turning on headlights at night and when visibility is poor

en.description: Honking, flashing lights legally, and using headlights when visibility is poor are all important ways to communicate safely on the road.

en.question: What part does NOT belong to the important parts of the steering system?

options.A: Tie rod
options.B: Steering shaft
options.C: Bearing plates

en.description: "Bearing plates" are not part of the steering system.

en.question: For loads extending how far beyond the vehicle's back must flags or lights be used?

options.A: 6 feet or less beyond the back.
options.B: 5 feet or less beyond the back.
options.C: 3 feet or more beyond the back
options.D: 4 feet or more beyond the back

en.description: Loads extending 4 feet or more beyond the vehicle's rear must have flags or lights for safety.

en.question: Whenever you park and turn off the engine, you must always _.

options.A: Open your window to listen for traffic.
options.B: Apply the parking brake.
options.C: Check your mirrors for traffic.

en.description: Always apply the parking brake when parking and turning off the engine to prevent the vehicle from moving.

en.question: When you want to shift up, first let go of the gas pedal, engage the clutch, shift to neutral, and then __

options.A: Pull the handbrake
options.B: Tap the brake pedal
options.C: Release clutch

en.description: After shifting to neutral while pressing the clutch, release the clutch pedal before continuing to the next gear.

en.question: Which action does NOT belong to the basic process of shifting up?

options.A: Letting go of the brake
options.B: Putting the clutch down and changing to a higher gear at the same time
options.C: Letting go of the clutch and stepping on the gas at the same time
options.D: Putting pressure on the clutch while speeding up and turning toward the driver's side.

en.description: Pushing the clutch while speeding up and turning the wheel is not part of the proper shifting up procedure.

en.question: What sign indicates a safety concern when inspecting wheels or rims?

options.A: Deformed rims
options.B: Missing lug nuts
options.C: Homemade welds on the wheel

en.description: Any of these issues—deformed rims, missing lug nuts, or homemade welds—are safety concerns and should be addressed.

en.question: What steps should you take to check an engine?

options.A: Apply the parking brake and shift into neutral or park (automatic)
options.B: Turn on the engine and hear if there are abnormal sounds
options.C: All of the above

en.description: Applying the parking brake and checking for abnormal engine sounds are both important steps in checking an engine.

en.question: What statement is correct about a pre-trip inspection of your wheels and rims?

options.A: If there is rust around the lug nuts, it could indicate that they are loose.
options.B: Cracks in the rim can be temporarily fixed with duct tape.
options.C: Using a hammer to straighten bent rims is acceptable for a temporary fix.
options.D: The loosened lug nuts can be hand tightened if you are in a hurry.

en.description: Rust around lug nuts can be a sign they are loose and needs proper attention.

en.question: Which actions, if convicted, would disqualify you from driving a commercial motor vehicle (CMV)?

options.A: Using your personal vehicle to commit a felony crime.
options.B: Driving under the influence of alcohol (DUI) in your personal vehicle
options.C: Driving your personal vehicle over the speed limit

en.description: Any of these unsafe driving behaviors could disqualify you from driving a CMV.

en.question: What should you do during an inspection test if there are no electrical fuses in your vehicle?

options.A: Replace the fuses with spare parts from another vehicle.
options.B: Check with a mechanic before the test.
options.C: Tell the examiner that the vehicle is not equipped with electrical fuses so you are skipping this step.

en.description: If the vehicle lacks electrical fuses, inform the examiner and skip that step.

en.question: Which drink has the most alcohol in it?

options.A: A 12-ounce glass of 5% beer
options.B: A 1.5-ounce shot of 80-proof liquor
options.C: A 5-ounce glass of 12% wine
options.D: They have the same amount of alcohol.

en.description: All these drinks contain roughly the same amount of alcohol.

en.question: How can you best monitor the rear and sides of your vehicle while driving?

options.A: Adjust all mirrors for optimal view; monitor the sides and rear of the vehicle regularly.
options.B: Open the door and look behind while driving.
options.C: Install rear-view cameras and constantly watch the live feed.
options.D: Extend your head outside the window to get a better view of the back.

en.description: Adjust mirrors properly and check them often to monitor your vehicle's rear and sides.

en.question: When should you downshift?

options.A: Right before going down a hill and entering a curve
options.B: Right before parking on a slope.
options.C: Right before entering a highway and changing lanes.
options.D: Right before going in a tunnel and on a bridge.

en.description: Downshift before going downhill or around curves to help control your speed.

en.question: You should immediately refuse to drive a vehicle if it has _

options.A: Different brands of tires
options.B: Various tire sizes
options.C: Retreaded tires
options.D: Different tread patterns with the tires

en.description: Tires of different sizes can affect vehicle safety; refuse to drive in this condition.

en.question: What does an anti-lock brake system do?

options.A: It will help you speed up faster.
options.B: It will help shorten the stopping distance.
options.C: It will help you slow down faster.
options.D: It does not change the way normally you brake

en.description: ABS prevents wheels from locking during braking but does not change how you brake.

en.question: What does the term "Gross Vehicle Weight" or GVW mean?

options.A: The weight of the driver and any passengers only.
options.B: The amount of fuel the vehicle can carry.
options.C: The total weight of a single vehicle and its load

en.description: GVW is the total weight of the vehicle plus its cargo.

en.question: What are the hazards associated with crossing railroad tracks or dirt roads?

options.A: Your vehicle could be hit by lightning.
options.B: You could get stuck in the middle of the tracks.
options.C: Your mirrors could fall off.

en.description: Crossing tracks or dirt roads risks getting stuck, which is dangerous.

en.question: What part of the cargo should you secure to prevent it from moving when driving?

options.A: Only on the sides.
options.B: Only at the top.
options.C: Use blocking and bracing for front and back and side to side to get a balanced load.

en.description: Use blocking and bracing on all sides of the cargo for balance and security.

en.question: In which two scenarios could carrying the legal maximum weight be considered hazardous?

options.A: Driving in poor weather conditions or driving on mountain roads.
options.B: Driving during a sports event and driving past schools.
options.C: Driving with old tires and driving without headlights on
options.D: Driving while being hungry and driving in a hurry.

en.description: Driving with maximum weight can be dangerous during bad weather or on mountain roads.

en.question: Do loaded trucks stop more quickly than empty trucks?

options.A: With used tyres only
options.B: Yes
options.C: Yes, if the road surface is slippery

en.description: Loaded trucks have better traction, allowing for more controlled and quicker stops.

en.question: What is a hazard?

options.A: Something on the road that could be dangerous
options.B: Something insurance companies invented to charge more.
options.C: A sign that tells you where to go.

en.description: A hazard is anything on the road that could cause danger.

en.question: What is INCORRECT regarding escape ramps?

options.A: Signs along the way tell you where they are.
options.B: You cannot use them if you are going too fast.
options.C: They might be made of soft and loose gravel.

en.description: Escape ramps are designed to stop vehicles going too fast, so the statement is false.

en.question: Which task is not considered your duty while transporting cargo safely?

options.A: Inspecting the cargo
options.B: Ensuring cargo is not overloaded.
options.C: Ensuring the cargo is properly secured
options.D: Ensuring the freshness of sealed food products.

en.description: Ensuring food freshness is not part of your duty when transporting cargo.

en.question: What's the best way to check the sides and back of your vehicle?

options.A: Listen for unusual noises from the back.
options.B: Use your mirrors to monitor the back.
options.C: Rely on other drivers passing by to honk you for issues with your vehicle.
options.D: Extend your head outside the window to get a better view of the back.

en.description: Use your mirrors regularly to monitor your vehicle's sides and rear.

en.question: During a walk-around inspection of the vehicle's front, you should _.

options.A: Check to see if the lights are working properly.
options.B: Check to see if the windshield is damaged or not.
options.C: Check the steering system to make sure there are no loose or worn parts.

en.description: All these checks are important during a walk-around inspection.

en.question: How should you handle your vehicle when you're nearing a curve?

options.A: Keep your vehicle in neutral and coast through the curve.
options.B: Slow down and downshift into a lower gear before entering the curve; then accelerate slightly inside the curve.
options.C: Slow down in the curve and keep the brake half way pressed
options.D: Maintain the same speed throughout the curve.

en.description: Slow down and downshift before the curve, then accelerate slightly through it.

en.question: How can you tell if the load you're carrying includes hazardous materials?

options.A: The container has a diamond-shaped, four-inch label that says "hazardous materials."
options.B: A placard for hazardous items is present on the vehicle.
options.C: All of the above

en.description: Hazardous materials are indicated by specific labels and placards.

en.question: What should you NOT be monitoring while driving?

options.A: Pressure gauges
options.B: Cargo and cargo covers
options.C: Phone messages

en.description: Avoid checking phone messages while driving to stay focused and safe.

en.question: When driving a truck with two trailers, which shut-off valve do you have to close on the last trailer?

options.A: Back valve.
options.B: Side valve.
options.C: Front valve.

en.description: When driving a truck with two trailers, make sure to close the back valve on the last trailer. This helps keep the air pressure right so your brakes work properly.

en.question: After coupling the trailer with the truck, in what position should the truck protection control valve be set?

options.A: Left position
options.B: Normal position
options.C: Horizontal position

en.description: After hooking up a trailer to a truck, the valve that helps control the brakes should be set to the 'normal' position. This makes sure the brakes work right when needed.

en.question: When uncoupling the trailer, after you turn off the trailer air supply and make sure the trailer's brakes are set, you should:

options.A: Check the engine oil level.
options.B: Back up gently to ease pressure on the fifth wheel.
options.C: Check the trailer's tire pressure.

en.description: After turning off the trailer's air supply and making sure its brakes are locked, you should back up a little bit. This helps reduce pressure on the connection point (fifth wheel) between your truck and the trailer, making it easier to separate them.

en.question: After you hook up the air lines, but before you back up under the trailer, you should:

options.A: Disconnect the electrical line.
options.B: Check the tire pressure on the trailer.
options.C: Supply air to the trailer system, then pull out the air supply knob.

en.description: After you connect the air lines, before you move your truck under the trailer, you need to make sure the trailer's air system is working. Do this by sending air into the trailer's system and then pulling the knob that controls the air supply. This ensures the brakes and other systems are ready to safely operate.

en.question: The higher the center of gravity of your truck, the:

options.A: Less control over the brakes.
options.B: Harder to accelerate.
options.C: Easier to turn over.

en.description: When your truck's center of gravity is high, it means the truck is more likely to tip over, especially when turning. This doesn't really affect how the brakes work or how fast the truck can speed up.

en.question: Why is it necessary to put grease on the fifth wheel plate?

options.A: To improve fuel efficiency.
options.B: To prevent steering problems.
options.C: To enhance tire traction.

en.description: Greasing the fifth wheel plate is crucial because it helps prevent steering problems. Without proper lubrication, the friction between the tractor and the trailer can make steering harder and less smooth. This can lead to difficulties in controlling the vehicle, especially when turning.

en.question: Trailers with air brakes made before 1975:

options.A: Usually need a glad hand converter.
options.B: Are not required to have spring brakes.
options.C: Cannot be legally operated on interstate highways.

en.description: Trailers with air brakes made before 1975 are not required to have spring brakes. These older trailers may also lack modern ABS systems and often require manual brake adjustment. While still legal in many places, they operate under different safety requirements than newer models.

en.question: You're getting ready to reverse your truck under a semitrailer. The semitrailer is at the correct height when the:

options.A: Kingpin locks into place without any adjustment needed.
options.B: Fifth wheel is completely visible below the trailer.
options.C: Trailer will be lifted slightly when the tractor backs under it.

en.description: The semitrailer is at the correct height when the trailer is slightly raised as the tractor backs under it. This helps ensure a proper connection and reduces the risk of missing or damaging the fifth wheel locking mechanism.

en.question: When you're driving behind another car in good weather, make sure there's at least one second of space for every____feet of your vehicle's length.
en.description: When following another vehicle in good weather, you should allow at least one second of space for every 10 feet of your vehicle's length. This ensures you have enough time and distance to react and stop safely if necessary.

en.question: When operating a combination vehicle, the trailer unexpectedly disconnects, causing both air lines to separate. In addition to the trailer brakes coming on, you expect:

options.A: The trailer lights to go out.
options.B: The tractor protection valve to close.
options.C: The emergency brakes to release.

en.description: When the trailer disconnects and air lines separate, the tractor protection valve automatically closes to keep air in the truck's brakes, allowing you to maintain control of the vehicle.

en.question: For a coupling to be properly done, the safety latch on the fifth wheel locking lever must be

options.A: Over the locking lever
options.B: Beside the locking lever
options.C: In front of the locking lever

en.description: The correct way to secure the fifth wheel locking lever is for the safety latch to be positioned over the locking lever to ensure proper coupling.

en.question: A truck pulling a ___ trailer needs the longest distance to stop.

options.A: Heavy
options.B: Empty
options.C: Slightly damaged

en.description: An empty trailer requires more stopping distance because it lacks the weight that provides traction during braking. This results in a longer stopping distance compared to a heavy trailer.

en.question: What is correct out of the following?

options.A: Brakes work more effectively when the vehicle is empty.
options.B: Braking efficiency increases as vehicle weight decreases.
options.C: Bobtail tractors can take longer to stop than a combination vehicle loaded to maximum gross weight.

en.description: Bobtail tractors without a trailer can take longer to stop compared to a combination vehicle fully loaded. This is because the weight of the trailer helps push the brakes down more effectively, improving stopping power.

en.question: What is the proper position for the fifth wheel when coupling with a trailer?

options.A: Slanted sideways towards the driver's side
options.B: Above the roof of the truck
options.C: Tilted down toward the end of the trailer.

en.description: When connecting the trailer to the truck, the fifth wheel (the part that connects them) should be tilted down towards the end of the trailer. This position helps hook up the trailer securely.

en.question: For a combination vehicle that uses air brakes, when the engine is off and the brakes are off, the air brake leakage rate should not be more than _ psi every minute.
en.description: When checking if the air brakes on a big truck and trailer are leaking too much (with the engine off and not using the brakes), it's okay if the air pressure drops a little, but not more than 3 pounds per square inch (psi) every minute.

en.question: How can you stop a trailer from skidding?

options.A: Apply the brakes
options.B: Release the brakes.
options.C: Tap the brakes lightly.

en.description: If your trailer starts to skid, quickly let go of the brakes. This helps your wheels start rolling again and gets the trailer back under control.

en.question: If you are not pulling a trailer, why should you lock the truck gladhands together (or use dummy couplers)?

options.A: It helps balance the air pressure between the tractor and trailer.
options.B: To make it easier to attach to a trailer later.
options.C: It will keep dirt or water out of the lines.

en.description: When you're not pulling a trailer, connecting the glad hands together or to dummy couplers helps keep dirt and water out of the air lines. This keeps the lines clean and ready for when you need to hook up to a trailer again.

en.question: When testing a combination vehicle, with the engine turned off and the brakes applied, the air shouldn't leak out faster than___ psi every minute.
en.description: For a big vehicle with multiple parts, like a truck pulling a trailer, when it's not running and the brakes are applied, the air pressure in the brakes shouldn't drop more than 4 psi in a minute. This ensures the brakes stay strong and can stop the vehicle safely.

en.question: There are two ways a driver can stop a truck from rolling over. They are: (1) put the load as low as possible and (2):

options.A: Go slow around turns.
options.B: Drive with windows open.
options.C: Keep both hands firmly on the steering wheel.

en.description: To stop a truck from tipping over, do two things: 1) Load stuff low down to keep it stable. 2) Take corners slowly. This way, the truck is more balanced and less likely to fall over.

en.question: Where should the truck be when you uncouple the trailer and inspect the landing gear?

options.A: With the tractor frame under the trailer.
options.B: Next to the trailer, but not aligned with it.
options.C: Parked at a 45-degree angle to the trailer.

en.description: After you disconnect the trailer, park your truck straight under the trailer, not to the side or at an angle. This way, you're in the right spot to check the landing gear safely and properly.

en.question: While driving a combination vehicle, the service line disconnects, but the emergency line remains connected. What will happen immediately?

options.A: The vehicle's speed will automatically increase.
options.B: Nothing is likely to happen until you try to apply the brakes.
options.C: The steering will lock up.

en.description: If the service line comes off but the emergency line is still connected, nothing major will happen right away. But, when you try to use the brakes, you'll notice the problem.

en.question: In what position should you set the truck's safety control valve when testing the emergency brakes on a trailer?

options.A: Parked
options.B: Emergency
options.C: Drive mode

en.description: When checking the emergency brakes on a trailer, you should set the truck protection control valve to the 'Emergency' position to ensure proper brake function.

en.question: When making sure the trailer is properly coupled to the truck, the landing gears should be:

options.A: Slightly raised.
options.B: Fully raised.
options.C: Touching the ground lightly

en.description: Landing gears should be slightly raised to confirm the trailer is properly and securely connected to the truck.

en.question: When uncoupling a full trailer, you should lower the landing gear until it:

options.A: Make firm contact with the ground, turn crank in low gear a few extra turns.
options.B: Reaches the ground.
options.C: Make contact with the ground and leave the trailer off the fifth wheel.

en.description: Lower the landing gear so it firmly touches the ground and crank a few more turns in low gear to ensure trailer stability.

en.question: It is common for combination vehicles to have colored air lines to prevent the lines from getting mixed up. The emergency line is __, the service line is__

options.A: Red, blue
options.B: Green, purple
options.C: Yellow, green

en.description: Emergency air lines are red and service air lines are blue to help distinguish them during connection.

en.question: If the emergency air line in your vehicle breaks or comes apart while driving, this will make the:

options.A: Air pressure gauge to increase rapidly.
options.B: Emergency trailer brakes to come on.
options.C: Air tank to refill automatically.

en.description: If the emergency line breaks, it triggers the emergency brakes on the trailer to stop safely.

en.question: When the iron trailer supports are up and the trailer sits on the truck, make sure that ___

options.A: There is enough clearance between the truck frame and the landing gear.
options.B: The air supply to the trailer is disconnected.
options.C: The trailer tires are inflated to their maximum capacity.

en.description: You must have enough clearance between the truck and the landing gear to prevent damage.

en.question: Air and electrical lines from the truck to the trailer should be:

options.A: Attached with a short chain
options.B: Secured but with enough loop to turn.
options.C: Hanging loosely near the road surface

en.description: The lines should be secured but with enough slack to allow turns without disconnecting or dragging.

en.question: What happens if you cross the air lines when hooking up to an old trailer?

options.A: The trailer will automatically disconnect from the tractor.
options.B: If the trailer has no spring brakes, you could drive away but you would not have trailer brakes.
options.C: The trailer wheels will lock up immediately when connected.

en.description: Crossing air lines on an older trailer without spring brakes can result in the trailer having no braking ability.

en.question: How can you check if the connection between the truck and the semitrailer is safe and secure?

options.A: Drive in a circle and listen for unusual noises.
options.B: Pull gently forward in low gear against the locked trailer brakes then look at it carefully.
options.C: Tap the side of the trailer with a hammer to check for sound changes.

en.description: Gently pull forward with the brakes locked, then visually inspect the connection to confirm it's secure.

en.question: What are the potential consequences when a driver mixes up the air hose connections when connecting to an old trailer?

options.A: The ABS system will fail to activate when needed.
options.B: If the trailer has no spring brakes, you could drive away but you would not have trailer brakes.
options.C: The trailer might automatically detach while driving.

en.description: Mixing up air hoses on older trailers without spring brakes could mean no trailer braking — a major safety risk.

en.question: Which of these vehicles will follow the wider path while turning because of off-tracking?

options.A: Tractor with two 27-feet trailers.
options.B: Tractor towing a 45-feet trailer.
options.C: 53-feet bobtail.

en.description: A tractor with two shorter trailers will experience more off-tracking, taking a wider turn path than longer single units.

en.question: After connecting with a semitrailer, where should you place the iron trailer supports before you start driving?

options.A: Hanging loosely without securing the crank handle
options.B: Lowered completely touching the ground
options.C: Fully raised with the crank handle secured in its bracket.

en.description: Iron trailer supports should be fully raised and the crank handle secured to prevent them from dropping or swinging while driving.

en.question: The hand valve should be used:

options.A: To change the radio station.
options.B: To adjust the side mirrors.
options.C: To test the trailer brakes.

en.description: The hand valve is used to test trailer brakes, not for adjusting mirrors or radios.

en.question: A major leak has occurred in the service line, so you put the brakes on. The service air will escape and cause:

options.A: Transmission to fail
options.B: Trailer emergency brakes to come on.
options.C: Engine to overheat

en.description: If there's a major leak in the service line, the service air escapes and causes the emergency trailer brakes to activate.

en.question: What do glad hands usually connect?

options.A: Transmission cables for gear shifting
options.B: Hydraulic fluid lines for brake cooling.
options.C: Service and emergency air lines from the vehicle to the trailer.

en.description: Glad hands are used to connect the service and emergency air lines between the truck and trailer to control the trailer's brakes.

en.question: When you have supplied air to the trailer, you should check that the air lines are not crossed and that the brakes are functioning. You can do this by:

options.A: Checking the radio for static changes.
options.B: Flipping the light switches inside the cab.
options.C: Applying and releasing the trailer brakes and listening for the sound of the brake.

en.description: After supplying air to the trailer, apply and release the trailer brakes and listen for the sound. This confirms the lines are correctly connected and the brakes function.

en.question: How much room should there be between the top and bottom parts of the fifth wheel after coupling?

options.A: 2 inches
options.B: 1/2 inch
options.C: None.
