en.description: There should be no space between the top and bottom of the fifth wheel after coupling. Any gap may indicate an improper or unsafe connection.

en.question: To unlock the fifth wheel, you need to move the locking lever to the ___ position.

options.A: Horizontal
options.B: Open
options.C: Locked

en.description: To release the trailer from the truck, move the fifth wheel locking lever to the 'Open' position.

en.question: To prevent a rollover, a driver can do two things: 1) Drive slowly when turning, and 2)

options.A: Keep the cargo as close to the ground as possible.
options.B: Drive in the middle of the road
options.C: Fill the fuel tank to the top before turning.

en.description: Prevent rollovers by slowing down in turns and keeping your load low to maintain a stable center of gravity.

en.question: You are coupling a truck to the semitrailer and have connected the air lines. Before reversing under the trailer, what should you do?

options.A: Check the tire pressure on the truck.
options.B: Supply air to the trailer system, then pull out the air supply knob.
options.C: Raise the landing gear completely.

en.description: Before backing under the trailer, supply air to the trailer and pull the air supply knob to ensure the brakes are functioning properly.

en.question: When you're preparing to reverse and go under a semitrailer, you should line up:

options.A: Align the truck's headlights with the trailer's tail lights.
options.B: Directly in front of the trailer.
options.C: About a truck-length away from the trailer.

en.description: To safely back under a semitrailer, line up the truck directly in front of the trailer for proper alignment.

en.question: When backing a truck under a trailer you should:

options.A: Use a spotter who signals you from the driver's side mirror.
options.B: Make sure your radio is turned up loud to hear the trailer better.
options.C: Always use the lowest reverse gear.

en.description: Always use the lowest reverse gear to move slowly and safely when backing under a trailer.

en.question: At what angle should the seals with the couplers be pressed together when connecting the glad hands?

options.A: 120 degrees
options.B: 90 degrees.
options.C: 75 degrees

en.description: Glad hands should be connected at a 90-degree angle to ensure a secure and sealed air connection.

en.question: To prevent a truck from rolling over, a driver needs to do two things: 1) drive slowly when turning, and 2)

options.A: Keep the cargo as close to the ground as possible.
options.B: Drive with the windows open to reduce air resistance.
options.C: Load the vehicle to its maximum capacity.

en.description: Driving slowly during turns and keeping cargo low helps maintain balance and prevent rollovers.

en.question: When the front trailer supports are up and the trailer rests on the truck, make sure:

options.A: There is enough clearance between the tractor frame and the landing gear.
options.B: There is enough clearance between the top of the tractor tires and nose of the trailer.
options.C: Both options are correct.

en.description: You must ensure both clearances—between the tractor frame and landing gear, and between the top of the tractor tires and trailer nose—are sufficient to avoid damage.

en.question: The truck protection valve will shut off, and the emergency brakes on the trailer will activate if there's a big leak in the _ brake line.

options.A: Cooling
options.B: Emergency
options.C: Fuel

en.description: If there's a major leak in the emergency brake line, the truck protection valve shuts off and activates the trailer’s emergency brakes.

en.question: How do you know if the test for the truck protection valve worked right?

options.A: The air tanks will rapidly fill up when the valve is tested.
options.B: The truck protection valve control will pop out or go from normal to emergency.
options.C: The headlights will flash on and off.

en.description: To verify the truck protection valve test, the control should pop out or switch from normal to emergency mode.

en.question: When you're checking your truck during the walk-around, make sure the electric and air hoses are:

options.A: Hung over the side mirror.
options.B: Wrapped around the axle
options.C: Secure, yet with enough slack for turns

en.description: The electric and air hoses must be secure and have enough slack to allow for proper turning movement.

en.question: Which of these vehicles will off-track more?

options.A: A 5-axle tractor that pulls a 48-foot trailer.
options.B: A 5-axle tractor towing a 45-foot trailer.
options.C: A 5-axle tractor towing a 52-foot trailer.

en.description: Longer trailers off-track more when turning, so the 52-foot trailer will off-track the most.

en.question: When coupling a truck-semitrailer, which of the following is NOT part of the inspection of the fifth wheel?

options.A: Checking the trailer wheels are chocked
options.B: Checking the engine oil level.
options.C: Inspecting the tire pressure on the tractor

en.description: Chocking trailer wheels is important for safety but not specifically part of the fifth wheel inspection during coupling.

en.question: When pulling doubles or triples, the shut-off valves must always be __, except for _

options.A: Open, the final trailer.
options.B: Open, the second trailer
options.C: Closed, the second trailer

en.description: When operating doubles or triples, all shut-off valves should be open except at the rear of the last trailer.

en.question: How can you check if the trailer's service brakes are working properly?

options.A: Drive in reverse, then apply the foot brake forcefully to check stability.
options.B: Push the brake pedal after disconnecting the trailer to test brake lights.
options.C: First move forward slightly and then stop with the handbrake.

en.description: To test the service brakes, pull forward slightly and apply the trailer handbrake to confirm braking action.

en.question: How can you test the security of a truck-semitrailer connection?

options.A: Pull gently forward in low gear against the locked trailer brakes; then look at it
options.B: Put the tractor in gear and pull ahead with a sharp jerk.
options.C: Drive slowly in a circle to see if the trailer follows correctly.

en.description: To check the connection, gently pull against the locked trailer brakes and inspect the connection.

en.question: What makes a truck more likely to roll over?

options.A: Keeping the cargo unsecured
options.B: Driving slowly around curves
options.C: Driving quickly around curves

en.description: Taking curves too fast increases the risk of rollover due to the shift in the truck’s center of gravity.

en.question: How can you check if air is reaching all the brakes on the trailers?

options.A: Check the tire pressure on each trailer.
options.B: Listen for a whistle from the trailer's undercarriage.
options.C: Open the emergency line shut-off valve at the last trailer and listen for air escaping. Then open the service line valve and listen, for air escaping.

en.description: By opening the emergency and service line valves at the last trailer and listening for air, you can confirm airflow to all brakes.

en.question: When you reverse a truck under a trailer, it is expected that___

options.A: When the truck backs up under the trailer, it will lift up a little bit.
options.B: The trailer will automatically disconnect from the truck
options.C: The trailer tires will inflate by themselves.

en.description: When backing under a trailer, the trailer should raise slightly as it settles onto the fifth wheel.

en.question: What does the term "truck jackknife" mean?

options.A: When the trailer detaches from the truck during high-speed maneuvering.
options.B: When the drive wheels on the truck are locked, causing the truck to skid to the side while the trailer continues to move straight.
options.C: When the truck and trailer both move in opposite directions due to braking failure.

en.description: A jackknife happens when a truck's drive wheels lock and the truck skids while the trailer keeps moving straight.

en.question: Which of the following statements is FALSE about the anti-lock braking system?

options.A: It decreases your braking ability.
options.B: It works in any weather conditions.
options.C: It requires regular manual adjustments.
options.D: Since March 1998, all air-brake vehicles must feature ABS

en.description: ABS does not reduce braking ability; it helps prevent wheel lockup during emergency stops.

en.question: Trucks made after 1975 must have__

options.A: Spring brakes
options.B: Disc brakes
options.C: Hydraulic steering systems

en.description: Federal rules require that trucks built after 1975 be equipped with spring brakes for safety.

en.question: What should you check when performing the walk around inspection of a combination vehicle?

options.A: Check the kingpin to determine if it is damaged or not.
options.B: Check the landing gear is fully raised.
options.C: Check all of the locking pins are present and locked in place.

en.description: All of these items should be checked during a walk-around inspection of a combination vehicle.

en.question: How can you determine if your vehicle has an anti-lock braking system (ABS)?

options.A: Check the color of the brake pads for a specific color indicating ABS.
options.B: Listen for a specific ABS sound when starting the vehicle.
options.C: Look under the vehicle for the electronic control unit and wheel speed sensor wires connected to the back of the brakes.

en.description: To check for ABS, look under the vehicle for an electronic control unit and sensor wires connected to the brakes.

en.question: Which one is NOT a part of checking the fifth wheel?

options.A: Taking a look at the area around the vehicle
options.B: Inspecting the engine oil level
options.C: Making sure all the lights work
options.D: Verifying the fifth wheel's readiness for attachment

en.description: Looking around the vehicle isn't specific to the fifth wheel inspection, which focuses on coupling readiness and condition.

en.question: Before you uncouple a trailer, what is the first thing you should do?

options.A: Ensure the trailer is not moving.
options.B: Check if the ground is stable enough to support the trailer's weight.
options.C: Make sure the air pressure is low.

en.description: Before uncoupling a trailer, ensure the ground is strong and stable to prevent sinking or tipping.

en.question: What might happen if you fail to check your brakes for air leaks before driving?

options.A: The vehicle's fuel efficiency may improve.
options.B: Your tires may wear out faster.
options.C: The brakes could fail while driving due to significant air loss.

en.description: Air brake systems must be checked for leaks; otherwise, air loss could cause brake failure during driving.

en.question: Jackknifing happens more often when pulling a trailer that is__.

options.A: Loaded to full capacity
options.B: Loaded halfway.
options.C: Lightly loaded

en.description: Jackknifing is more common with empty trailers due to reduced traction and stability.

en.question: Nearly half of all truck driver fatalities result from which type of collision?

options.A: Lane changing
options.B: Rollovers.
options.C: Texting while driving

en.description: Rollovers cause nearly 50% of truck driver deaths due to the truck tipping over during turns or evasive actions.

en.question: What is one of the steps to make sure the truck is safe and secure?

options.A: Pull the parking brake and shift the transmission into neutral.
options.B: Adjust the rearview mirror to see better.
options.C: Turn off the truck's headlights.

en.description: Securing the truck includes engaging the parking brake and shifting to neutral to prevent movement.

en.question: Which statement is correct about the trailer air supply control?

options.A: It is used to get air into the trailer, shut off the air, and turn on the emergency brakes on the trailer.
options.B: It regulates the temperature inside the trailer for sensitive cargo.
options.C: It enables automatic adjustment of the trailer's suspension height.

en.description: The trailer air supply control manages air to the trailer brakes, including emergency functions.

en.question: When checking the coupling, you do NOT have to _

options.A: Inspect tire pressure on the trailer
options.B: Verify the connection by driving the vehicle.
options.C: Ensure the headlights are functioning properly.
options.D: Make sure the locking lever is in the lock position.

en.description: You don’t need to drive the vehicle to confirm the coupling; visual and manual inspections are sufficient.

en.question: What does the service line, control line, or signal line do?

options.A: Transfers hydraulic fluid to the trailer's brake system.
options.B: Delivers air to a relay valve that enables the trailer brakes to be promptly engaged.
options.C: Controls the trailer's audio system.

en.description: The service line sends air to a relay valve so the trailer's brakes engage quickly when needed.

en.question: What might go wrong if you try to couple a trailer that's set too high?

options.A: The trailer might not be properly coupled to the fifth wheel.
options.B: The fifth wheel could get damaged.
options.C: The kingpin might not align with the fifth wheel.

en.description: If the trailer is too high, it may not properly couple to the fifth wheel, causing an unsafe connection.

en.question: A truck that is full has a __ bigger chance of rolling over during a crash than an empty truck.

options.A: 2 times
options.B: 8 times
options.C: 6 times

en.description: A fully loaded truck is 10 times more likely to roll over in a crash than an empty one.

en.question: When you park a trailer that doesn't have spring brakes, it's a good idea to use chocks because _

options.A: Using chocks makes it easier to reconnect later.
options.B: The brakes will not function if the air supply leaks.
options.C: They make it easier to level the trailer.

en.description: If the trailer has no spring brakes and air leaks, chocks prevent it from moving unintentionally.

en.question: Which trailer is more likely to roll over when you quickly turn while pulling two trailers?

options.A: The final trailer is twice as likely as the tractor to flip over.
options.B: The front trailer is twice as likely as the tractor to flip over.
options.C: All trailers have the same chance of tipping over as the tractor.

en.description: The rear trailer is the most likely to roll over due to the whip effect in sudden turns.

en.question: What can you use to control the air in the service line?

options.A: Hand brake of the trailer
options.B: Brake pedal
options.C: Both the hand brake and brake pedal

en.description: Both the hand brake and the foot brake can control air sent to the service line.

en.question: Should you use the trailer's hand brake to straighten out a jackknifing trailer?

options.A: Yes, it's essential to adjust your speed using the trailer hand brake for better control.
options.B: No, since the skidding was caused by the trailer's brakes.
options.C: No, only if the trailer is empty and light.
options.D: Yes, the trailer hand brake will lock the wheels and slow down the skid.

en.description: You should not use the trailer hand brake during jackknifing since it's often caused by brake overuse.

en.question: What can you do to stop a combination vehicle from rolling over?

options.A: Place the heavy cargo beneath the lightest ones to help keep center of gravity low and drive slowly around turns.
options.B: Keep the heaviest cargo at the rear end of the trailer and accelerate quickly after turns.
options.C: Spread the load evenly across all axles and make turns at high speed.
options.D: Place the lightest load on the bottom first so that the center of gravity is lower and drive slowly through the curves.

en.description: Keeping a low center of gravity and taking turns slowly helps prevent rollovers in combination vehicles.

en.question: To check if the truck protection valve works, fill up the trailer air brake system with air, turn off the engine, and then__

options.A: Engage the cruise control.
options.B: Pump the brake pedal several times.
options.C: Activate the windshield wipers.
options.D: Engage the trailer hand valve fully and hold it in place to check for leaks.

en.description: Pump the brake pedal after filling the system and shutting off the engine to test the protection valve.

en.question: What should you do to back up into a curve to the driver's side?

options.A: Use all your side mirrors
options.B: Back your vehicle slowly
options.C: Examine your path of backing up and the surrounding of the vehicle

en.description: Backing into a curve on the driver’s side requires full awareness: use mirrors, go slow, and assess the path.

en.question: If a vehicle's load sticks out four feet or more beyond the rear trailer at night, the load must have __ at the end.

options.A: Two red lights.
options.B: Flashing yellow lights
options.C: A red flag

en.description: If a load extends 4 feet or more from the rear of the trailer at night, two red lights must be mounted at the end for visibility and safety.

en.question: Compared with a regular five-axle truck-trailer, the final trailer of a triple is__ more likely to roll over.

options.A: 6 times
options.B: 3.5 times
options.C: 7 times

en.description: The last trailer in a triple trailer setup is 3.5 times more likely to roll over compared to a standard five-axle truck-trailer.

en.question: How should you reverse a trailer?

options.A: Make sure to use all of your side mirrors
options.B: Back the vehicle in a slow and careful manner.
options.C: Walk all the way around your vehicle to thoroughly inspect the path you will be taking.

en.description: To reverse a trailer safely, use mirrors, go slowly, and check your entire path before backing.

en.question: When doing the walk-around inspection, which of these things is NOT something you check when looking at the sliding fifth wheel?

options.A: Ensure that the crank handle is securely fastened.
options.B: Checking the tire pressure of the truck
options.C: Checking the engine oil level
options.D: Ensuring that the sliding fifth wheel is not pushed too far forward

en.description: The crank handle fastening is not part of the sliding fifth wheel check. It's more important to check wheel position and locking mechanisms.

en.question: What is NOT the right way to determine if the trailer has ABS?

options.A: Look for the ABS indicator light on the left rear of the trailer. If the trailer has ABS, this light should turn on when the ignition is powered and then turn off.
options.B: Check for an ABS electronic control unit (ECU) and wheel speed sensors on the axles.
options.C: A cartoon sticker on the door jamb that says "ABS"
options.D: Look for documentation indicating ABS is present.

en.description: A cartoon sticker is not a valid or reliable way to confirm the presence of ABS on a trailer.

en.question: Among the functions of an emergency air line is__

options.A: To cool down the engine during long drives.
options.B: To turn on the trailer brakes when there is loss of air pressure
options.C: To adjust the radio volume automatically.

en.description: The emergency air line activates the trailer brakes if there’s a drop in air pressure, helping stop the vehicle safely.

en.question: The following distance for a 70-foot combination vehicle driving at 50 mph is ___

options.A: 6 seconds
options.B: 11 seconds
options.C: 8 seconds

en.description: For a 70-foot truck at 50 mph, maintain at least 8 seconds of following distance to allow enough time to react.

en.question: Which of these is more likely to off-track?

options.A: Properly maintained vehicles do not off-track.
options.B: The truck without any trailers attached.
options.C: A vehicle with anti-lock brakes installed.
options.D: The rearmost trailer of a double combination vehicle.

en.description: In a double trailer, the last trailer is more likely to swing wide or off-track, especially when turning.

en.question: Why do we connect the glad hands to a vehicle that has "dead-end" couplers?

options.A: To improve the grip between the truck and trailer connections.
options.B: To make the brakes respond faster.
options.C: It will keep dirt and water out of the lines.

en.description: Connecting glad hands on a vehicle with dead-end couplers helps seal the system and keeps contaminants out.

en.question: How can you avoid your truck's landing gear getting stuck on railroad tracks or other stuff on the road?

options.A: Raise it up completely
options.B: Tilt it slightly forward.
options.C: Lower it just before crossing.
options.D: The rule of thumb is 4 feet off the ground

en.description: To prevent the landing gear from catching on obstacles like train tracks, make sure it’s fully raised before moving.

en.question: If your vehicle breaks down on a railway crossing, what should you do?

options.A: Wait for the train to pass before doing anything.
options.B: Evacuate the vehicle quickly to a safe location and then call 911.
options.C: Try to push the vehicle off the tracks by yourself.
options.D: Wave at the incoming train to stop it from crashing into your vehicle.

en.description: If your vehicle is stuck on train tracks, get out quickly and move to safety. Then call 911 to report the emergency.

en.question: To stop the cargo from tipping over, the driver should keep the load very low to the ground and__

options.A: Keep the truck windows open.
options.B: Drive with high beams on at all times.
options.C: Go slowly around turns.
options.D: Raise the landing gear all the way

en.description: Keeping the load low and taking turns slowly helps prevent the cargo from tipping over.

en.question: Trying to fix a jackknifing trailer by using the trailer hand brake won't help. Why is this method not effective?

options.A: The trailer hand brake has failed.
options.B: The trailer doesn't have a hand brake.
options.C: The hand brake wire is disconnected.
options.D: The trailer is skidding because of the wheel brakes.

en.description: Using the trailer hand brake can lock the wheels, worsening the skid. That’s why it won’t stop a jackknife.

en.question: What is the least likely to roll over?

options.A: On-ramps.
options.B: Mountain roads
options.C: Straight segments of highway.

en.description: Straight highways are the least risky for rollovers compared to curved or uneven roads.

en.question: Which one of these statements is correct?

options.A: The foot brake distributes air to all brakes (including trailers).
options.B: Use trailer hand valve to test the trailer brakes only
options.C: Both of these statements are true.

en.description: Both the foot brake controls all brakes and the hand valve is used to test trailer brakes only.

en.question: Truck protection valve closes automatically if air pressure drops to a certain level. What is that level?

options.A: 20 to 45 psi
options.B: 130 to 150 psi
options.C: 60 to 80 psi

en.description: If the air pressure drops between 20 to 45 psi, the truck protection valve shuts to help keep the system safe.

en.question: Which of the following does NOT help stop a trailer from skidding?

options.A: Seeing the skid coming
options.B: Let the foot off the brake
options.C: Not using the hand brake

en.description: Using the hand brake during a skid can worsen it and should be avoided.

en.question: After you have unlocked the fifth wheel, what should you do next?

options.A: Pull the vehicle backwards.
options.B: Move the tractor forward until it is partly free of the trailer
options.C: Activate your hazard lights

en.description: After unlocking the fifth wheel, move forward slightly to partially disengage from the trailer.

en.question: What does the term "off-tracking" mean?

options.A: The back wheels travel in a turn differently than the front wheels
options.B: The vehicle stopping quicker than usual due to heavy cargo.
options.C: The vehicle's radio losing signal during sharp turns.
options.D: Not tracking your sleep hours when driving interstate trips.

en.description: Off-tracking is when the rear wheels follow a different path than the front wheels during a turn.

en.question: __of a double or triple vehicle have a higher tendency to go off-track.

options.A: The middle wheels of the second trailer.
options.B: The side wheels of the first trailer.
options.C: The rear wheels of the final trailer
options.D: The front wheels of the final trailer.

en.description: The rear wheels of the last trailer in multi-trailer setups are most prone to going off-track.

en.question: If the fifth wheel locking lever isn't locked after the jaws close around the kingpin, it means:

options.A: The coupling is not right and should be fixed before driving the coupled unit
options.B: The air pressure is too high for coupling.
options.C: The vehicle's brakes are automatically applied.

en.description: If the locking lever doesn’t lock, the connection isn’t safe. You need to fix the coupling before driving.

en.question: Semi-trailers with air brakes built before 1975:

options.A: They are usually fitted with spring brakes as a standard safety feature.
options.B: Often do not have spring brakes.
options.C: They commonly include anti-lock braking systems (ABS) for improved stability.

en.description: Older semi-trailers built before 1975 often don’t have spring brakes, unlike modern ones.

en.question: After uncoupling the trailer, you should inspect the trailer supports. What gear should the truck engine be in during this inspection?

options.A: Low forward
options.B: Neutral.
options.C: High forward

en.description: When inspecting trailer supports after uncoupling, the truck should be in neutral to prevent movement and ensure safety.

en.question: When is it appropriate to park a combination vehicle with the hand valve?

options.A: To park on a grade.
options.B: To park at loading docks.
options.C: Never.

en.description: You should never use the hand valve to park a combination vehicle. It's not safe because it can cause the trailer brakes to wear out unevenly. Always use the parking brakes when you need to park.

en.question: You supply air to the trailer tanks by:

options.A: Flipping the dashboard switch.
options.B: Turning the ignition key to the accessory position.
options.C: Pushing in the trailer air supply valve.

en.description: To provide air to trailer tanks, you press the trailer air supply valve. This valve, often found on the dashboard, sends air from the truck to the trailer to make sure the brakes work properly.

en.question: Before you back under a trailer, make sure that:

options.A: The track protection valve is normal.
options.B: The trailer brakes are locked.
options.C: The air supply knob is in.

en.description: Before you reverse under a trailer, you need to make sure that the trailer brakes are locked. This prevents the trailer from moving while backing up.

en.question: What components should you connect before reversing under the semitrailer while coupling a truck to it?

options.A: The emergency and service air lines.
options.B: Connect the water hose.
options.C: Attach the trailer registration document.

en.description: Before backing the truck under the semitrailer, you should connect the emergency and service air lines.

en.question: Once you've secured the kingpin into the fifth wheel, what is the proper method for verifying the connection?

options.A: Driving in reverse for 10 feet and then stopping quickly
options.B: Pulling the tractor ahead gently with the trailer brakes locked.
options.C: Visually inspecting without applying any force.

en.description: The correct way to check the kingpin connection is to gently pull forward with the trailer brakes locked, ensuring a secure connection.

en.question: After you press the trailer air supply valve, you shouldn't back the truck under a trailer until the entire air system is:

options.A: At normal pressure.
options.B: Empty.
options.C: Below 20 psi

en.description: Before hooking a truck to a trailer, make sure the air pressure in the system is normal so brakes and other air systems function properly.

en.question: The locking jaws should close around____ the kingpin.

options.A: The neck
options.B: The tip
options.C: The shank.

en.description: The locking jaw should close around the shank of the kingpin to ensure a secure connection between the trailer and the tractor.

en.question: If you realize that you can't make your turn without moving into a different lane on the road, you should:

options.A: Stop in the middle of the turn and wait for traffic to clear.
options.B: Make the turn quickly to avoid traffic.
options.C: Turn wide as you complete the turn.

en.description: If you can't stay in your lane while turning, make a wide turn as you complete the maneuver. Don’t stop or rush.

en.question: When driving, some drivers pull the hand brake before stepping on the foot brake to avoid the jack-knife. Which of these statements is correct?

options.A: It should not be done.
options.B: It is a safe maneuver to help stabilize the truck during emergency stops.
options.C: It is a technique that enhances control by reducing the risk of wheel lock-up.

en.description: Using the hand brake first can cause trailer wheels to lock and lead to a skid or jackknife. It should not be done except in emergencies.

en.question: Combination vehicles require __ things to check than regular trucks or buses.

options.A: More
options.B: The same number
options.C: Fewer

en.description: Combination vehicles like tractor-trailers have more parts and systems, so they require more checks than a regular truck or bus.

en.question: Once the trailer is coupled, you should elevate the landing gear by engaging -

options.A: Fast gear
options.B: Medium gear
options.C: Low gear.

en.description: After hooking up the trailer, lift the landing gear using the low gear. It's slower but gives you more control to avoid damage.

en.question: A truck with a/an ______ trailer needs the least distance to come to a stop.

options.A: Fully loaded
options.B: Empty
options.C: Half-loaded

en.description: A fully loaded trailer is heavier and provides better traction, which can help the truck stop more effectively compared to an empty one.

en.question: If pushing the trailer air supply valve doesn't release the spring brakes, you should:

options.A: Adjust the mirrors
options.B: Check air line connection.
options.C: Check the tire pressure.

en.description: If the spring brakes don’t release, check the air line connections to ensure proper airflow between the tractor and trailer.

en.question: The risk of a truck-trailer combination rolling over during a turn is highest when the combination involves -

options.A: A 48 ft. trailer.
options.B: Triple 27 ft. trailers.
options.C: A single 53 ft. trailer.

en.description: A truck with three 27-foot trailers is the most likely to roll over during a turn due to its increased instability.

en.question: If only your trailer has antilock brakes, it __

options.A: Will give you more control over the vehicle when braking.
options.B: Decreases your braking distance significantly.
options.C: Reduces the effectiveness of your vehicle's overall braking system.

en.description: Having ABS only on the trailer improves control during braking, even though it doesn't shorten braking distance.

en.question: When a trailer is ___, it is at the highest risk of jackknifing.

options.A: Fully loaded with solid goods
options.B: Half loaded with liquid.
options.C: Empty

en.description: An empty trailer has less weight to provide traction, making it more prone to jackknifing in slippery or sudden braking conditions.

en.question: When parking a trailer, when is it necessary to use chocks?

options.A: Only when the trailer is fully loaded.
options.B: Always.
options.C: Only when the parking brake is not working.

en.description: You should always use chocks when parking a trailer to prevent it from rolling away.

en.question: When are you allowed to get out of your vehicle while backing?

options.A: When you are unsure of your path of travel.
options.B: When you have a clear, unobstructed view of your surroundings.
options.C: When you need to adjust your radio.

en.description: If you’re unsure of your path while backing, get out and check to avoid hitting obstacles.

en.question: What should you do if the antilock braking system on your trailer is not functioning?

options.A: Ignore the breakdown as it does not affect the overall functionality of the vehicle.
options.B: Not drive until it is repaired.
options.C: Drive normally, but get the system serviced soon.

en.description: If your trailer's ABS isn’t working, you can drive normally but need to get it repaired as soon as possible.

en.question: The indication that the trailer ABS brakes are malfunctioning is when __.

options.A: Yellow ABS malfunction lamps on the left side of the trailer stays ON.
options.B: Green ABS indicator lights on the trailer's front panel blink rapidly.
options.C: Blue warning lights on the trailer's rear door stay lit

en.description: If the ABS system isn't working properly, the yellow ABS warning light on the left side of the trailer will remain lit.

en.question: To make a turn safely without entering another traffic lane _

options.A: You should make the turn as quickly as possible to avoid other vehicles.
options.B: You should turn wide as you complete the turn.
options.C: You should make the turn slowly to watch for other vehicles.

en.description: To turn safely without crossing into another lane, you need to turn wide as you complete the turn. This helps you stay in control and avoid accidents.

en.question: What is the first thing you need to do after colliding with another vehicle?

options.A: Check underneath the vehicles for any leaks.
options.B: Turn on your four-way flashers.
options.C: Call a friend to come and help you.

en.description: After a crash, the first step is to turn on your hazard lights (four-way flashers) to alert other drivers and prevent further accidents.

en.question: The trailer air supply control valve is designed to close automatically when the air pressure drops to a range of _ psi.

options.A: 20 and 45
options.B: 30 and 70
options.C: 45 and 90

en.description: The trailer air supply control valve shuts off automatically if the air pressure drops between 20 and 45 psi, helping to prevent brake failure.

en.question: You can determine if the trailer you are driving is equipped with antilock brakes by checking for __

options.A: Yellow ABS malfunction lamps on the left side of the trailer.
options.B: Green indicator lights on the trailer's front panel.
options.C: Blue warning signs on the trailer doors

en.description: To identify if a trailer has ABS, look for yellow ABS lights located on the trailer’s left side.

en.question: What is the quickest and most effective method to identify that the trailer has begun to skid?

options.A: Seeing it in your mirrors.
options.B: Feeling a sudden change in speed.
options.C: Noticing a change in the trailer's shadow.

en.description: The fastest and most reliable way to notice a trailer skid is by watching your mirrors carefully.

en.question: Loss of air pressure in the emergency line causes:

options.A: The service brakes to release slowly.
options.B: The air compressor to activate more frequently.
options.C: The trailer's emergency brakes to come on.

en.description: When emergency line air pressure drops, the trailer’s emergency brakes automatically activate to prevent uncontrolled movement.

en.question: Do not reverse a truck under a trailer until the entire air system is __

options.A: Below 40 psi
options.B: At normal pressure.
options.C: Over 100 psi

en.description: Ensure that the air system is at normal operating pressure before backing a truck under a trailer. This guarantees safe and proper brake function.

en.question: To unlock the fifth wheel, move the release handle to the _ position.

options.A: Locked
options.B: Engaged
options.C: Open

en.description: To disconnect the trailer from the tractor, move the fifth wheel release handle to the 'open' position.

en.question: What combination of a truck and trailer has the highest chance of rolling over in a turn?

options.A: A single 53 ft. trailer.
options.B: Triple 27 ft. trailers.
options.C: A single 48 ft. trailer.

en.description: Truck-trailer setups with triple 27 ft. trailers have the greatest risk of rollover during turns due to instability.

en.question: To check if the trailer air brake system is working, first fill it up with air. Then, push the red knob that supplies air to the trailer, or set the truck protection valve control in the _ position.

options.A: Closed
options.B: Released
options.C: Normal

en.description: To test the trailer air brake system, fill the system with air and set the trailer air supply control to the 'normal' position.

en.question: Emergency air line is__

options.A: Regulates the flow of music in the cab's entertainment system.
options.B: Controls the flow of hydraulic fluid for steering assistance.
options.C: Controls trailer emergency brake control.
options.D: Providing emergency air supply to the D tractor cabin at the peaks of mountain roads.

en.description: The emergency air line controls the trailer's emergency brake system. It activates the brakes if there's a serious problem, like a break in the line.

en.question: What is the first step in coupling a tractor-semitrailer?

options.A: Adjust the rearview mirrors
options.B: Fill the fuel tank.
options.C: Inspect the fifth wheel
options.D: Hook up all air lines to the trailer

en.description: Before coupling, the first thing to do is inspect the fifth wheel for damage or misalignment.

en.question: When is ABS useful?

options.A: If it is ONLY used during the daytime.
options.B: If it is ONLY used in dry conditions.
options.C: Whether it is the tractor or the trailers.

en.description: ABS helps prevent wheel lockup whether it’s on the tractor, trailer, or both — it's useful in all weather and lighting conditions.

en.question: What happens if the service line has a big leak and you try to stop the truck by pressing the brakes?

options.A: Brake pedal will feel normal, but brakes won't engage.
options.B: The trailer's emergency brakes are activated.
options.C: Brakes will only work at slower speeds.

en.description: A major service line leak causes the trailer's emergency brakes to activate to help bring it to a stop safely.

en.question: Which of the following is NOT part of the trailer's airline system?

options.A: Brake pedal sensitivity adjuster
options.B: Tire pressure monitor
options.C: Locking jaw

en.description: The locking jaw is part of the hitching mechanism, not the trailer’s air brake system.

en.question: Which of the following truck-trailer combinations is most likely to experience a "crack-the-whip" effect?

options.A: A tractor pulling a flatbed trailer.
options.B: A tractor with a heavy load trailer.
options.C: A tractor hauling three trailers

en.description: A tractor pulling three trailers is most at risk of a 'crack-the-whip' rollover, which happens when the last trailer swings violently.

en.question: Emergency air lines are used for all of the following, EXCEPT___

options.A: To supply air to the air tanks of the trailer
options.B: Engaging the emergency (spring) brakes if there is a loss of pressure.
options.C: Activating the trailer's emergency braking system in case of air loss.
options.D: To supply air to the relay valves, which helps the foot brake work faster.

en.description: Emergency air lines don’t supply air to the relay valves for faster foot brake response — that’s handled by the service line.

en.question: You should leave 1 second of distance to the vehicle in front of you for every___ feet of your vehicle's length.
en.description: For every 10 feet of vehicle length, you should allow 1 second of following distance for safe stopping.

en.question: What are other names for the service air line?

options.A: Control line and signal line
options.B: Supply line and management line
options.C: Guidance line and support line

en.description: The service air line is also known as the control line or signal line because it carries air to apply the brakes based on the driver’s brake pedal use.

en.question: What should you avoid doing when you're backing up a trailer?

options.A: Ignore warning signals.
options.B: Turn off your lights.
options.C: Back up as fast as possible.
options.D: Back up at a slow speed

en.description: You should never back up a trailer quickly. Always go slow to maintain control and watch for hazards.

en.question: After coupling the fifth wheels, how much gap should there be between the top and bottom fifth wheels?

options.A: About 2 inches
options.B: About 3/4 inch
options.C: About 1 inch

en.description: Leaving about 2 inches of gap ensures the kingpin is fully seated and allows for safe articulation without metal-on-metal contact.

en.question: When disconnecting the electrical cable during uncoupling, you should also__

options.A: Wrap it around the trailer hitch.
options.B: Hang it with the plug facing down.
options.C: Leave it on the ground.

en.description: Hanging the plug downward prevents water from entering the connector, reducing corrosion and electrical faults.

en.question: Before you start checking the trailer supports or landing gears, first ensure the truck is safely parked by setting the parking brake and putting the transmission in _

options.A: Neutral
options.B: Park mode
options.C: High gear

en.description: Putting the transmission in Neutral and setting the parking brake prevents unintended movement during inspection.

en.question: At railroad crossings, low-slung vehicles are more vulnerable than other vehicles because

options.A: They require a longer distance to stop safely.
options.B: They are much more likely to become stuck on raised railroad crossings.
options.C: They have lower visibility to oncoming trains.
options.D: Their acceleration speed is slower than other vehicles.

en.description: Low-slung frames can catch on the raised rails or approach plates, causing the vehicle to stall or become grounded.

en.question: Which one of these is a description of the "crack-the-whip" effect?

options.A: When you change lanes quickly or move the steering wheel quickly, the back trailer tends to swing out. The force of the back trailer gets amplified, which makes it flip over.
options.B: Driving over a speed bump at high speed, causing the trailer to bounce and lose control.
options.C: Driving too close to the curb, causing the trailer tires to burst.

en.description: Sudden steering inputs amplify movement at the end of a multi-trailer rig, making the last trailer swing out violently.

en.question: What is NOT a step in testing the truck protection valve?

options.A: Charging the air system.
options.B: Releasing the trailer brakes.
options.C: Reducing air pressure.
options.D: Slowly moving forward, then putting on the trailer brakes

en.description: Testing the protection valve involves pressurizing and bleeding air, not vehicle movements; slowly moving forward and applying brakes tests coupling, not the valve.

en.question: What might be the result of the crack-the-whip effect?

options.A: The headlights may suddenly turn off.
options.B: Trailer rolling over
options.C: The vehicle's speed will automatically increase.
options.D: Air compressor will stop filling the air tanks.

en.description: The amplified swing of the last trailer can cause it to tip or roll over.

en.question: When backing a truck under a trailer, you need to ensure that the air pressure is ___ so you can brake safely.

options.A: Above 100 psi
options.B: At normal pressure
options.C: Between 80 to 90 psi

en.description: Normal system pressure ensures both tractor and trailer brakes will engage properly during coupling.

en.question: Which type of vehicle is most likely to get stuck at a raised railroad crossing?

options.A: Moving vans
options.B: Car carriers
options.C: Single-axle tractors hauling a long trailer with its landing gear set for a tandem-axle tractor

en.description: Any vehicle with low ground clearance—vans, car carriers, or mis-geared semis—can snag on raised rails.

en.question: What license do you need to legally drive a triple trailer combination?

options.A: A Class B CDL
options.B: A Class D CDL
options.C: A Class E CDL
options.D: A Class A CDL with a doubles/triples (T) endorsement

en.description: Operating triples requires a Class A commercial license plus the ’T’ endorsement for doubles/triples.

en.question: Which of these is most likely to get stuck at a train crossing?

options.A: Lowboy
options.B: Moving van
options.C: Car carrier

en.description: All of these vehicles have low ground clearance, which increases the risk of getting hung up on raised railroad crossings.

en.question: What purpose does the trailer air supply control serve, and how do you use it?

options.A: You supply the trailer with air by pushing it in.
options.B: By turning it, you adjust the temperature inside the trailer.
options.C: By sliding it sideways, you control the trailer's lights.
options.D: By pulling it out, you remove air from overinflated tires.

en.description: Pushing in the trailer air supply control sends air to the trailer's brake system, enabling proper brake function.

en.question: Which of the following will stop the cargo from rolling over?

options.A: Stack all items in a pyramid shape.
options.B: Distribute the cargos in a uniform manner and place the heavy items at the bottom
options.C: Tie all the items loosely together with a rope.
options.D: Put the light items at the bottom and the heavy items at the top.

en.description: Proper cargo distribution with heavy items at the bottom maintains a low center of gravity and reduces rollover risk.

en.question: Where can you find the shut-off valve?

options.A: On the side of the trailer
options.B: Under the driver's seat.
options.C: In the trailer's back,

en.description: The shut-off valve is typically located at the back of the trailer and controls air flow between units.

en.question: When the trailer has anti-lock brakes, but the truck pulling it doesn't, the trailer has _

options.A: Less chances to swing out
options.B: Likely to stop quicker than the tractor.
options.C: More likely to skid uncontrollably

en.description: ABS on the trailer helps prevent it from locking up, reducing the chance of swinging out even if the tractor doesn't have ABS.

en.question: Which of the following is NOT true about the anti-lock braking system?

options.A: It increases the stopping distance.
options.B: It makes your vehicle impossible to steer while braking.
options.C: It only works on wet roads.
options.D: Since March 1998, all air-brake vehicles must feature ABS

en.description: ABS is designed to help maintain control and can reduce stopping distance, not increase it.

en.question: When you are making sure air gets to all the trailers, you do NOT have to _

options.A: Press the pedal several times to lower the air pressure
options.B: Turn off the engine and remove the keys.
options.C: Adjust the mirrors to see the end of the trailer.
options.D: Walk to the rear of the last trailer

en.description: Lowering air pressure by pumping the brake pedal is not required to check if air reaches all trailers.

en.question: When you need to back up your vehicle in a curve, it's best to reverse toward the driver's side because _.

options.A: The driver can monitor the back of vehicle from the side window.
options.B: The mirrors provide a less clear view on this side.
options.C: The vehicle's controls are on that side.

en.description: Reversing toward the driver’s side improves visibility through the window, allowing for safer maneuvering.

en.question: If your trailer doesn't have spring brakes, should you use chocks to park it?

options.A: Only if the parking area is flat.
options.B: Only if the vehicle is carrying heavy cargo.
options.C: Always

en.description: Always use wheel chocks to prevent unintended movement if the trailer is not equipped with spring brakes.

en.question: If you are driving with two trailers and must use the emergency brakes to avoid crashing, you should _

options.A: Pump the brakes gently.
options.B: Use controlled or stab braking.
options.C: Turn off the engine immediately.

en.description: Controlled or stab braking helps maintain control during emergency stops, especially with multiple trailers.

en.question: Where can you find the yellow ABS malfunction lamp on a trailer?

options.A: On the top middle of the trailer
options.B: Inside the driver's side door
options.C: On the left front or left rear corner

en.description: The yellow ABS warning light on a trailer is typically located on the left front or left rear corner to alert the driver of ABS issues.

en.question: When there is a big leak in the brake line, the truck protection valve will shut off and the trailer's__ will turn on.

options.A: Emergency brake
options.B: Hand brake
options.C: Air pressure gauge

en.description: A major leak in the brake line activates the trailer’s emergency brakes to safely stop it.

en.question: When inspecting the lower fifth wheel, you do NOT have to check if _.

options.A: The fifth wheel plate is properly aligned.
options.B: There are no damaged parts.
options.C: There are no puddles on the ground.
options.D: There is no gap between the upper and lower fifth wheels.

en.description: Puddles on the ground are not part of the fifth wheel inspection during a commercial vehicle check.

en.question: Checking the service brakes on a trailer does not include which of the following?

options.A: Checking the tire pressure on the trailer
options.B: Putting the trailer air supply control in the "emergency" position
options.C: Listening for any unusual noises from the brakes
options.D: Slowly moving forward with your vehicle

en.description: You don’t place the trailer air supply control in the emergency position when checking service brakes.

en.question: What happens if the air does not flow to the back of a trailer?

options.A: Your brakes won't work properly.
options.B: Your lights will not turn on.
options.C: Your engine will overheat.

en.description: If air doesn't reach the rear trailer, its brakes may fail to operate correctly, risking safety.

en.question: Which of these is true about going off track?

options.A: Larger vehicles are not affected by off-tracking.
options.B: Turning sharply doesn't cause off-tracking.
options.C: The rear wheels of the last trailer will off-track the most.
options.D: Off-tracking happens when you brake while turning

en.description: In turns, the rear wheels of the last trailer follow a tighter path than the front, causing significant off-tracking.

en.question: Approximately what percentage of truck drivers die in rollover crashes?

options.A: Exactly 15%
options.B: More than 50%
options.C: Around 10%

en.description: Over half of truck driver fatalities result from rollover crashes, highlighting their danger.

en.question: Why shouldn't you use the trailer hand valve when driving?

options.A: It increases fuel consumption.
options.B: It reduces the turning radius of the vehicle.
options.C: The trailer may skid because of it.

en.description: Using the trailer hand valve while moving can cause the trailer to skid, risking a loss of control.

en.question: Why should you use wheel chocks when parking a vehicle without spring brakes?

options.A: To secure the trailer from moving.
options.B: To balance the trailer on uneven ground.
options.C: To adjust the trailer height for easier access.
options.D: To provide something solid for the land gear.

en.description: Wheel chocks prevent unintended trailer movement when spring brakes are not present.

en.question: Your vehicle got stuck on the railroad tracks. What should you do in this situation?

options.A: You should wait inside the vehicle for help to arrive.
options.B: You should try to push the vehicle off the track.
options.C: You should move away from your vehicle and call 911 or the posted emergency number.

en.description: Leave the vehicle immediately and call emergency services for assistance if stuck on train tracks.

en.question: Why does a combination vehicle with no load take more time to stop than when it's fully loaded?

options.A: There isn't as much traction
options.B: Brakes work better on heavier loads.
options.C: The center of gravity is lower.
options.D: Drivers tend to drive faster in empty vehicles.

en.description: Empty combination vehicles have less traction because they don't press as firmly against the road, making it harder to stop.

en.question: If you have to back up on a curved path, where should you turn so that there is a rear view?

options.A: Left side or driver's side
options.B: Using rearview mirror only
options.C: With assistance from a co-driver

en.description: Backing toward the driver’s side gives better visibility and control, making it the safest option.

en.question: How far (in seconds) should a 40-foot vehicle going 30 mph be from the vehicle in front of it?

options.A: 4 seconds
options.B: 3 seconds
options.C: 8 seconds

en.description: A 40-foot vehicle at 30 mph should maintain at least a 4-second following distance to allow safe stopping.

en.question: When the air pressure gets to a __ level, the knob that controls the air supply on a trailer will pop out.

options.A: 30 to 60 psi
options.B: 20 to 45 psi
options.C: 40 to 70 psi

en.description: The trailer air supply control will pop out when pressure falls between 20 and 45 psi, activating the emergency brakes.

en.question: Which of the following vehicles is more likely to roll over?

options.A: A single trailer loaded above its weight limit
options.B: The rearmost trailer of a triple combination
options.C: A single trailer with balanced cargo distribution

en.description: The last trailer in a triple combination is most likely to roll over due to increased sway and reduced stability.

en.question: Since what year are new trucks required to have anti-lock brake systems (ABS)?
en.description: As of March 1, 1998, all new air-braked trucks are required to be equipped with ABS for improved braking safety.

en.question: To check if the truck protection valve functions properly, in what position should the red air supply control knob be?

options.A: Emergency
options.B: Pulled out
options.C: Neutral

en.description: Set the red knob to the 'Emergency' position when testing the truck protection valve to ensure it works correctly.

en.question: What can make brakes get worse or stop working?

options.A: Use of the service brakes too much
options.B: Brakes that aren't set right
options.C: Not using the engine brakes enough

en.description: Brakes can stop working well if you use them too much, they're not adjusted correctly, or you don't use engine braking enough. So, all of these reasons can make brakes go bad.

en.question: In controlled braking, you press the brakes as hard as possible without making the wheels stop turning and _

options.A: Turn off the engine immediately.
options.B: Accelerate a little.
options.C: Maintain the vehicle traveling in a straight line.

en.description: When using controlled braking, you press on the brake really hard but make sure your wheels don't stop spinning completely. This way, you can keep your vehicle moving straight without it sliding or going off course.

en.question: What happens when you step on the brake pedal?

options.A: The brake pedal becomes harder to press.
options.B: Pressurized air flows to the brake chambers.
options.C: The vehicle automatically speeds up.

en.description: When you push the brake pedal, air that's under pressure goes to the brakes and makes them work. This is how the vehicle slows down or stops.

en.question: How can you figure out if your vehicle has a system that stops the brakes from locking up (ABS)?

options.A: Look for an "ABS" badge or sticker on the brake fluid reservoir.
options.B: Check to see if the vehicle was manufactured after 1998.
options.C: Check under the hood for a uniquely shaped ABS control module.

en.description: To know if your vehicle has an anti-lock braking system (ABS), check if it was made after 1998. Cars built after that year usually have ABS.

en.question: When doing the final check, how can you tell if the spring brakes activate when the air pressure gets too low?

options.A: Check the dashboard for a specific light indicator while driving at a low speed.
options.B: Park on level ground, chock the wheels, release the parking brake when you have enough air pressure, shut the engine off, and repeatedly press on and off the brake pedal until the warning light comes on
options.C: Drive around the block until the air pressure warning light activates.

en.description: To check if the spring brakes activate at the right air pressure level, do this: Find flat ground and put blocks on the wheels. With enough air in the system, turn off the parking brake, then the engine. Push the brake pedal several times until you see a warning light.

en.question: How can you make sure the low air pressure warning light in your vehicle is working properly?

options.A: Reduce air pressure below 60 psi by pumping the brakes with the engine off.
options.B: Pump the brakes while the engine is turned on.
options.C: Fill the tires with water to check pressure stability.
options.D: Completely remove the air compressor to check.

en.description: To check if the low air pressure warning in your vehicle works, do this: Turn off the engine and then hit the brakes a few times until the air pressure drops below 60 psi. This should make the warning go off if it's working right.

en.question: What's the best method to fix a skid caused by the drive wheels locking up?

options.A: Pump the brakes while the engine is turned on.
options.B: Stop braking, turn quickly, and countersteer
options.C: Accelerate and steer straight ahead.

en.description: When your vehicle's drive wheels lock up and skid while braking, the best thing to do is to stop braking, turn quickly in the direction you want to go, and then steer back to straighten out.

en.question: If you're driving a vehicle that has a front brake limiting valve, you should __

options.A: Only use it in heavy traffic conditions.
options.B: Always set it to normal mode
options.C: Switch it off during rain.

en.description: If your truck has a special control that changes how the front brakes work, you should always keep this control in the normal setting. This means you shouldn't mess with it or switch it to a different mode. Keeping it normal helps make sure your truck stops the right way and keeps you safe on the road.

en.question: The service brake system uses _

options.A: The air conditioning system to reduce speed.
options.B: The brakes when the driver presses on the foot brake pedal.
options.C: The vehicle's sound system to signal slowing down.

en.description: When you press the foot brake pedal in a vehicle, you're using the service braking system. This helps to slow down or stop the vehicle.

en.question: Why do you have to demonstrate your knowledge by passing the exam on air brakes?

options.A: If not, you will have to get a restricted CDL.
options.B: To ensure your vehicle doesn't use too much fuel.
options.C: To make sure you can drive safely in the rain.
options.D: Air brakes are on all trucks.

en.description: Taking the air brakes exam is a must because if you don't, you'll end up with a limited version of the commercial driver's license, which means you can't drive all the vehicles you might want to.

en.question: Can you leave your truck without putting on the parking brakes or chocking the wheels first?

options.A: Yes, if it's parked on a flat surface.
options.B: Yes, if the engine is still running.
options.C: No, never.

en.description: No, you should never leave your truck without making sure it's safely parked. This means either putting on the parking brakes or using blocks to stop the wheels from moving. It's important to do this so your truck doesn't roll away.

en.question: What is true about a dual air brake system?

options.A: Only one set of brake controls is used.
options.B: One system controls the front axle and another the rear
options.C: One is called the "primary" system and one is called the "secondary" system.

en.description: A dual air brake system for big trucks has two main parts. One part is called "primary" and the other is "secondary." The primary part usually takes care of the back wheels, and the secondary part handles the front. But there's just one set of controls for the driver to use. So, the correct answer is that all these statements are true.

en.question: Can you adjust the automatic slack adjuster manually?

options.A: Never adjust it manually.
options.B: Adjust it after every long trip.
options.C: When it's not working properly.
options.D: Always adjust it in every inspection.

en.description: Only adjust the automatic slack adjuster yourself if it's not working right. This means, if you notice it's not adjusting the brakes like it should, then you can manually fix it.

en.question: What are spring brakes?

options.A: They are special brakes used only for parking on steep hills.
options.B: If the air brakes lose pressure, the spring brakes will activate to stop the vehicle.
options.C: They are advanced brakes that automatically adjust based on the weight of the cargo.
options.D: They are a type brakes designed to work more effectively during the Spring season

en.description: Spring brakes are like emergency helpers for big trucks. If the truck's main brake system, which works with air pressure, fails or loses power, these spring brakes automatically kick in to stop the truck. This helps prevent accidents.

en.question: If the braking system fails, the emergency braking system can use __ to stop the vehicle.

options.A: Parts of the service and parking brakes
options.B: Gravity and wheel friction
options.C: The vehicle's momentum

en.description: If the main brakes don't work, the emergency brakes can use parts of the normal and parking brakes to stop the truck.

en.question: The maximum permissible rate of air pressure loss in the braking system of a vehicle when the brakes are applied and the engine is off is__

options.A: 5 psi for single and 6 psi for combination
options.B: 2 psi for single and 3 psi for combination.
options.C: 5 psi for single and 6 psi for combination
options.D: 4 psi for single and 5 psi for combination.

en.description: The right answer is: 2 psi for a single vehicle and 3 psi for a vehicle that's pulling another one.

en.question: Air brakes work by using___ to operate the brakes.

options.A: Hydraulic fluid
options.B: Carbon dioxide
options.C: Pressurized air

en.description: Air brakes in big trucks work with pressurized air. This means they use air that's pushed together tightly to make the brakes stop the truck.

en.question: What does the ABS do?

options.A: Regulates the engine speed.
options.B: Makes the vehicle go faster.
options.C: Turns on when the wheels are about to lock up
options.D: Always decreases the stopping distance significantly.

en.description: ABS helps stop your vehicle without the wheels getting stuck and skidding. When it senses the wheels might lock up and cause a skid, it quickly pumps the brakes to keep the wheels rolling and give you better control.

en.question: When you use the parking brakes, _.

options.A: Locking the wheels immediately.
options.B: Taking air out of the brake chambers.
options.C: Releasing air from the tires.

en.description: When you use the parking brakes, it means you are letting air out of the brake parts that help stop the truck. This helps keep the truck from moving when parked.

en.question: Which one of these is NOT included in the air brake system?

options.A: Service brake system
options.B: Emergency brake system
options.C: Radio signal system

en.description: The air brake system helps big vehicles like trucks stop safely. But the radio signal system does not help with stopping the vehicle, so it's not part of the air brake system.

en.question: How do you make sure the slack adjusters in your truck are okay?

options.A: Use gloves and pull hard on each slack adjuster that you can reach.
options.B: Check the vehicles oil level.
options.C: Inspect the tire tread depth.

en.description: To check the slack adjusters in your truck, wear gloves and pull hard on each one you can reach.

en.question: The truck protection valve___

options.A: Supplies the braking system with air.
options.B: Automatically closes if the air supply falls below a particular threshold.
options.C: Can be closed by applying the parking brakes.

en.description: The truck protection valve does three things: it gives air to the brakes, closes by itself if air gets too low, and can be shut off when you use the parking brake. So the answer is 'All of the above.'

en.question: What does the S-cam do?

options.A: Helps to cool down the engine faster
options.B: Increases fuel efficiency by optimizing air flow.
options.C: Push the brake shoes against the inside of braking drum

en.description: We need the S-cam to push the brake pads against the inside of the brake drum. This helps the vehicle to stop when you press the brake pedal.

en.question: If you want to stop as quickly as you can when driving a vehicle without anti-lock brakes, the most effective technique is _

options.A: The controlled braking technique
options.B: The stab braking technique
options.C: Both techiques will help stop the vehicle quickly.

en.description: To stop quickly in a vehicle without anti-lock brakes, use both techniques mentioned. These methods help the vehicle stop faster.

en.question: How thick do the drum linings have to be according to the government rules on air brakes?

options.A: 1/8 inch
options.B: 1/4 inch
options.C: 3/8 inch

en.description: For air brakes on trucks, there is a rule about how thick the brake pads need to be. They can't be thinner than 1/4 inch. This is important for safety.

en.question: Which of the following statements about a dual air brake system is correct?

options.A: Each system operates independently in case of a failure in the other system.
options.B: It only has one set of brake controls.
options.C: One system is called the "primary" system and the other one is called the "secondary" system.
options.D: All of the above are true.

en.description: A dual air brake system includes two independent systems, called the primary and secondary systems, and uses a single set of brake controls. All statements are correct.

en.question: Which of the following statements about spring brakes is correct?

options.A: Consisting of strong springs that are kept in place by air pressure when driving.
options.B: Until your air pressure drops to a particular range, often 20 to 30 psi, spring brakes will not exert its full effect.
options.C: Emergency brakes on a truck or tractor that activate when the air pressure gets too low.

en.description: Spring brakes serve as emergency brakes in heavy vehicles. They are held back by air pressure during driving, and fully activate if air pressure drops below about 20–30 psi. All statements are true.

en.question: If your ABS stops working, which of these is correct about your brakes?

options.A: Your brake lights will stop working.
options.B: Your brakes will only work at low speeds.
options.C: You will still be able to use your brakes but need to get the ABS fixed soon.
options.D: The ABS will work again if you pump your brake pedal

en.description: If ABS (Anti-lock Braking System) fails, your standard brakes will still function, but without the anti-lock feature. You should repair the ABS system soon.

en.question: Which of the following statements about slack adjusters is correct?

options.A: They are located between the push rod and S-Cam on drum brakes.
options.B: They are located between the power screw and push rod on disc brakes.
options.C: All of the above

en.description: Slack adjusters help maintain proper brake adjustment. Their location depends on the brake type: between the push rod and S-Cam for drum brakes, or between the power screw and push rod for disc brakes. All are correct.

en.question: What will happen if the low air pressure warning signal is not working correctly?

options.A: The vehicle's fuel efficiency will improve.
options.B: In a single-circuit air system, it could cause the brakes to stop quickly in an emergency
options.C: The vehicle's speed will increase due to reduced air resistance.

en.description: In a single-circuit air brake system, a malfunctioning low air pressure warning signal can prevent the driver from knowing when air pressure is dangerously low, potentially leading to sudden brake failure.

en.question: Why does the alcohol evaporator release the evaporated alcohol into the air system?

options.A: To make the brakes smell nice.
options.B: To cool down the engine.
options.C: To prevent ice buildup in the air brake system

en.description: The alcohol evaporator releases alcohol mist into the air brake system to prevent ice from forming in cold weather.

en.question: How can you make sure the air compressor governor is working correctly?

options.A: Listen for strange noises coming from the air compressor.
options.B: Raise the air pressure until the air compressor is turned off and then lower the air pressure; keep stepping on and off the brake pedal until the air compressor turns on.
options.C: Turn the engine on and off repeatedly to check if the air compressor responds.

en.description: To test the air compressor governor, build up air pressure until the compressor cuts out, then reduce the pressure by pressing the brake repeatedly until it cuts back in.

en.question: What's the most important thing to know about hard braking?

options.A: Increases fuel efficiency
options.B: Improves tire traction.
options.C: Don't lock the wheels for longer than a split second
options.D: Brake pads will wear out faster

en.description: When braking hard, avoid locking the wheels for more than a split second, as it can lead to loss of vehicle control.

en.question: Your truck got up to 40 mph going down a steep hill. You have to use your brakes to slow it down until it's going ___ mph.

options.A: 25 mph
options.B: 20 mph
options.C: 35 mph

en.description: When descending a steep hill, if your truck hits 40 mph, slow it down to 35 mph using your brakes.

en.question: When checking for air leaks in the air brake system, you should turn off the engine and hold the brake pedal down for one minute. The air pressure shouldn't go down by more than _ during that time.

options.A: 8 psi
options.B: 7 psi
options.C: 3 psi

en.description: During a leak check, with the engine off and brakes applied for one minute, air pressure loss should not exceed 3 psi.

en.question: How can you figure out how fast air is leaking when the truck is not moving?

options.A: Release the service brakes and observe the pressure gauge.
options.B: Turn off the engine, let go of the parking brake, and wait for the system to settle.
options.C: Engage the service brakes and monitor fuel levels.

en.description: To check the rate of air leakage, turn off the engine, release the parking brake, and let the system settle before observing the pressure.

en.question: When should you use both the parking brakes and the air brakes at the same time?

options.A: When the vehicle is being loaded or unloaded.
options.B: Before starting your driving shift.
options.C: Never do that
options.D: Any time you need to stop quickly

en.description: You should never use parking brakes and air (service) brakes at the same time, as it can damage the system.

en.question: How should you correctly use anti-lock brakes?

options.A: Brake normally
options.B: Slam the brakes continuously.
options.C: Pump the brakes rapidly.

en.description: With ABS, just brake normally. The system will manage wheel lock-up.

en.question: How do you properly set a manual slack adjuster?

options.A: Pull the release lever while turning the adjusting nut clockwise.
options.B: Screw the adjusting nut until the slack adjuster's end stops moving toward the air chamber. Then turn the nut a quarter of a turn in the other direction to pull the brake shoes away from the inside of the brake drum.
options.C: Tighten the adjusting nut with a hammer until it feels tight.

en.description: To adjust a manual slack adjuster, turn the nut until contact, then back off a quarter turn to ensure clearance.

en.question: Where can you find the foundation brakes?

options.A: All the wheels.
options.B: On the roof of the vehicle
options.C: Under the driver's seat

en.description: Foundation brakes are installed on all the wheels and are the main braking components of the vehicle.

en.question: Which vehicles must be equipped with a low air pressure warning system?

options.A: After the year 2000, new vehicles must feature low-air-pressure warnings.
options.B: Vehicles with manual brakes only.
options.C: All air brake-equipped vehicles must have low-pressure warning lights to drive on the roads.

en.description: Any vehicle that uses air brakes must have a warning signal for low air pressure to be allowed on the road.

en.question: If you're driving a truck-trailer combination vehicle equipped with ABS, which one of these things is NOT something you do when braking?

options.A: Only use as much brake as you need to stay in control safely.
options.B: When slowing down, watch your tractor and trailer and ease off the brakes.
options.C: Brake normally regardless of the ABS brakes
options.D: Step on the gas pedal to speed up which would keep the trailer and truck straight.

en.description: You should not accelerate to try and keep the truck and trailer straight; this is unsafe.

en.question: For the S-cam drum brakes to work, they need air to be pushed into each brake chamber first. The force of the air pressure pushes the pushrod outward. The rod then moves ___ which makes ___ rotate.

options.A: Pushrod; steering wheel
options.B: Kingpin; fifth wheel
options.C: Slack adjuster; brake camshaft

en.description: The pushrod moves the slack adjuster, which turns the brake camshaft and activates the brakes.

en.question: Before going down a hill, you must change to the right gear __

options.A: So you just need to use the brake enough to feel a slowdown.
options.B: To allow you to cruise downward.
options.C: So that you may shift through the gears on the downhill.

en.description: Before descending, choose the proper gear so that only light braking is needed to control your speed.

en.question: What should you do before you leave a vehicle unattended?

options.A: Take starter key with you.
options.B: Engage the parking brakes.
options.C: Place the wheel chocks.

en.description: Before leaving a vehicle unattended, you should take the key, set the parking brake, and block the wheels.

en.question: How can you check if the truck's slack adjusters are functioning correctly?

options.A: Park on level area, turn off the parking brakes, and pull each slack adjuster hard. Check to see if it moves less than 1 inch.
options.B: Park on level area, put on the parking brakes and keep pressing the brake pedal.
options.C: Park on level area, release the parking, press the gas pedal, and see if the adjuster moves or not.

en.description: To test slack adjusters, pull on each one with the brakes released. If it moves more than 1 inch, it needs adjustment.

en.question: Why should you drain air tanks?

options.A: They may overheat
options.B: Your brakes could emit a loud noise.
options.C: To ensure the headlights always stay on.
options.D: The frozen water may cause the brakes to fail.

en.description: Draining the air tanks removes moisture that can freeze and prevent the brakes from working properly.

en.question: What does the handbrake control?

options.A: The brakes when you are driving in reverse.
options.B: The brakes when you are changing lanes.
options.C: It releases the air out of the brake chambers.

en.description: The handbrake releases air from the brake chambers, engaging the spring brakes to hold the vehicle in place.

en.question: How do brakes work when going down a long, steep hill?

options.A: By increasing the vehicle's speed to reduce strain.
options.B: As a supplement and the engine braking effect as the main.
options.C: By using only the vehicle's weight to slow down.

en.description: Engine braking should be the primary method of speed control on long descents, with brakes used only to assist.

en.question: Can you use the spring brakes and air brakes at the same time?

options.A: Yes, only when carrying heavy loads.
options.B: Yes, but only at high speeds.
options.C: No, never.

en.description: Spring brakes are for parking or emergencies, not for use while driving. Never use both at once.

en.question: Why do we use an alcohol evaporator?

options.A: To clean the air filters more efficiently.
options.B: To increase fuel efficiency by adding alcohol to the engine.
options.C: Reduce the risk of icing in air brake valves in cold weather.

en.description: An alcohol evaporator helps prevent ice from forming in the air brake valves when it's cold, ensuring the brakes work properly.

en.question: If your truck has an alcohol evaporator, what should you do with it when the weather gets cold?

options.A: Drain and remove the evaporator.
options.B: Check and fill the alcohol level.
options.C: Adjust the coolant system for alcohol.

en.description: In cold weather, ensure the evaporator has enough alcohol to prevent freezing in the air brake system.

en.question: What brake system applies and releases the brakes when the driver steps on the brake pedal?

options.A: Automatic
options.B: Service
options.C: Manual

en.description: The service brake system is used for normal braking when the brake pedal is pressed.

en.question: If your vehicle doesn't have automatic tank drains, you should drain the oil and water from the bottom of the air tanks _

options.A: Every month.
options.B: Before starting the engine each morning.
options.C: At the end of each day of driving.

en.description: Daily draining prevents moisture buildup that can cause brake system issues.

en.question: How do you normally engage the parking brakes?

options.A: Shift into neutral gear.
options.B: Push the gas pedal down.
options.C: Apply brakes by pulling the parking brake control knob out.

en.description: Pulling out the control knob engages the spring brakes, securing the vehicle when parked.

en.question: The safety valve lowers pressure when it reaches __ psi.
en.description: The safety valve opens at 150 psi to release excess pressure and protect the system.

en.question: A low air pressure warning signal must appear when the air pressure in the tank falls below__ psi.
en.description: A warning light activates at 60 psi to alert the driver of dangerously low air pressure. In some states, it's 55 psi.

en.question: What does the air compressor governor control?

options.A: The amount of fuel the engine uses
options.B: The temperature of the engine.
options.C: When air is pumped into the air tanks.

en.description: The governor tells the air compressor when to start and stop filling the air tanks.

en.question: When you use the service brakes too much, they can get too hot and this can cause _.
