options.A: Expansion of the brake drums.
options.B: Decreased fuel efficiency
options.C: Reduced tire pressure

en.description: Overuse of brakes causes drum expansion from heat, reducing braking effectiveness.

en.question: If the air pressure doesn't go up to the needed level fast enough, then:

options.A: The headlights could become dimmer.
options.B: You might need to adjust the mirrors more frequently.
options.C: Air pressure may drop to a low point while driving, requiring an emergency stop.

en.description: If air pressure builds too slowly, it may drop dangerously low during driving, requiring an emergency stop.

en.question: Which of the following types of foundation brakes are most commonly found on heavy vehicles?

options.A: Air pad
options.B: S-cam drum.
options.C: Hydraulic disc

en.description: The S-cam drum brake is widely used on heavy vehicles like trucks and buses due to its durability and effectiveness.

en.question: What statement about spring brake braking power is correct?

options.A: It depends on the service brakes being in adjustment.
options.B: It decreases as the vehicle's speed increases.
options.C: It is most effective when the vehicle is fully loaded.

en.description: Spring brakes rely on the service brakes being properly adjusted in order to apply sufficient stopping force.

en.question: Air brakes have a longer total stopping distance than hydraulic brakes due to ___ distance.

options.A: Acceleration distance
options.B: Brake lag
options.C: Cooling time

en.description: Brake lag refers to the delay between pressing the pedal and the brakes activating in air brake systems, increasing stopping distance.

en.question: If you pull hard on a slack adjuster and it moves more than __, it needs to be adjusted.

options.A: 5/8 inch
options.B: 1 inch
options.C: 3 inches

en.description: Slack adjusters should not move more than 1 inch when pulled. If they do, the brakes are out of adjustment.

en.question: At what psi does the air compressor stop pumping air?
en.description: The compressor stops at 125 psi to maintain optimal pressure and prevent overloading the system.

en.question: What happens if your vehicle's brake drums overheat?

options.A: They expand.
options.B: They crack and leak fluid.
options.C: They glow bright red

en.description: Overheated brake drums expand, reducing braking effectiveness due to increased clearance with the brake shoes.

en.question: Excessive heat caused by overusing your brakes can also cause _.

options.A: Engine oil to overheat.
options.B: Tire pressure to decrease.
options.C: Brake to fade or fail.

en.description: Too much heat can lead to brake fade or failure, making it harder or impossible to stop the vehicle safely.

en.question: What is the purpose of a brake light switch?

options.A: It activates the turn signals when you apply the brakes
options.B: It turns on the brake lights when you put on the air brakes.
options.C: It adjusts the brightness of your headlights.

en.description: The brake light switch activates the rear brake lights when the brake pedal is pressed, alerting other drivers.

en.question: When going down a steep hill and reaching your safe speed of 40 mph, you would use the brake until your speed goes down to __mph.
en.description: To prevent overheating, brake until your speed is reduced to 35 mph, then release the brakes to let them cool.

en.question: When the air pressure falls below___ psi, the straight truck spring brakes will come fully on.
en.description: When driving a straight truck, if the air pressure gets too low, special brakes called spring brakes kick in to stop you. This happens when the air pressure drops below 20 psi (pounds per square inch). It's a safety feature to prevent accidents when there's not enough air pressure for the regular brakes..

en.question: What does the term "Wig Wag" mean?

options.A: A light that flashes when the engine is overheating
options.B: A mechanical arm that signals low air pressure
options.C: A lever that controls the speed of the engine.

en.description: A 'Wig Wag' is a mechanical arm that drops down as a visual warning when air pressure in the brake system is dangerously low.

en.question: Why is it important to remove water from the compressed air tanks?

options.A: Water is removed because its presence might cause the tank to change color, which is thought to be a sign of wear.
options.B: Water is removed from the compressed air tanks to make the system lighter and improve fuel efficiency.
options.C: Water can freeze in cold weather and cause brake failure.

en.description: Water in air tanks can freeze in cold weather, blocking air flow and leading to brake failure.

en.question: Parking or emergency brakes must be kept in position by something that does not leak, like:

options.A: Spring pressure.
options.B: Magnetic force
options.C: Electric current

en.description: Spring pressure holds the parking or emergency brakes in place without relying on air or electricity, which can leak or fail.

en.question: Your truck is equipped with a dual air brake system and minimum-size air tanks. How long should it take for the air pressure to go up from 85 to 100 psi?
en.description: The air pressure should rise from 85 to 100 psi in 45 seconds or less in a properly functioning dual air brake system.

en.question: How can you tell if your brakes are fading?

options.A: Less pressure is needed on the brake pedal for each stop.
options.B: You have to push harder on a brake pedal to control your speed on a downgrade.
options.C: The vehicle stops more quickly than usual.

en.description: Brake fade means the brakes are losing effectiveness, and you'll need to push harder to slow the vehicle, especially on hills.

en.question: You should NOT apply the parking brake, _

options.A: If it's raining lightly outside.
options.B: If the brakes are very hot (e.g. Just after coming down a steep grade).
options.C: If the parking area is completely flat and secure.

en.description: Applying the parking brake when the brakes are hot can damage the system or cause it to lock up.

en.question: The safety valve automatically open at__

options.A: 200 psi
options.B: 75 psi
options.C: 150 psi

en.description: The safety valve opens at 150 psi to release excess air and protect the system from overpressure damage.

en.question: When the spring brakes are activated, when is it okay to press the brake pedal?

options.A: Only at a full stop.
options.B: Only when making sharp turns.
options.C: Never.

en.description: Pressing the brake pedal when spring brakes are on can damage the braking system. You should never do this.

en.question: What holds the air in the tanks if there is a leak in the air compressor?

options.A: The dual circuit brake system
options.B: The one-way check valve.
options.C: The pressure release valve

en.description: The one-way check valve allows air into the tank but prevents it from flowing back out, maintaining pressure even if the compressor fails.

en.question: Using your brakes too much can also cause:

options.A: Brake to fade or fail.
options.B: Tire pressure to decrease.
options.C: Brake fluid to evaporate.

en.description: Excessive brake use generates heat, which can lead to brake fade or complete failure.

en.question: When is it safe to leave your truck unattended without applying parking brakes and chocking the wheels?

options.A: If you are parked on a flat surface.
options.B: Never.
options.C: If you are only away for a few minutes.

en.description: It is never safe to leave your truck without applying the parking brakes and chocking the wheels, regardless of the situation.

en.question: What pressure (PSI) in the service air tank triggers the low air pressure warning?
en.description: The low air pressure warning comes on when the pressure drops to 60 psi, alerting the driver to a potentially dangerous condition.

en.question: To check if the air service brakes function properly, you should:

options.A: Brake gently while the vehicle is in neutral.
options.B: Press the brake pedal repeatedly while the vehicle is stationary.
options.C: Brake firmly while slowly moving forward.

en.description: To check brake function, move forward slowly and apply the brakes firmly to ensure they engage correctly.

en.question: How can you check that your service brakes are functioning properly?

options.A: Drive at a high speed, then slam on the brakes to see if the vehicle stops quickly.
options.B: Park on a slight slope, drain off air pressure, set the parking brake and check movement.
options.C: Park on level ground, wait until normal air pressure is reached, release the parking brake and move forward slowly at about 5 mph. Then apply the brakes firmly.

en.description: This is the safest and proper method to test service brake function without risking vehicle damage or loss of control.

en.question: In vehicles with dual parking control valves, you can use pressure from a separate tank to _.

options.A: Release the spring emergency/parking brakes to move a short distance.
options.B: Check the tire pressure without exiting the vehicle.
options.C: Fill the fuel tank without going to a gas station.

en.description: The auxiliary air tank allows for temporary release of the spring brakes to move the vehicle a short distance in emergencies.

en.question: To go down a steep, long grade, select the right gear first. Then, to brake correctly, slow down until you're going about __ miles per hour slower than the speed limit, and then release the brakes.

options.A: 25 mph
options.B: 5 mph
options.C: 20 mph

en.description: Brake until your speed drops 5 mph below your safe speed, then release the brakes to avoid overheating them.

en.question: A truck or bus emergency or parking brakes can be legally held by a/an__ pressure.

options.A: Hydraulic
options.B: Magnetic
options.C: Spring

en.description: Spring pressure is the standard legal method to hold parking or emergency brakes in trucks and buses.

en.question: Spring brakes are usually held back by — during normal driving.

options.A: Air pressure.
options.B: Hydraulic fluid
options.C: Magnetic force

en.description: Under normal conditions, air pressure keeps the spring brakes released. If air pressure drops, the springs engage the brakes.

en.question: What is the purpose of the S-cam?

options.A: Rotates the wheels at different speeds for better handling.
options.B: Adjusts the tire pressure for optimal braking.
options.C: Forces the brake shoes against the inside of the brake drum.

en.description: The S-cam mechanism applies the brake shoes against the drum to create friction and stop the vehicle.

en.question: The braking power of the spring brakes:

options.A: Decreases as the speed of the vehicle increases.
options.B: Depends on the brakes being in adjustment.
options.C: Increases when the vehicle is fully loaded.

en.description: The effectiveness of spring brakes relies on proper adjustment of the braking system. Poor adjustment can lead to brake failure.

en.question: When driving down a long and steep hill, using the brakes should only be an extra help to:

options.A: Use of spring brakes.
options.B: The use of the front brakes limiting valve.
options.C: The braking effect of the engine.

en.description: On steep downgrades, the engine's braking power should be the main method of control, with brakes used only as needed to assist.

en.question: If you have to stop quickly in an emergency, make sure you brake in a way that:

options.A: Will allow you to steer and keep your vehicle in a straight line.
options.B: Will allow you to turn sharply to avoid obstacles.
options.C: Will make your vehicle spin to reduce speed.

en.description: Maintaining steering control and a straight path is key to avoiding accidents during emergency braking.

en.question: All vehicles with air brakes have:

options.A: An automatic pressure adjustment system.
options.B: A supply pressure gauge.
options.C: A manual air control valve.

en.description: Every air brake-equipped vehicle includes a gauge that shows the air supply pressure to monitor brake system readiness.

en.question: How many feet does a truck or bus with air brakes need to stop if going 55 mph under perfect conditions?

options.A: Exactly 150 feet.
options.B: Exactly 250 feet.
options.C: More than 300 feet.

en.description: At 55 mph, a vehicle with air brakes can take about 450 feet to stop—so the correct answer is more than 300 feet.

en.question: If you keep pushing and letting go of the pedal over and over, it could cause__

options.A: A loss of brake air pressure.
options.B: A buildup of brake air pressure.
options.C: Increased fuel consumption.

en.description: Repeatedly pressing and releasing the brake pedal can quickly reduce air pressure, leading to brake failure.

en.question: What should you do first and right away when the low air pressure alarm goes off?

options.A: Stop and safely park as soon as possible.
options.B: Check the oil level.
options.C: Continue driving and monitor the situation.

en.description: A low air pressure warning indicates a potential brake failure. Stop and park the vehicle safely immediately.

en.question: What is the purpose of draining compressed air tanks of water?

options.A: Water can freeze in cold weather and cause brake failure.
options.B: Water low boiling point reduces braking power.
options.C: To prevent air leaks in the tires.

en.description: Water in the air tanks can freeze and block airflow, potentially causing brakes to fail in cold weather.

en.question: When should you use the parking brake on a vehicle with air brakes?

options.A: Any time when vehicle is parked.
options.B: Only during vehicle inspection.
options.C: When making a quick stop.

en.description: Always apply the parking brake when parking to secure the vehicle and prevent it from rolling.

en.question: If you need to stop quickly because of an emergency, you should brake in a manner that lets you__

options.A: Switch to neutral and let the vehicle coast.
options.B: Tap the gas pedal lightly before braking.
options.C: Keep your vehicle in a straight line.

en.description: Braking in a straight line during emergencies helps maintain control and avoid skidding.

en.question: How should you check the free play of S-cam brakes' manual slack adjusters?

options.A: Park on a slope, engage the parking brake, and check with the engine running.
options.B: Park on level ground, chock the wheels and release the parking brakes.
options.C: Park on a slope and check without chocking the wheels.

en.description: To safely check slack adjusters, park on flat ground, chock the wheels to prevent movement, and release the parking brakes.

en.question: If your truck or bus has a dual-air brake system and one of them shows a low air pressure warning, what should you do?

options.A: Increase your speed to reach your destination quicker.
options.B: Check your mirrors for traffic before deciding to continue driving.
options.C: Stop right away and safely park. Continue only after the system is fixed.

en.description: If your truck or bus with two air brake systems shows a low air warning for one system, don't keep driving. Stop safely as soon as you can and fix the problem before you go any further.

en.question: Why do brakes that use air take longer to work than those that use liquid?

options.A: Air brakes have larger pistons.
options.B: Air brakes take more time to flow through the lines than hydraulic fluid.
options.C: Air brakes need to warm up before use.

en.description: Air brakes take longer to start working than liquid-based brakes because air moves slower through the brake lines than liquid does.

en.question: The application pressure gauge shows how much air pressure you _.

options.A: Are applying to the brakes.
options.B: Need to refill the air compressor.
options.C: Have in the hydraulic fluid system

en.description: The application pressure gauge shows how much pressure you're using when you press the brakes.

en.question: The safety valve will automatically let go of extra pressure when the pressure hits _ psi.
en.description: If the pressure gets too high, at 150 psi, the safety valve will open to release excess pressure.

en.question: The supply pressure gauge tells you___

options.A: How much pressure is in the air tanks.
options.B: The temperature of the air compressor
options.C: The speed of the vehicle

en.description: The supply pressure gauge tells you how much air pressure is in the tanks.

en.question: What can legally keep the parking or emergency brakes on trucks, truck-trailers, or buses in place?

options.A: Magnetic force
options.B: Spring pressure.
options.C: Gravity

en.description: The parking or emergency brakes on large vehicles use spring pressure to stay applied and work correctly.

en.question: When you use the brakes, the brake shoes will push against the:

options.A: Brake drum or disc.
options.B: Wheel axle
options.C: Tire rim

en.description: When you press the brakes, the brake shoes push against the brake drum or disc to stop the vehicle.

en.question: When the straight truck engine is off and the brakes are on, the air loss rate should not exceed__

options.A: 3 psi in one minute.
options.B: 4 psi in 2 minutes
options.C: 5 psi in 3 minutes

en.description: With the engine off and brakes applied, air loss should not exceed 3 psi in one minute to ensure safe braking.

en.question: The parking brake on a vehicle with air brakes should be used:

options.A: To stop at traffic lights.
options.B: Whenever you leave the vehicle unattended.
options.C: When you're driving at a high speed.

en.description: Always use the parking brake when leaving the vehicle to prevent it from moving.

en.question: At what psi is an air brake system considered to be fully charged?
en.description: An air brake system is considered fully charged at 125 psi, meaning it's at full operating capacity.

en.question: The brake pedal in an air brake system:

options.A: Controls the air pressure applied to the brakes.
options.B: Adjusts the temperature of the brake pads.
options.C: Increases the amount of fuel to the engine

en.description: The brake pedal in an air brake system controls how much air pressure goes to the brakes.

en.question: Some trucks have an alcohol evaporator. What may happen if you don't maintain the right level of alcohol in it?

options.A: The brakes may overheat and stop working properly.
options.B: Ice may form in the air brake valves and cause brake failure.
options.C: The brake fluid could evaporate, leading to total brake loss.

en.description: If the alcohol level in the air brake system is too low, ice can build up in the valves, leading to brake failure.

en.question: If your truck has a dual air brake system and one of them doesn't have enough pressure:

options.A: The system will automatically redistribute the available pressure, ensuring that all brakes remain fully effective.
options.B: The brake pedal will feel unusually soft.
options.C: Either the front or rear brakes will not be fully functional.

en.description: If one part of a dual air brake system fails, either the front or back brakes might not work properly.

en.question: When the engine is turned off and the brakes are not applied, the air brake system in a straight truck or bus shouldn't lose more than __ psi every minute.
en.description: The system should not lose more than 2 psi per minute when the engine is off and brakes are not applied.

en.question: When driving at 55 mph on a dry road, how many feet will air brake lag distance add to your total stopping distance?
en.description: At 55 mph on a dry road, air brake lag adds 32 feet to the total stopping distance.

en.question: What will happen if your truck has a dual air system and one loses air pressure?

options.A: The brake lights will remain on continuously.
options.B: The truck will automatically speed up.
options.C: Either the front or back brake will not be fully operational.

en.description: If one part of the dual air system fails, either the front or rear brakes will not function properly.

en.question: How do you do emergency stab braking the right way?

options.A: Pump the brakes gently until the vehicle stops.
options.B: Apply your brakes all the way. Release the brakes when wheels lock up. As soon as the wheels start rolling, apply the brakes fully again.
options.C: Turn off the engine immediately.

en.description: Emergency stab braking: brake hard, release if wheels lock, then reapply when wheels start rolling.

en.question: What tells you how much air pressure is in the tanks?

options.A: Fuel meter
options.B: Water level indicator
options.C: Supply pressure gauge

en.description: The supply pressure gauge shows how much air pressure is in the tanks.

en.question: What should you do if your truck or bus has dual air brakes and a warning light turns on because one system has low pressure?

options.A: Ignore the warning and focus on your driving.
options.B: Bring your vehicle to a complete stop right B away and safely park. Continue only after the system is fixed.
options.C: Continue driving as normal and check the system after your trip.

en.description: Stop the vehicle safely and park it. Fix the system before driving again if the low-pressure warning light comes on.

en.question: It's not safe to drive a vehicle if its brake drums have cracks bigger than of the friction area.
en.description: If brake drums have cracks wider than half the friction area, the vehicle is unsafe to drive.

en.question: Air brakes consist of three different braking systems: service, parking and _.

options.A: Emergency
options.B: Hydraulic
options.C: Disc

en.description: The emergency brake is a backup system that works if the main brakes fail, using parts of the service and parking brakes.

en.question: How many extra feet does it take for an air brake to start working when you're going 55 mph on a dry road?
en.description: At 55 mph on a dry road, air brake lag adds 32 feet to the time it takes for the brakes to start slowing the truck down.

en.question: Whenever you park, always use the parking brakes, except:

options.A: If the brakes are very hot (e.g., after just coming down a steep grade).
options.B: If the parking area is completely level.
options.C: If the parking spot is designated for short-term parking only.

en.description: Do not use the parking brakes if they are too hot from heavy braking after descending a steep hill.

en.question: When testing combination vehicles with the engine off and brakes applied, the air pressure should not drop more than _ psi every minute.
en.description: For combination vehicles, air pressure should not fall more than 4 psi per minute when the engine is off and brakes are applied.

en.question: When is it NOT a good time to use the parking brakes?

options.A: To brake vehicle very hard, in other word when coming down the steep grade.
options.B: Parking on an incline or decline
options.C: In an emergency brake failure

en.description: Parking brakes are not meant for hard braking when coming down steep grades.

en.question: Emergency controlled braking is when you

options.A: Apply the brakes as hard as you can without locking the wheels.
options.B: Press down on the accelerator while lightly tapping the brakes.
options.C: Turn off the engine and coast to a stop.

en.description: Emergency controlled braking means applying brakes hard while preventing wheel lock-up.

en.question: The service line has a big leak, so you hit the brakes. Service air pressure will escape, causing -

options.A: Engine to overheat
options.B: Brakes to release automatically.
options.C: Trailer emergency brakes to come on.

en.description: If service air pressure escapes due to a leak, trailer emergency brakes will activate.

en.question: Before you drive a truck or bus that has a dual air brake system, the air pressure needs to be at least _ psi.
en.description: Air pressure should be at least 100 psi in a dual air brake system before driving.

en.question: What does the brake pedal do in an air brake system?

options.A: Sends signals to the vehicle's lights and indicators.
options.B: Controls the air pressure applied to put on the brakes.
options.C: Adjusts the vehicle's steering direction.

en.description: The brake pedal controls air pressure applied to the brakes.

en.question: What is true about the antilock braking system?

options.A: ABS makes your tires last longer.

en.question: How much liquid you can put in a tank depends on...

options.B: Increases the tanker's speed.
options.C: Protects the tanker from corrosive cargo

en.question: A baffled tanker is one with...

en.question: You can minimize the impact of liquid surge if you...

en.question: Stop valves in a cargo tank...

en.question: In what situations should you exercise extra caution when driving a smooth bore tanker combination?

en.question: How do you think a truck carrying a tank with partitions inside would drive on the road?

options.C: Turn on the headlights

en.question: When conducting a walkaround inspection, why is it important to check the converter dolly?

options.A: To verify it’s painted the correct color
options.B: To ensure the tow bar, safety chains, and brakes are in working condition
options.C: To confirm fuel levels

en.description: Inspecting the converter dolly ensures all essential components like the tow bar, safety chains, and brake system are functioning properly.

en.question: What does a double trailer rig require during a pre-trip inspection that a single rig might not?

options.A: A check for extra license plates
options.B: Inspection of the coupling systems between trailers
options.C: Fuel cap security

en.description: Double trailers have multiple coupling points that must be inspected to ensure each trailer is securely attached and safe for travel.

en.question: When coupling a second trailer to your combination vehicle, what should you use to secure it?

options.A: The trailer's spring brakes and emergency air brakes
options.B: Wheel chocks
options.C: Both answers are correct

en.description: When attaching a second trailer, you may use either the trailer's own spring brakes/emergency brakes or wheel chocks to keep it from rolling. Both are acceptable safety practices.

en.question: Is it true that the dolly tow bar might rise up if the pintle hook is unlocked while the converter dolly remains under the rear trailer?

options.A: TRUE
options.B: FALSE

en.description: Yes, it's true. If the pintle hook is unlocked while the converter dolly is still under the trailer, the tow bar can rise suddenly and cause injury or damage.

en.question: The most effective method for resolving all skids is to ___

options.A: Restore traction to the tires
options.B: Turn off the engine.
options.C: Counter steer and accelerate

en.description: To recover from a skid, the priority is to restore traction between the tires and the road surface.

en.question: How do you know that the trailer height is correct before attaching a converter dolly to a second or third trailer?

options.A: The trailer will be raised slightly when the converter dolly is backed under it.
options.B: The locking jaws are below the center of the kingpin.
options.C: The fifth wheel is above the trailer's frame.

en.description: If the trailer is lifted slightly when backing the dolly underneath, it indicates the height is correct for a proper and safe coupling.

en.question: What purpose does a converter dolly serve?

options.A: To couple tow or three trailers behind a tractor truck.
options.B: To lift heavy loads onto the trailer.
options.C: To increase the speed of a tractor-trailer on highways.

en.description: A converter dolly is used to link additional trailers to a tractor, allowing the vehicle to tow two or three trailers at once.

en.question: A combination vehicle requires a more extensive inspection compared to a single vehicle?

options.A: TRUE
options.B: FALSE

en.description: Combination vehicles have more parts and connections than single units, necessitating a more thorough pre-trip inspection.

en.question: What method can you use to confirm that you have provided air to a second trailer?

options.A: Go to the rear of the second trailer and open the emergency line shut off
options.B: Listen for air escaping from the brake lines.
options.C: Listen for the horn to honk automatically.

en.description: To verify air supply to the rear trailer, open the emergency line shutoff valve and listen for air escape. This confirms that the line is charged.

en.question: What is another way to call the trailer air supply control?

options.A: Tractor protection valve control or trailer emergency valve
options.B: Trailer air balance lever
options.C: Air pressure adjustment knob

en.description: The trailer air supply control is also known as the tractor protection valve control or trailer emergency valve. It manages air flow to the trailer brakes.

en.question: Which statement is accurate?

options.A: The air supply in a triple trailer is more reliable than in a single trailer.
options.B: Check the brakes on a double/triple trailer as you would any other combination vehicle but be aware of the additional air brake checks needed.
options.C: The service line fills with water to help brakes work better.

en.description: Brake checks on double/triple trailers are similar to other vehicles, but due to their complexity, they require additional air brake system inspections.

en.question: What precaution should you take when making a turn with a double or triple?

options.A: Turn wide enough to avoid the curb or pedestrians but, at the same time, not too wide so that a driver can try to pass you on the right.
options.B: Make sharp turns to keep all trailers aligned.
options.C: Turn wide enough to avoid the curb.

en.description: Double and triple trailer turns require wide, controlled arcs to avoid curbs and pedestrians, while not giving other vehicles room to sneak up on the right.

en.question: Under what circumstances could a drive-wheel skid while pulling doubles lead to a jackknife?

options.A: The tractor brakes lock up
options.B: The trailer pushes the towed vehicle sideways
options.C: The trailer slides off the right side of the road

en.description: A drive-wheel skid can cause the trailer to push the towing vehicle sideways due to lost traction, leading to a jackknife.

en.question: What is a correct procedure for uncoupling a rear trailer?

options.A: When on firm ground, park the rig straight.
options.B: Lower the dolly too fast without checking the area.
options.C: Always disconnect the air lines before lowering the landing gear.

en.description: To safely uncouple the rear trailer, make sure the vehicle is straight and parked on firm, level ground.

en.question: What are three ways to make sure a second trailer is safely attached before linking it up?

options.A: Release the dolly brake by opening the air tank petcock or if the dolly has a spring brake, use the dolly parking brake control.
options.B: Wheel the dolly into position by hand so it is in line with the kingpin.
options.C: All of the above.

en.description: Ensuring the dolly brake is released and positioning the dolly correctly are both essential steps for safe attachment of a second trailer.

en.question: Do all converter dollies come with spring brakes?

options.A: Yes
options.B: No

en.description: All converter dollies are equipped with spring brakes to ensure they remain stationary when parked or in case of air pressure loss.

en.question: Is it necessary to conduct a walk-around inspection before pulling doubles or triples?

options.A: Yes
options.B: No

en.description: A thorough walk-around inspection is essential to ensure all parts of doubles or triples are safe and ready for the road.

en.question: Two different methods are used for uncoupling the second and third trailers.

options.A: TRUE
options.B: FALSE

en.description: The same standard method is used for uncoupling both the second and third trailers to ensure safety and consistency.

en.question: Coupling and uncoupling techniques are consistent across typical truck-trailer combinations, but there are various methods for coupling and uncoupling the diverse array of truck-trailer combinations in use.

options.A: TRUE
options.B: FALSE

en.description: While standard procedures apply to typical combinations, various trailer setups may require different techniques.

en.question: Many large trucks are equipped with convex, or "spot," mirrors. These mirrors __

options.A: Can only be used at night.
options.B: Make things look smaller and farther away than they really are
options.C: Require a special license to use

en.description: Convex mirrors provide a wider field of view but make objects appear smaller and farther away.

en.question: Once the rear truck is correctly connected to the converter dolly, ___

options.A: There should be no space between the upper and lower fifth wheel.
options.B: There should be 2 inches of space between the upper and lower fifth wheel.
options.C: There should be 3 inches of clearance between the upper and lower fifth wheel.

en.description: When properly coupled, the fifth wheel components should be flush with no visible gap.

en.question: To ensure optimal road handling when pulling doubles and triples, how should the load be placed?

options.A: Load evenly distributed across all trailers.
options.B: The heavier load in first position, the lighter in the rear.
options.C: Both trailers should have equal weights.

en.description: Placing the heavier load in the first trailer and the lighter in the rear improves stability and handling.

en.question: While driving a 100-foot twin trailer combination at 50 mph under dry road conditions and good visibility, what is the recommended minimum amount of space you should maintain ahead of you, measured in seconds?
en.description: Keep at least 11 seconds of space ahead of you when driving twin trailers at 50 mph under clear, dry conditions to allow safe stopping.

en.question: What precautions should be taken when connecting the converter dolly to the rear trailer?

options.A: Make sure trailer brakes are locked
options.B: Make sure trailer height is correct
options.C: Raise the landing gear slightly off the ground

en.description: All these steps—locking trailer brakes, ensuring correct height, and slightly raising the landing gear—are necessary for safely connecting the converter dolly.

en.question: To prevent which potential issue should you assess your truck protection valve?

options.A: The emergency brakes coming on due to loss of air
options.B: The loss of air from the air hose
options.C: The loss of air from your trailer brakes

en.description: Assessing the truck protection valve prevents multiple air system failures, including emergency brake engagement and trailer brake air loss.

en.question: When maneuvering to evade a collision with double trailers while pulling doubles, remember to __

options.A: Keep both hands on the steering wheel
options.B: Stay off the brake while turning
options.C: Be prepared to counter-steer

en.description: All listed actions—steady steering, avoiding braking mid-turn, and counter-steering—are key to safely avoiding collisions with doubles.

en.question: When operating triple trailers, which part is at a higher risk of rolling over?

options.A: The second trailer
options.B: The middle trailer
options.C: The last trailer

en.description: The last trailer in a triple combination is most prone to rollover due to amplified motion during turns or sudden maneuvers.

en.question: Is it advisable to release the pintle hook while the converter dolly remains under a trailer?

options.A: Yes, this is standard procedure
options.B: Yes, this keeps the trailer from falling
options.C: No, this could damage the pintle hook
options.D: No, this could result in your injury

en.description: Releasing the pintle hook with the dolly still under the trailer is hazardous and could lead to injury due to uncontrolled trailer movement.

en.question: When connecting twin trailers, you should disengage the dolly brakes by __

options.A: Flipping the switch near the driver's seat
options.B: Opening the air tank petcock
options.C: Turning off the vehicle engine.
options.D: Pushing the air release valve on the dash

en.description: Open the air tank petcock to release air and disengage the dolly brakes safely before connecting the second trailer.

en.question: To begin coupling doubles, start by__

options.A: Lowering the landing gear on the first trailer fully.
options.B: Backing the converter dolly under the second trailer
options.C: Closing the doors of the first trailer.
options.D: Putting the second trailer against a dock

en.description: The first step in coupling doubles is to back the converter dolly under the second trailer to align and connect it.

en.question: Trucks with double or triple trailers...

options.A: Have a dangerous 'crack the whip' effect
options.B: Present a rearward amplification hazard
options.C: Can turn over in response to abrupt steering movements

en.description: Double and triple trailer trucks are subject to all listed hazards—whip effect, amplification, and rollovers from sharp steering.

en.question: When uncoupling double trailers, where should you park your rig?

options.A: Near a water body
options.B: On level ground
options.C: Near a loading dock

en.description: Always park on level ground when uncoupling double trailers to ensure safety and stability.

en.question: During an inspection of doubles, what should be the position of the shut-off valves at the rear of a trailer?

options.A: Open at the rear of front trailer, open at the rear of the last trailer
options.B: Open at the rear of front trailer, closed at the rear of the last trailer
options.C: Closed at the rear of front trailer, open at the rear of the last trailer

en.description: Open the valves on the rear of the first trailer so air can flow to any trailing trailers. Close them on the rear of the last trailer to stop air from escaping and keep brake pressure stable.

en.question: During a walk-around inspection of a double or triple trailer rig, you should ensure the converter dolly air tank drain valves are __ and the pintle hook is __

options.A: Closed, locked.
options.B: Closed, unlocked
options.C: Closed, latched

en.description: When checking a big truck with two or three trailers, make sure the air tank valves under the trailers are shut tight and the hook connecting the trailers is securely latched.

en.question: Which part of a truck-trailer combination is most prone to rolling over due to the "crack the whip" effect?

options.A: The rear trailer of a double
options.B: A full trailer behind a truck
options.C: The rear trailer of a triple

en.description: When trucks with trailers make quick turns, the last trailer in a line of three is most likely to flip over. This is because it swings out the widest, kind of like the end of a whip. So, the rear trailer of a triple is most at risk, especially compared to just one trailer, no matter the weather.

en.question: Under what circumstances does the "driver's manual" recommend disengaging the steering axle brakes to maintain the vehicle's straight path?

options.A: Before going uphill.
options.B: When making a tight turn.
options.C: When the road is slippery

en.description: Never. You should not disconnect the steering axle brakes to keep the truck straight. Doing this can be dangerous. Always follow safe driving practices.

en.question: When driving a 100-foot truck with double trailers at 30 mph on a dry road with good visibility, ensure you maintain a distance of at least __ seconds ahead.
en.description: To drive a big truck with two trailers safely at 30 mph on a dry road, you should keep a distance of at least 10 seconds ahead of you. This helps ensure there's enough space to stop or slow down if needed.

en.question: When operating a truck with double or triple trailers, what actions should a driver take?

options.A: Use special care in bad weather and mountain conditions
options.B: Allow more following distance than for smaller vehicles
options.C: Both A and B

en.description: When driving a truck with double or triple trailers, the driver should take extra care in bad weather and mountain conditions. This helps to prevent accidents because these conditions can make driving more dangerous. Additionally, the driver should keep a larger distance between their truck and the vehicle in front of them compared to smaller vehicles. This extra space allows more time to stop or react if something unexpected happens.

en.question: When hauling multiple trailers, which trailer should be positioned directly behind the truck?

options.A: The oldest trailer
options.B: The heaviest trailer
options.C: The newest trailer

en.description: When pulling more than one trailer, the heaviest trailer should be directly behind the truck. This helps keep the drive smoother and safer.

en.question: How should you handle a skid to stop it?

options.A: Turn off the engine.
options.B: Countersteer and accelerate
options.C: Restore traction to the tires

en.description: To stop a skid, make sure the tires can grip the road again. Do this by steering gently in the direction you want to go and avoid braking hard.

en.question: Which statement accurately describes the relationship between quick steering movements and double/triple trailers?

options.A: Using cruise control is recommended for stability during quick steering moves.
options.B: Doubles / triples are no problem with a quick steering move
options.C: Quick steering movements increase stability for double and triple trailers.
options.D: Doubles / triples flip over from quick steering moves more easily than many other vehicles

en.description: When you make a rapid turn with a vehicle pulling two or three trailers, it's easier for those trailers to tip over compared to other types of vehicles. Be extra careful with quick steering.

en.question: When driving with double trailers and faced with the need to brake suddenly to prevent a collision, what action should you take for emergency braking?

options.A: Pump the brakes lightly and repeatedly.
options.B: Use only the trailer brakes
options.C: Use controlled or stab braking

en.description: If you're driving a truck with two trailers and need to stop quickly to avoid an accident, the best way to brake is to use controlled or stab braking. This means you apply the brakes fully until they almost lock up, then release them briefly before applying them fully again. Repeat this process to stop safely.

en.question: The shippers package hazardous materials, they must certify that this was done according to the regulations. The only exception is when:

options.A: The shipper is a private carrier carrying his or her own product
options.B: The shipment is a hazardous waste
options.C: The driver is given a sealed cargo compartment

en.description: When companies send out dangerous goods, they must follow rules to pack them safely. The only time they don't have to is if the company is moving its own products and not selling the service.

en.question: With most hazardous materials, you may park within 5 feet of the road briefly. If your work requires it. The materials that are the exception and do not allow parking this close to the road are?

options.A: Explosives 1.1 thru 1.3
options.B: Corrosives and oxidizers
options.C: Acids and poisons

en.description: When it comes to parking near the road with hazardous materials, you usually can if it's quick and needed for work. But, don't do this with very explosive materials (like fireworks or dynamite), flammable stuff (like gasoline or propane), because it's too dangerous.

en.question: By law, how regularly must employees involved in transporting hazardous materials be tested?

options.A: Within 90 days of hire and then every 6 months
options.B: At least every 5 years
options.C: Within 90 days of hire and then every 3 years

en.description: People who transport dangerous stuff must be tested within 90 days of starting their job and then every 3 years to make sure they know how to handle these materials safely.

en.question: How do you gain a hazardous material endorsement?

options.A: Pass a written test on the regulations and requirements.
options.B: Apply for the endorsement and pay the associated fee.
options.C: You must have been transporting hazardous materials for at least 5 years.

en.description: To get permission to carry dangerous goods, you must pass a written exam about the rules and what you need to do.

en.question: What forms can hazardous materials come in?

options.A: Gases, solids, and flammable and combustible liquids
options.B: Solids, gases, and combustible liquids
options.C: Gases and combustible liquids

en.description: Hazardous materials can be in different forms like gases (air-like materials), solids (hard or powdery substances), and liquids that can catch fire easily or burn slowly. These materials need special care when being moved to keep everyone safe.

en.question: When there is a hazardous materials emergency. You should:

options.A: Keep people away and warn them of the danger
options.B: Prevent smoking and keep open flames away
options.C: Both

en.description: In a hazardous materials emergency, it is important to both keep people away and warn them of the danger, as well as prevent smoking and keep open flames away. This helps ensure everyone's safety by reducing the risk of exposure to dangerous materials and preventing potential fires or explosions.

en.question: What is the Reportable Quantity of phosphoric acid?

options.A: 100 Pounds
options.C: 5000 Pounds

en.description: The right amount of phosphoric acid that needs to be reported if it spills is 5000 pounds.

en.question: Which of the following choices is a hazard class you are not allowed to smoke around?

options.A: Explosives
options.B: Oxidizers
options.C: Both

en.description: You can't smoke around both explosives and oxidizers because they are very dangerous and can easily catch fire or explode.

en.question: When fueling a placarded vehicle, someone must always be:

options.A: Within 10 feet of the pump with a fire extinguisher
options.B: At the nozzle, controlling the fuel flow
options.C: At the emergency power shut off for the pump

en.description: When putting fuel in a vehicle that has warning signs on it, someone needs to be right at the fuel pump, managing how the fuel goes in. This is to make sure everything is safe and under control during fueling.

en.question: What does ERG stand for?

options.A: Emergency Reporting Guidelines
options.B: Explosive Risk Guidelines
options.C: Emergency Response Guidebook

en.description: The correct answer, Emergency Response Guidebook, is a book that helps truck drivers know what to do if there's a dangerous spill or accident. It's like a handbook for dealing with emergencies safely.

en.question: The emergency response telephone number is the responsibility of which individual?

options.A: The local authorities
options.B: The shipper
options.C: The carrier

en.description: The person who sends the goods, known as the shipper, is responsible for providing the emergency phone number to call if there's an accident or problem during transport.

en.question: How many identical placards is a vehicle hauling hazardous materials required to display and where?

options.A: Four (4), two on the front and two on the back
options.B: Two (2), one on the front and one on the back
options.C: Four (4), one on the front, one on the back, and one on each side of the truck

en.description: A truck carrying dangerous stuff must show 4 signs. One sign goes on the front, one on the back, and one on each side of the truck. This helps everyone know it's carrying something risky.

en.question: Which of these materials does not have a Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds?

options.A: Phosphine
options.B: Phenylmercuric acetate
options.C: Phorate

en.description: Phorate does not have a Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds, meaning it has a different threshold for reporting spills or releases compared to Phosphine and Phenylmercuric acetate.

en.question: Which of the following is the most important package marking?

options.A: Name of hazardous material
options.B: Name and address of shipper
options.C: Name and address of consignee

en.description: The most important marking on a package is the name of the hazardous material. This helps identify what's inside so it can be handled safely.

en.question: You may not park a vehicle carrying hazardous materials within ___feet of an open fire.
en.description: You can't park a vehicle with dangerous goods closer than 300 feet from a fire.

en.question: What are 'containment rules'?

options.A: Rules that inform drivers of the proper way to load, transport, and unload bulk tanks.
options.B: Rules that inform drivers of the proper way to load bulk tanks.
options.C: Rules that inform drivers on how to safely transport large quantities of hazardous material.

en.description: Containment rules tell drivers the right way to pack, move, and unpack big tanks safely.

en.question: When is it necessary to ground the trailer?

options.A: Only when filling a trailer with explosives
options.B: Only when unloading a cargo tank filled with any flammable liquid
options.C: When filling or unloading any flammable liquid tank, ground must be maintained until filling hole is properly closed

en.description: You need to connect the trailer to the ground when you're filling or emptying tanks with stuff that can catch fire. Keep it connected until you've properly sealed the tank again.

en.question: What type fire extinguisher is required in the power unit of a placarded vehicle?

options.A: A U.L. rating of 10 B:C or above
options.B: A U.L. rating of 5 B:C or above
options.C: A U.L. rating of 15 ABC

en.description: For trucks carrying hazardous materials, they must have a fire extinguisher with a U.L. rating of 10 B:C or more. This means it's strong enough to put out fires caused by flammable liquids and electrical equipment.

en.question: Which of the following is the proper definition of a cargo tank?

options.A: A bulk container permanently attached to a vehicle
options.B: A bulk container not permanently attached to a vehicle
options.C: Both

en.description: A cargo tank is a large container that is permanently fixed to a vehicle to carry bulk items.

en.question: What does an orange placard represent?

options.A: Hazardous contents
options.B: Flammable contents
options.C: Explosive contents

en.description: An orange placard on a vehicle is a warning sign that tells you the truck is carrying explosive materials. It's a safety warning to keep distance and to be cautious around it.

en.question: A truck carrying explosives has crashed with another vehicle. You should not pull them apart until?

options.A: The shipper's loading foreman is present
options.B: The explosives have been placed at least 200 feet away from the vehicles and occupied buildings
options.C: At least 30 minutes have passed

en.description: If a truck with explosives crashes with another vehicle, don't try to separate them until the local traffic officials say it's okay. Make sure any explosives are moved 200 feet away from the vehicles and buildings around.

en.question: If an 'x' or 'ra' is in the 'hm' column of a shipping paper entry, the:

options.A: Material listed on that line in the largest part of the shipment
options.B: Entry refers to the materials that must be top loaded
options.C: Shipment is regulated by hazardous material regulations

en.description: If you see an 'x' or 'ra' in the 'hm' column on a shipping paper, it means the shipment contains hazardous materials that must follow special rules.

en.question: Which of the following helps to identify which placard to use?

options.A: Materials hazard class
options.B: Amount being shipped
options.C: Both

en.description: To choose the correct placard, you need to consider both the hazard class of the material and the amount being shipped.

en.question: To find out if a shipment includes a hazardous material, you should:

options.A: Open and inspect every package and container
options.B: Check for a fence around the loading dock
options.C: Look at the shipping papers

en.description: To know if a shipment has dangerous goods, check the shipping papers. They list what's inside.

en.question: Which of these is a Class 1 hazardous material?

options.A: Dynamite
options.B: Helium
options.C: Propane

en.description: Dynamite is the right answer because it's a type of explosive. This makes it a Class 1 hazardous material because it can cause a lot of damage if it's not handled properly.

en.question: Why is it important that shipping papers are placed correctly in the vehicle?

options.A: So that you don't waste time at your destination.
options.B: In the event of an emergency, they may get damaged.
options.C: In the event of an emergency, you may not be able to speak.

en.description: It's crucial to put shipping papers right in the vehicle so in emergencies, if you can't talk, others can quickly see what you're carrying.

en.question: Who is responsible for checking to be sure the shipper correctly named, labeled, and marked a hazardous materials shipment?

options.A: The shipper
options.B: The carrier
options.C: The driver

en.description: The carrier, who physically transports the shipment, has the key responsibility of verifying that the shipper has accurately identified, labeled, and marked the hazardous materials.

en.question: You can't haul 1.1 explosives with?

options.A: Cargo tank without baffles
options.B: Radioactive material
options.C: OMR-D materials

en.description: Radioactive materials pose unique hazards, and combining them with high-explosive materials increases the risk of both radioactive contamination and a large-scale explosion.

en.question: Which of the following must drivers have in their possession while transporting class 1.1 or 1.3 explosives?

options.A: The carrier's insurance policy
options.B: The written route plan
options.C: Both

en.description: When moving class 1.1 or 1.3 explosives, drivers need to carry a written plan showing the route they'll take.

en.question: What placard must be used with an inhalation hazard load?

options.A: Dangerous
options.B: Poison/inhalation hazard
options.C: Flammable

en.description: When hauling a load that's dangerous to breathe in, you must use a 'Poison/Inhalation Hazard' sign. This warns people about the risky material you're carrying.

en.question: How many hazard classes are there?
en.description: There are 9 different types of dangers or hazard classes that truck drivers need to know about when they are carrying goods. These classes help them understand what kind of special care or rules they need to follow to keep the roads safe.

en.question: A truck has hazardous material, when can it be moved without the placards on the truck?

options.A: Never
options.B: When the shipper says it's ok
options.C: To protect life or property

en.description: A truck carrying hazardous materials must display placards, except in emergencies where removing or relocating the truck is necessary to protect life or prevent property damage.

en.question: In the symbol column, the letter 'G' stands for?

options.A: Gases
options.B: Identifies the proper shipping name for which one or more technical names of the hazardous material must be entered in parentheses, along with the basic description
options.C: Identifies the proper shipping name

en.description: The letter 'G' in the hazardous materials table means you must include the technical name(s) of the hazardous substance in parentheses with the basic description.

en.question: The driver must also carry on his person at all times a dated certificate signed by the employer. This certificate must also be updated every

options.A: 1 year
options.B: 2 years
options.C: 3 years

en.description: Truck drivers carrying hazardous materials must have a training certificate signed by their employer, which must be updated every 2 years.

en.question: How many identical placards are required on a vehicle transporting hazardous materials?
en.description: When transporting hazardous materials, four placards are required—one on the front, one on the back, and one on each side of the vehicle.

en.question: In what order are proper shipping names listed in the hazardous materials table?

options.A: Alphabetical
options.B: By packing group
options.C: By hazard class

en.description: Proper shipping names are listed alphabetically in the hazardous materials table to make them easier to locate.

en.question: Whose responsibility is it to package the hazardous product correctly?

options.A: The shipper
options.B: The carrier

en.description: The shipper is responsible for ensuring hazardous materials are correctly packaged according to regulations for safe transport.

en.question: On a public roadway with a placarded tanker hauling flammable liquids, when can you transfer from one tanker to another?

options.A: In an emergency situation
options.B: When the fire department is there
options.C: You should never make a transfer

en.description: Transfers between tankers on public roadways are only allowed in emergency situations where safety is at risk.

en.question: A vehicle contains 500 pounds each of explosives 1.1 and 1.3, you must use:

options.A: explosives 1.1 placards
options.B: dangerous placards
options.C: blasting agents placards

en.description: When carrying 500 pounds or more of explosives 1.1 and 1.3, the vehicle must display 'explosives 1.1' placards.

en.question: What does 'RQ' stand for?

options.A: Regulated Quality
options.B: Reduced Quality
options.C: Reportable Quantity

en.description: RQ stands for Reportable Quantity, which means the amount of hazardous substance that requires reporting if released.

en.question: Which hazard class does sodium come under?

options.A: Flammable liquid
options.B: Spontaneously combustible when wet
options.C: Spontaneously combustible

en.description: Sodium reacts violently with water and can ignite on contact. It's classified under materials that are spontaneously combustible when wet.

en.question: In the hazardous material table, column 3, any shipping name written in italics means?

options.A: Just another way of writing the shipping name
options.B: That this substance is highly flammable
options.C: It isn't the proper shipping name, those in roman type above it are

en.description: Italicized names in the hazardous materials table are not proper shipping names. Use the non-italicized (roman type) names listed above them.

en.question: What action should you take if you see the phrase "Inhalation Hazard" on your shipping paper?

options.A: Ensure good ventilation.
options.B: Display "poison" or "poison gas" placard.
options.C: Display a Class 5 placard.

en.description: If your shipping papers say "Inhalation Hazard," you must display a placard that says 'Poison' or 'Poison Gas' to warn of breathing dangers.

en.question: Which of these is not a responsibility of the driver?

options.A: Follow all rules about transporting hazardous materials.
options.B: Deny leaking shipments.
options.C: Decide the identification number of the product.

en.description: The shipper is responsible for assigning the correct identification number. The driver follows regulations and checks for safety.

en.question: The total transport index of all radioactive material packages in a single vehicle must not exceed -
en.description: The transport index is a number that shows radiation levels. The total must not go over 50 per vehicle for safety.

en.question: If there is an RQ before or after the item description on the shipping paper, it means the:

options.A: Material has an insurance value of over $1,000
options.B: Material is in a package containing no other materials
options.C: Carrier must report any spill of this material

en.description: RQ means 'Reportable Quantity.' If spilled, it must be reported to proper authorities because it could pose a hazard.

en.question: What three things do you need to know to decide which placards (if any) you need?

options.A: Amount of all hazardous material on your truck, the weight of the material, the color of the material.
options.B: What you were told is on the truck, the amount of material on the truck, material's hazard class.
options.C: Material's hazard class, amount being shipped, amount of all hazardous material on your truck.

en.description: To pick the correct placards, you must know the hazard class, the amount you're shipping, and the total of all hazardous materials onboard.

en.question: What information must be shown on a hazardous materials shipping paper, and in what order?

options.A: Proper shipping name, packing group, ID number, hazard class
options.B: ID number, proper shipping name, hazard class, packing group
options.C: Hazard class, proper shipping name, ID number, packing group

en.description: Hazardous materials shipping papers must list in order: ID number, proper shipping name, hazard class, and packing group.

en.question: Drivers placard their vehicle to __ the risk.

options.A: Stop
options.B: Minimize
options.C: Show

en.description: Placards are used to **show** that the vehicle contains hazardous materials. This alerts others to the risk for safety purposes.

en.question: Who is responsible for signing the shipping documents for hazardous materials?

options.A: The driver hauling the hazardous materials.
options.B: The shipper packaging the hazardous materials.
options.C: The owner of the truck hauling the materials.

en.description: The shipper is responsible for properly preparing and signing the shipping documents for hazardous materials before transport.

en.question: What are cargo tanks?

options.A: Tanks that are not permanently attached to a vehicle.
options.B: Tanks that are put on the vehicle for transportation.
options.C: Tanks that remain on the vehicle when you load and unload them.

en.description: Cargo tanks are special tanks that stay on the vehicle while loading and unloading. They are used to transport liquids or gases and are not removed from the truck.

en.question: In what order do the following operate?

options.A: Carrier, driver, shipper
options.B: Shipper, driver, carrier
options.C: Shipper, carrier, driver

en.description: First, the shipper prepares the shipment. Then the carrier takes responsibility for transport. Finally, the driver physically moves the goods. The correct order is shipper, carrier, driver.

en.question: Around which hazard classes must you never smoke?

options.A: Class 1 explosives, class 4 flammable solids, class 5 oxidizers, class 3 flammable liquids
options.B: Class 8 explosives, class 6 flammable solids, class 7 explosives, class 5 flammable solids
options.C: Class 1 through 5 flammable liquids

en.description: Smoking is not allowed near materials that are explosive, flammable, or can help other materials burn faster. These include Class 1, 3, 4, and 5 hazardous materials.

en.question: Which three hazard classes should not be loaded into a trailer that has a heater or air conditioner unit?

options.A: Class 4 explosives, class 1 oxidizer, class 8 flammable solid
options.B: Class 1 explosives, class 4 flammable solids, class 5 oxidizers
options.C: Class 1 flammable solid, class 2 flammable solid, class 3 flammable solid

en.description: Explosives (Class 1), flammable solids (Class 4), and oxidizers (Class 5) should not be in trailers with temperature control units, which could trigger combustion.

en.question: Shippers package in order to the material__

options.A: Safely ship
options.B: Quickly ship
options.C: Cheaply ship

en.description: Shippers package goods to make sure they’re transported safely and arrive undamaged. Safety is always the main goal.

en.question: What is a portable tank?

options.A: Tanks that are permanently attached to a vehicle.
options.B: Tanks that are not permanently attached to a vehicle and are loaded and unloaded while the tank is off the vehicle.
options.C: Tanks that are sometimes attached and sometimes not attached to a vehicle

en.description: Portable tanks can be removed from a vehicle and are usually filled or emptied when not on the truck. They’re not permanently attached.

en.question: What is shipper's certification?

options.A: Certifies that the package has been prepared according to the rules.
options.B: Certifies that the materials have been paid for.
options.C: Certifies that the driver has a CDL with Hazardous Material Endorsement.

en.description: The shipper’s certification is a statement that the package was prepared and labeled according to legal and safety rules.

en.question: Where must you keep shipping papers describing hazardous materials?

options.A: In the tool storage area.
options.B: In the driver's wallet.
options.C: In the cab of the tractor driver door or in view within immediate reach.

en.description: Shipping papers for hazardous materials must be kept in the truck cab, either on the driver's door or where they can be quickly reached and seen.

en.question: An order contains both hazardous and nonhazardous materials. Which of the following is not an appropriate way marking the hazardous materials on the shipping paper?

options.A: The letters "NHM" in the column "HM."
options.B: Highlighted in a contrasting color.
options.C: The letter "X" or "RQ" in a column marked "HM."

en.description: "NHM" stands for non-hazardous material and should not be used to mark hazardous goods. Use an "X," "RQ," or highlight to mark hazardous items properly.

en.question: What must a driver have before transporting hazardous materials?

options.A: A CDL with a HazMat endorsement
options.B: A safety inspection report
options.C: An escort vehicle

en.description: Drivers must have a Commercial Driver’s License (CDL) with a Hazardous Materials (HazMat) endorsement to legally and safely transport hazardous materials.
